DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1987SHIPS (CAPITAL GRANTS) BILL 1987MINISTERS OF STATE AMENDMENT BILL 1987DEFENCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, 7 May, 20 March and 28 April, on motions:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the Bills before the Senate is the Social Security Amendment Bill 1987. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) described this Bill as `measures to streamline the Social Security Act and its administration'. That all sounds quite innocuous; however, this Bill covers a multitude of sins. I will quote from the Minister's second reading speech. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members will be aware, the Government has taken initiatives to ensure that social security expenditure is limited to those who are eligible under the Act. Measures have also been taken to reduce the level of overpayments. This includes initiatives to limit fraud and to detect and prosecute those who abuse the system.

That sounds fine. In line with that, the Minister assured us some time ago that the easy time for dole cheats was over and the work test would be enforced. He said that the Government would crack down on them. That statement was hardly put in a restrained manner. I am sure that everyone here would agree. It was only recently that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that there needed to be a tougher work test.

Let us see what the Government has done to tighten up the Act to overcome these excessive frauds and overpayments occurring in the Department of Social Security. The Minister assured us in his second reading speech that he would toughen up the work test. At the time of the last Budget we were told with much fanfare that the Government would undertake a review of all young unemployed people who had been unemployed for more than two years. There were to be interviews and counselling in an effort to see whether we could help all those young people who had been unemployed for more than two years. The Government was also to conduct a review to look at their financial position to make sure that these people were not defrauding the Government, that they were not accepting the unemployment benefit while they had jobs or part time jobs. This was thought to be necessary because the increase in the long term unemployed had ballooned under this Government.

But what actually happened? The Minister made his high falutin statements and members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association-the union of officers of the Department of Social Security-refused to carry out the Minister's requests. They said that they would not ask the questions the Minister had set them to ask, that they would not ask any questions if they did not feel like it, that they would not ask for any identification if they did not feel like it and, indeed, that they would do their own thing and were not going to be told what to do by the Minister. We all remember their work bans. They would not undertake the direction of the Minister. As usual, the Government was helpless before the onslaught of these unions. Nothing was done. The Minister sat on his hands for nearly 12 months. There was no crackdown on fraud and no reviews took place,-nothing at all.

Finally, the Government has brought this legislation before us. It has done a real cave in. The unions have told it what they are prepared to do and the Minister has backed off. He said: `All right, you do what you want to do and we will conduct this public relations exercise for the benefit of the people of Australia because, after all, we are facing an election. We have to pretend to the people of Australia that we really are cracking down on the fraud that is going on within the Department'. The Auditor-General has already said that fraud is going on. The estimate is that the Government has been defrauded of roughly $1 billion. So we will just see in this legislation what the Government has been prepared to do.

Let us not forget the questions that the Minister for Social Security wanted asked. Those questions simply are not being asked. Unions blatantly have refused to do so. They say: `If we think it is necessary we will ask those questions-but only if we think it is necessary'. The Minister has sat back and said: `All right, you take over. You ask the questions you think are necessary'. The Minister asks that questions be asked and that each page of the declaration be signed by the applicant for unemployment benefits. Unions have said: `We will not enforce that. We will not make them do that. People can sign at the end of the declaration, and that is all'. There will be one signature only. The unions also said that they would not indulge in any counselling unless they saw fit. It is up to the officers to determine the format and length of the interview. The Government has even backed off the requirement in the review to ask questions relating to identity because the officers said: `We will not be told by the Government how to conduct a review'. Employees of the Government have told it that they will conduct the review in the way they want. They will not necessarily ask questions about identity. If they do not want to they will not ask any questions at all and the declaration will have only one signature.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) admitted last year that he believed about 10,000 unemployed people were getting benefits that they were not entitled to. A pilot group of 4,000 people was interviewed. Of those 4,000 people, 1,000-a quarter-were getting unemployment benefits that they were not entitled to. But as for being able to investigate this throughout the whole of the Department, the unions have informed the Minister that that is not on. They will do what they want to do. This legislation increases penalties. I will read from the Minister's second reading speech:
Penalties are to be increased for other offences under the Act. For failure to comply with the requirements to report circumstances or events which affect entitlement to a social security payment-
that is good stuff-
the penalty will be increased from a $500 fine to a $1,000 fine or six months imprisonment, or both . . .
It goes on:

For failure to comply with a requirement to provide information about entitlement, the fine will be increased from $1,000 and six months imprisonment to $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment, or both . . .

That sounds like good stuff. But if the questions are not being asked, if identification is not being insisted upon and if signatures are not put on each page, as the Minister requested, how will any misstatements be proved? So we find in this legislation that the Minister is having a good public relations exercise-but that is all. He is not forcing his officers to carry out his demands. He is not forcing his employees to do the job that he wants them to do. I quote again from the Minister's second reading speech:

Section 17 of the Principal Act places an obligation on officers not to divulge personal information obtained in the course of their duties. This section will be extended in line with the secrecy provisions in other Commonwealth legislation such as the Income Tax Assessment Act. Reference to `officers' will include former officers as well as others performing work for the Commonwealth . . .

The Government sees the need for tightening the security of information. I could not agree more. I certainly am not critical of the officers of the Department. We are all well aware that there are a few-I stress `a few'-bad apples in every group of people. On one occasion some officers were caught selling private information. The Minister, very correctly, is trying to tighten up that area. So there is an attempt by the Government to tighten up the secrecy provisions but it will have to do a lot better than that before it can introduce an Australia-wide Australia Card. There is no guarantee at all that that private information can be kept secret. So much more is attached to that Bill.

The Bill also provides for the indexation of the threshold limits on the assets test. Whilst under this Government I certainly would support the indexing of the threshold limits on the assets test, under our government there will not be this Government's assets test on the aged-no way in the wide world-and the people of Australia know it. One of our promises-and there have not been many-is that we will do away with the inhumane, uncaring and lacking in incentive assets test. There is no doubt in the community that after 11 July the assets test will go.

Another area of the Bill we agree with is the provision whereby the Department's decision can be appealed against in every situation. This is very important to the rights of the people. I am glad to see it in this legislation. It is not so with some of the other Government legislation we will be discussing later in the week. There are a number of minor amendments, including provision for more effective recovery of compensation claims. Again, we agree with this. Perhaps of greatest concern to the Opposition is that this Government has attempted to sneak through-I say this because it is the truth-a redefinition of the words `de facto spouse'. It was not mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech or in the substantive legislation but is tucked away in the Schedule to the Bill. What has this Government done? This Government and its Ministers lack any standards. Do honourable senators remember Mick Young's long lunch? Mick Young was on the most secret committee this Government has, or any previous government had, which deals with the security of Australia and what did he divulge? He divulged to one of his mates the fact that they were tossing out a Russian spy and that Combe was involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Walters's remarks have nothing to do with the Bill at hand. I ask you to bring her to order and ask her to address her remarks to the legislation being debated.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: It is the Government which has put together a series of Bills under this guillotine, including the mixture of social security amendments, which reduce the entitlements of invalid pensioners and widows; the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill, which provides for Commonwealth funds to be made available for ship building; and the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, which enables money to be paid to Ministers of State. It is not the fault of the Opposition that we are dealing with this disparate group of Bills. Talking about the behaviour of Ministers of this Government, including Mr Young who was guilty of a breach of national security in the rather shameful way that was indicated by Senator Walters, is perfectly legitimate in debate that includes debate on legislation that goes to the payments received, if not very adequately earned, by Ministers including the Minister at the table. I object in the strongest possible terms to a point of order on the issue of relevance when this Government, because of its untimely and early election that the Prime Minister promised he would not hold, has forced us to debate this extraordinary grab bag of Bills. Then the Minister dares to take a point of order, disturbing Senator Walters's comments on these Bills in this way. Clearly, there is no point of order and I think that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, should tell the Minister that she should not interrupt debate in this political and pathetic manner.
—I have noted the point of order. Senator Walters, I would ask you to stay within the guidelines.
—I am talking about the standards in this legislation that I believe have been downgraded by this Government and, as such, I am talking about standards--
—Senator Walters, I have ruled that you can continue and I have asked you to stay within the guidelines.

—Under your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President, still I come back to the standards of this Government. As I said we had the case of Mick Young, and also we had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) refusing to fill in his income tax forms. What sorts of standards are these? He received a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation--

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I suggest that Senator Walters is defying the Chair. Now she is making allegations about the Treasurer which, even with the fantastic leaps of imagination in which Senator Chaney has just engaged, cannot be regarded as being in any way pertinent to the legislation.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Your ruling was that the senator on her feet could proceed. You did not rule her out of order and the point is that the Government has put before us legislation including legislation that involves the Ministers of this Government. It is acceptable to talk about the performance of those Ministers and, in my view, it would be quite wrong of you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to interfere with any comments that Senator Walters may choose to make about the performance of Ministers when we are debating whether or not we should pass legislation that enables the Ministers to be paid even more handsome salaries. Your previous ruling certainly was not a ruling to which I objected because, as I understood it, you did not rule Senator Walters out of order. The Minister has totally misinterpreted your ruling. As far as I am concerned, the Opposition would strongly resist any suggestion that, in these cognate debates that have been forced upon us by the Government, there is anything to prevent senators addressing matters that go to the range of Bills that are before us.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I draw Senator Chaney's attention to the fact that you have already ruled that Senator Walters was to stay within the bounds of the legislation before the chamber. She has deliberately moved outside the bounds of that legislation, and once again I have to ask, as part of my point of order, that you call her to order and tell her to remain within the Bills that are before the chamber at this time.
—Senator Walters, I request once again that you stay within the realms of the Bills and I request that you respect the Chair by doing so.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek clarification from you. I would like to know what your ruling is. Are you ruling that in this debate, which includes debate on the Ministers of state legislation, senators are not entitled to discuss the performance of Ministers for whom pay rises are being sought through this legislation? I ask whether you are ruling that.
—What I am asking is that Senator Walters stay within the realms of the Bills before the House.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your clarification. The honourable senator was addressing questions relating to the conduct of Ministers of this Government. You have twice allowed her to be interrupted by points of order which suggest that her doing that is outside the bounds of the debate. Mr Acting Deputy President, your ruling is not at all clear to me and I would like to know whether you are ruling--
—I am certainly not ruling that Senator Walters cannot refer to Ministers of state. What I am asking is that she does not go outside the realms of the Bill.

—That makes it very clear to me. Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. Your ruling also makes it clear to the Government that I can, indeed, refer to the Ministers of state. I am referring to the standards of these Ministers. I have already referred to Mick Young. I have already referred to the fact that he divulged secret security matters of this country to his mates and was, indeed, suspended for a time. He then brought into this country undeclared goods and another inquiry was undertaken on his behalf. What standards do we have? We then had the Treasurer, Mr Keating, refusing to fill in his tax returns. He got a special letter from the Commissioner of Taxation pleading with him to do so, and he refused to do so for two years running. Citizens of Australia are fined if they do not fill in their tax returns but the Treasurer said that he was too busy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I refer you to the requirement of relevance, beyond which I would strongly argue that Senator Walters is now trespassing to the extent that her remarks do not bear upon the remuneration of Ministers, which is the subject matter of the Ministers of State Amendment Bill before us, but rather on other alleged matters of their behaviour. As such, I would ask you to draw Senator Walters's attention to the Standing Orders on that ground alone. Secondly, I refer you to standing order 418, which I will quote. It is expressed, as I am sure you are well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, in the following terms:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall use offensive words against either House of Parliament or any Member of such House . . . unless for the purpose of moving for its repeal-
I do not think that is applicable in this instance-
and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

We have-not in the context of a substantive motion about the Ministers in question but in the context, at best, of a Bill which deals with an addition to the remuneration of Ministers of state, now some 12 months old-reflections on members of the other place, Ministers in the other place, which are highly disorderly within the meaning of standing order 418, and I urge you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to call Senator Walters to order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters, I think you are going a bit too far, and I am suggesting that you stay within the realms of the Bill and do not make remarks about--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, it is obvious that the Government does not want me to speak about the standards of Ministers. I will not do so, because they have now taken 10 minutes of my time. But I will refer to the standards in this legislation, which, as I said, are being sneaked through. The Minister was not prepared to speak about this matter in his speech, but we find that the Government has redefined `de facto spouse' and it is prepared to pay a married rate of social security benefit to underaged children committing crimes by living together. Mr Acting Deputy President, let us just suggest that your little girl of 14 was infatuated with a bloke a bit older, say 16. She might have a few arguments at home about doing her homework and she might then say: `I am going to live with Joe Blow'. You could rightly say: `You can't do that. How would you survive?'. She could then say: `The Government will pay me the married rate to live with Joe Blow down the hill as a de facto spouse'. That is how the Government has redefined `de facto spouse' in this legislation. That is why the Government refused to acknowledge that in the Minister's second reading speech or in the legislation but tucked it away in the Schedule.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government says it will pay minors, but I might add that in every State it is a crime for a young girl, without special permission, to live in a married relationship with a more senior male. If they are to be married, a judge and the parents must give permission. There is a whole range of areas where permission must be granted. But this Government is prepared to pay people a married rate if they want to live in a de facto relationship without any permission at all being granted. It is a disgrace. We have been told by the Government on so many occasions that we should not impose our middle class morality on the people of Australia, but that is because the Government has no morals. It is taking action deliberately to encourage young girls and boys to get away from home; it is undermining the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I ask you to draw Senator Walters's attention to the fact that her fulminations are directed against a clause in the Bill that the Government has foreshadowed it will amend. That underlines what Senator Walters is suggesting, and accordingly I ask Senator Walters to bear that in mind in making her remarks.
—There is no point of order.

—That is no point of order at all. This is the legislation that got through the House of Representatives purely because the Government had the numbers. Indeed the Opposition is putting up an amendment. This is not the Government's amendment. The Bill was passed unamended in the House of Representatives. If the Government was sincere and wanted to amend it, it would have done so in the House of Representatives. The Government did not want to amend the Bill. It was pushed through the House of Representatives. The Opposition is putting up an amendment which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 15, Part 1 of Schedule 1, omit the amendment of the definition of ``de facto spouse'' in subsection 6 (1).
(2) Page 16, Part 1 of Schedule 1, after the amendment of the definition of ``Reserve Forces'' in subsection 6 (1), insert the following amendment:
``Section 6:
Add at the end the following subsections:
`(10) Where:
(a) a person who is living with another person of the opposite sex as the spouse of that other person on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married to that other person; and
(b) either of those persons is under the age of consent applicable in the State or Territory in which those persons are living;
neither of those persons shall be treated as a married person for the purposes of this Act.

`(11) The rate of a pension, benefit or allowance under this Act payable to a person to whom subsection (10) applies shall not exceed the rate at which it would be payable to the person if the person were married to the other person.'.''.

We have refused to back down and public pressure has forced the Government to withdraw and accept our amendment. We will not tolerate the standards of Australian families being lowered by this Government. That is what the Government has done ever since it came to office. There is no way in the world the Opposition will allow it to carry out the destruction of the family any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ships (Capital Grants) Bill 1987 provides a grant of 7 per cent of the price of new trading ships whether purchased or newly built or 7 per cent of the modification cost of existing ships. These grants could be substantial. A new bulk carrier would cost between $30m and $50m, so 7 per cent of that could result in a grant of $3.5m. It is appropriate-in fact it is essential-that we should provide support to Australian shipping in capital costs, for virtually all our competitors already do this, and capital costs are by far the biggest shipping expense. Although, of course, the balance of costs varies with such things as the changing costs of fuel, a typical breakdown of the costs of running a ship is: Forty-seven per cent capital, 19 per cent fuel, 14 per cent manpower, 8 per cent port charges, and 12 per cent for the remainder, of which by far the largest cost is for repairs and maintenance. As I have said, because our competitors do provide capital assistance to ship owners, it is essential if our shipping is to be fairly competitive, that we should do likewise. I would be grateful if the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), when she closes this debate, could provide more detail about the financial impact statement provided with this Bill, or if the Minister is not going to respond to the debate, she could table a statement in answer to these questions before the Senate rises. The questions are as follows: How many ships are expected to be eligible for this grant? How is the foreign exchange contribution of $40m to $50m a year to be achieved? How is the saving of $40m a year from the use of more efficient coastal ships to be achieved? Further, can the Minister provide a breakdown of the estimated boost to tax receipts from increased profits and job creation?

SPEECH.PARA: I observe that the balance of payments argument is also part of the Government's rationale for this Bill. The balance of payments bogy has long been a favourite catchcry for those encouraging us to put our trade into Australian ships. At first sight the argument is plausible. As the `Moving Ahead' report stated, `Australia has the fifth largest shipping task of the world's trading nations on a tonne/kilometre basis. Yet Australian ships carry only about 3 per cent (by volume) of our overseas trade. The cost of the 1984-85 sea freight bill to the deficit for invisibles amounted to $5,800m, and this cost represented approximately 11 per cent of the total value of Australia's overseas trade'. The Minister claims that this is a heavy burden on our balance of payments. However, the experts do not agree on the balance of payments argument. Many of them have estimated that the effects of freight costs in foreign ships are offset by the lower freight rates offered by them, compared to the higher freight rates in Australian ships-which is the result of the high costs of manning our ships. If we are to carry more of our trade in Australian ships-and I would very much like us to do so-our costs must be competitive with foreign ships. That, of course, is the purported intention of this Bill.

Nevertheless, if we are going to make capital grants of as much as $3.5m a ship, it is obviously necessary that conditions should be attached to ensure that the objective of making Australian shipping competitive with the shipping of other countries is achieved. In this respect the Government's proposals are quite inadequate. The Government does indeed attach conditions, but they are not nearly stringent enough to achieve the objective of making Australian shipping internationally competitive.

What conditions does the Government impose? The ship attracting the grant must be a trading ship, a tanker, a container vessel, a bulk carrier or a liner, crewed with Australian residents at a maximum level of 21, except in the case of tankers on the coastal trade, for which the maximum crew level is set at 23. The ship to attract a grant must also be owned and registered in Australia. This Bill is the result of one of the recommendations in the recent report of the Maritime Industry Development Committee, called `Moving Ahead'. This Committee concluded that a modern bulk carrier, either a new or a modified second-hand vessel, should be manned as follows: Four deck officers, including the master, one radio officer, four engineer officers, and 12 ratings, integrated and catering-making a total crew of 21. This crew of 21 is still very large by international standards. A modern West German ship, for instance, operates with a total crew of 17, compared with our proposed crew size of 21. On the West German ship three are deck officers, including the master, which would mean that the master would have to keep a watch. I can see no objection to this on international voyages, but there would be some difficulties on a coastal vessel. A West German ship would also have a radio officer, two engineer officers and one electrical officer. The reason that we have four engineer officers on Australian ships-one chief engineer and three watch-keeping engineer officers-is that we are still stuck with the idea of someone brooding over the machinery all the time it is running. Other countries have woken up to the fact that with modern machinery this is not necessary, and it is a step that we should follow. Finally, a West German ship would have 10 ratings instead of 12.

Although the proposed Australian crew of 21 is still far too high-it means that our crew levels are still about 20 per cent greater than those of our competitors-nevertheless it is a great improvement on present Australian crew levels. It may sound extraordinary, but last year when we had 21 Australian flag vessels engaged in overseas trade the average crew was well over 30. One of these ships, the Iron Sirius, had a crew of 40; the Iron Shortland had a crew of 39; two ships had crews of 35; six had 33; five had 32; two had 31; two had 27; and two had 26. In other words, 17 of our 21 overseas trading ships still operate with a crew of more than 30, and only four have crews of less than 30. All are still far above this new level of 21, and none of these ships will be affected by this new legislation which will apply only to newly purchased or converted ships. We are still a very long way from facing up to the economic realities of manning levels on our ships.

I accept that we must proceed step by step in reducing our crew sizes because one of the necessities is ratings trained in more than one discipline, and the production of such ratings by the Australian Maritime College does take time. Nevertheless, we must keep on pressing to bring our crew sizes into line with those of our competitors; otherwise we will never be competitive. For that reason I shall be moving in the Committee stage that, instead of the figure of 21 being fixed permanently in the Bill as the crew size, the crew size will be reviewed annually and adjusted by regulation. I hope that in a few years it will be down to levels which other nations find satisfactory.

Nothing in the legislation, says the Minister, will prevent ships from being operated with lower crew levels provided that that can be done with safety. Frankly, I cannot imagine any union in present circumstances agreeing to a crew level of less than 21 while 21 is still enshrined in this Bill. The union response, of course, will be that it cannot be done with safety. If some honourable senators think that I am being unjust or cynical, they should remember that one of our ships still carries a crew of 40. Therefore, I will be moving in the Committee stage for a provision for an annual review of this figure of 21 in the light of developments in crewing and manning levels in comparable Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development ships. We must not get carried away with 21 being the best possible level that we can achieve. We should be aiming for crew levels well below 20 and for manning conditions matching those of comparable overseas shipping nations. Only then will we begin to be competitive.

Before I leave crew size, some other problems concern me. Although tankers engaged in foreign trade will have a crew level of 21, tankers engaged in the coastal trade will have their crew level set at 23. I have heard two arguments why this should be so: The first is that coastal tankers carry refined fuel, which requires more care in loading and handling than the bulk oil usually carried by tankers in the foreign trade, and the second is that coastal tankers have more ports of call and therefore more handling of the cargo is required. I am not in the least convinced by these arguments. I see no reason why Australian seamen should not be at least as productive as foreign competitors. A coastal tanker manned by the West Germans would have a crew of 16 and one manned by the Japanese would have a crew of 14. Why on earth do we require a crew of 23?

I shall move an amendment at the Committee stage to bring the crew for coastal tankers back to a maximum of 21 which, I again emphasise, is extremely generous by international standards. There have been far too many rorts for far too long in our coastal shipping trade. These rorts have made coastal shipping very expensive and, coupled with our deplorable port handling arrangements, have resulted in cargoes that should, on any economic criteria, go by sea being sent by land instead. Typically, such cargoes have not gone by the next most economic method of transport-that is rail-because, despite the extraordinary subsidies paid by State governments to rail transport, the incredible incompetence and inefficiency of our nationalised rail network has also discouraged the use of rail cargoes. So cargoes that should go by sea or rail are consigned by road which is free enterprise and not dominated by militant unions. Therefore road is the only efficient form of transport in this country. But it is not the most economical way to move many of our cargoes, if only our sea and rail transport systems were run sensibly.

I will give just one example of the sorts of rorts that have been going on in our coastal shipping. Until 1983 there was no liquefied petroleum gas carrier on the Australian register and foreign LPG carriers were used to transport LPG to Tasmania. In 1983 we acquired an LPG carrier and the price of LPG in Tasmania immediately rose 75 per cent at a time when the price of LPG dropped everywhere else in Australia. Some rort.

The second worry I have about these manning levels is the discretionary power given to the Secretary to the Department of Transport by this Bill to give approval for ships to operate above the very generous maximum crew level of 21. If this Parliament delegates to a public servant the right to approve additional crew members, two things should happen. Firstly, Parliament should be informed every time its instructions are varied in this manner and informed of the reason for the variation and, secondly, there should be an opportunity for Parliament to disallow this measure. In the Committee stage I will move an amendment to give effect to this.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) talks about improving the productivity of Australian shipping but the only commitment he exacts in return for these very generous capital grants is this very modest reduction in the present grossly excessive crew numbers. This does not begin to tackle the problem of the lack of competiveness of Australian shipping. The Australian maritime unions have had a monopoly on our coastal shipping and they have used this monopoly ruthlessly in order to exact conditions of service far in excess of those provided for the crews of foreign ships, including countries far wealthier than we are such as West Germany, Norway and Japan. Worse still, our crews do virtually no on-board maintenance which results in our repair costs and out of service time of our ships being far greater than those of comparable foreign ships. What we must do is bring crew conditions in our new ships-that is all that is being covered by this Bill-to levels which are in line with those of our competitors. In terms of national income per head, we are right in the middle of the OECD countries-these are, of course, developed countries-and there can be absolutely no justification for our seamen using their monopoly power, demanding conditions that are far in excess of those provided for the seamen of any other OECD country, including those much wealthier than we are.

Let us look at a few of the rorts that have gone on. First there is leave. The figure for leave entitlements for Australia is grossly higher than for any other comparable country. For every crew billet provided in one of our ships, we require 2.3 seamen. This is because our seamen get nearly six months leave a year. This figure of 338 days leave for each year's work for an Australian should be compared with 226 for a Frenchman, 216 for an American, 174 for a West German, 141 for a Norwegian, and 84 for a British rating. For an Australian it is 338. This is outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four times as much as the British.

—Yes, and the costs reflect that. Then, there is travel, the question of air travel to relocate crews. Our seamen always travel first class. No other nation's seamen do. There are our repatriation conditions. If a crew member becomes ill with even a minor complaint in an Asian port, he may be flown to Sydney, first class of course; a replacement crew member may be flown from Australia to the ship, first class of course; and the ship may be delayed for several days at a cost of between $30,000 and $50,000 a day. There is victualling. Australian awards require two hot meals a day with alternative menus and full catering in port, despite the low crew numbers left on board. I am not for a moment advocating unfair or depressing conditions for our seamen, but I think a monopoly union and complacent management have allowed the whole Australian community to be ripped off. I will therefore move in the Committee stage an amendment to provide that the conditions for Australian seamen should be as generous as, but no more generous than, the average of the OCED countries. These countries are not flags of convenience; they are developed countries like Australia, and I can see no justification for our seamen exploiting their monopoly to extract from the Australian community conditions that are far more generous than those of any other OECD country, including many that are far wealthier than we are.

SPEECH.PARA: Then there is the problem of the accommodation and facilities required on board our ships. It has been estimated that to fit a ship out to the standards successfully demanded by our unions adds $1m in capital costs over and above that required for the seamen of any other country-an extra $50,000 a head. It would seem to me outrageous that this proposed new grant from the taxpayers would be used to provide swimming pools for the use of the crew in all Australian ships of more than 8,000 tonnes. In ships of more than 15,000 tonnes all officers must have private bathrooms and so on. I do not see why, in a country in Australia's economic position, we should be providing for our seamen conditions which are not provided for the seamen of any other country.

The other problem is the lack of routine preventive maintenance done by the crews of Australians ships. Our crews do virtually no such work, which is one of the reasons why the repair and overhaul bill for our ships is so high. I can think of no justification for this behaviour and I shall move an amendment in the Committee stage to provide that our seamen should do the same amount of on-board maintenance as is done by the average of the OECD countries. I was delighted to hear from the Minister that:
Australia's seafarers have adopted an enlightened approach, squarely facing up to the issues and supporting measures which will put Australian shipping on course for a better future.

If they really are, that is wonderful news for the community. I have outlined some of the measures which the Bill has not provided which would, to quote the Minister again, `squarely face up to the issues and put Australian shipping on course for a better future'. We have got to bring our crew levels down to international standards; we have got to provide conditions of service which are on a par with those of countries of our economic standing; and we have got to ensure that our crews do adequate on-board maintenance, so our ships do not have high repair bills and long out of service time.

In my experience Australian seamen are as good as any in the world and I think that they deserve good conditions. However, in the past the monopoly power they have been given has enabled them-as all monopolies do-to extract unreasonable conditions from the rest of the community. This has been damaging both to our shipping and to our national economy. The measures that I will move in the Committee stage will help to put these matters right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate of four remarkably unrelated Bills and most of my comments will be addressed to the Social Security Amendment Bill 1987. The other three Bills in this debate are the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill 1987, the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1987 and the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. As Senator Chaney has already indicated, this is a disparate group of Bills. He further indicated that he believed it was purely the Government's fault that such a situation should arise because the Government had seen fit to call an inordinately early election. However, the experience of the past months of sitting so far this year indicates that plenty of time has been wasted in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The very small amount of legislation that we get through is astonishing. This is something which the Parliament as a whole needs to address. I take the opportunity to point out that while it is currently the prerogative of any Prime Minister of any political persuasion to do what this Prime Minister has done and call an early election, it is the policy of the Australian Democrats that we should have fixed term parliaments. Our preference would be a four-year term so that both the Parliament and the people of Australia would know when an election was due and perhaps that would encourage parliaments to get through their business in a more efficient way than they do at present.

As I said earlier, my remarks will be addressed mainly to the Social Security Amendment Bill 1987, which makes a large number of changes to the Social Security Act. In fact, it seems that the changes made in this Bill are so vast that when the Government was getting the Bill together and taking it through the House of Representatives it did not even realise that a provision in Schedule 1 would have required the Department of Social Security to pay married rate benefits to underaged de factos who, in some States, would have been committing a crime under State law. As was pointed out earlier in this debate, the Government has now seen fit to bring forward amendments which appear to be mirrored by subsequent Opposition amendments. I am not sure why the Opposition has done this because the Government amendment was circulated to the Australian Democrats many days ago and that fact seems to have escaped the attention of the Opposition spokespeople on this legislation. The Government has decided to amend that oversight in the original legislation-if that is what it was-and the Australian Democrats support that amendment.

The legislation also includes current reciprocal agreements on social security with the United Kingdom and New Zealand in the Social Security Act. It updates provisions concerning criminal prosecutions and increases the level of penalties for offences against the Act to current levels under other Commonwealth legislation. It extends the secrecy provisions to bind officials who have access to confidential information but who do not otherwise have duties or functions under the Act. It also extends the review and appeal provisions to all decisions made under the provisions of the Act. It further extends eligibility for the supporting parent's benefit to a person whose spouse was held in legal custody on remand. This is to be welcomed. It provides for indexation of the assets test threshold limits-again, a welcome inclusion in the legislation.

Clause 37 of the Bill amends the offence provisions involving fraud. The amendments make it clear that an offence is committed only if a person knowingly or recklessly engaged in certain conduct and extends the crime of fraud to cover the cases of an application under the pen- sion loans scheme and in instances where a person obtains only part of a payment that is not payable. The amendments also enable a monetary penalty of $2,000 and a period of imprisonment of 12 months to be imposed.

The Australian Democrats do not oppose the tightening of fraud provisions in this Bill. We cannot, however, support the most recent attempts by the Government, embodied in the package of mini-Budget Bills to come before us later today, to increase the power of the Department of Social Security to access and divulge information about and collect debts from social security consumers and persons associated with them. In this upcoming legislation, legislation of a very draconian nature, the Government seems to be intent on changing the Department of Social Security from a provider of assistance to the poor to a prosecutor and persecutor of the poor. We will have a great deal more to say about that in the very short time that is being allocated to the mini-Budget legislation, and in particular on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill.

This Bill before us reflects the increasing concern in the community that fraud in the area of social security should not occur and should not cost the taxpayer money. That is a concern which I am sure all taxpayers share. However, it is of some concern to me that there is no balance in what is happening to taxpayers' money, and in general terms in relation to contributions to Government revenue. For instance, there does not seem to be an equal concern about the actions of those people perhaps at the other end of the economic scale. In the corporate sector it is a fact that over the last decade that sector's contribution to Government revenue has gone down from some 20 per cent to around 10 per cent overall, meaning, of course, that the pay as you earn sector has had to pick up a greater part of the burden.

Whilst this legislation, as I said, is supported by the Australian Democrats and we believe that most of its provisions are reasonable and necessary, the Government has now gone too far-obviously under pressure from the forces on the Right, which themselves seem to be crumbling somewhat this morning-with this sort of provision and we are looking at too much victimisation of people receiving payments from the Department of Social Security. Much more balance is needed in this area and will be encouraged by the Australian Democrats at all possible opportunities.

I take this opportunity to point out that it is not only the Australian Democrats who believe that the scales are not balanced when it comes to who is making a contribution and who does not have the right attitude. I would like to place on record the comments of a very notable Australian, Mr Dick Smith, who has expressed the view that people should think about putting something back into this country. In the May edition of the magazine the Australian Way which, of course Australian Airlines has on its aircraft, he is reported as follows:

One of his general disappointments is the apparent selfishness of the wealthy in Australia. Where he asks, are the modern philanthropists? . . . He believes Australians should be delighted to pay tax. To him that's putting something back into a fantastic country, investing in the future.
He believes the wealthy should pay more tax.
If you do well in the United States, as well as paying your taxes you almost have an obligation to put something back into the country. . .
Here the attitude is amazing. All of my business friends-
and I am quoting Dick Smith-
constantly complain about socialism, the taxes and the Government. But when you ask them to put money into this or that they say `The Government should pay for it'.
They will put nothing in, the Government should do it, but the Government should do it without raising their taxes. Until we change that attitude, we have no hope.

I echo those remarks wholeheartedly and suggest that we must have proper balance in the way this country is managed and, in particular, in the way we give support to those who need it. I agree with Dick Smith that there are amongst us those who appear not to be prepared to make their contribution. Whilst this legislation makes adequate and necessary provisions, it is really the forerunner of further draconian legislation which must be resisted, and will be resisted by the Australian Democrats to the extent that it is possible.

In the interests of balance and a correct attitude in one area, in the Committee stage of this debate I will be moving amendments which would broaden the provisions for access to the carer's pension under the Social Security Act. This is a measure which the Parliament should support. I will address a few remarks to it now, especially as the Committee stage of this cognate debate will not provide a great deal of time for my remarks. The spouse carer's pension was introduced in 1983 and was available only to husbands. Wives of age or invalid pensioners were eligible for a wife's pension. In November 1985 an expanded carer's pension replaced the spouse carer's pension. The new pension was available to spouses and a number of specified close relatives but not to aunts, uncles, nieces or nephews.

There was also a discretionary clause which allowed the Secretary to treat any other person as a relative in certain circumstances. In May 1986 this discretion was repealed, which means that various categories of carers are not eligible for a carer's pension but are eligible for the special benefit. There are, however, substantial differences between the payment of a special benefit, which is intended to cover short term and temporary situations, and the payment of a carer's pension, which is intended to cover long term situations.

I will outline in some detail what the differences are. For instance, there is a difference in the rate of payment. Seven dollars a week less is available to special benefit recipients compared with carer's pensions. No rent assistance is available to special benefit recipients for the first six months and then it is a maximum of $10 a week, whereas carer's pensioners receive a maximum of $15 a week from day one, which is a significant difference in many cases. Pensioner concessions such as concessions on rates, telephones, medical expenses and travel, which could easily be worth up to $30 a week, are not available to special benefit recipients.

A stricter income test applies to special benefit recipients once other income exceeds $70 a week-a dollar for dollar reduction compared with a 50c for $1 reduction for carer's pensioners. Carer's pensions are usually reviewed annually, whereas special benefit claims are usually reviewed quarterly. Currently, eligibility for either the carer's pension or special benefit requires that the person cared for must be an age or invalid pensioner, must be severely handicapped-that is, he or she must have a physical or mental disability by reason of which he or she needs constant care and attention-and the claimant must be providing the needed constant care and attention in the home where both the claimant and the person cared for live.

Currently there are two further requirements for eligibility for the carer's pension. The first is that the person cared for must be a relative as defined by a limited definition. Secondly, the care must be required permanently or for an extended period. This has been interpreted to mean either that the illness must be terminal or that care will be needed for at least six months. Whilst I agree that there is a strong rationale for the requirement that the person cared for needs constant care and attention and that the care required must be permanent or for an extended period, my amendments will remove the relative requirement, save the government the cost of institutionalised hospital care and improve the quality of the lives of both the carer and the person being cared for. The relative requirement serves no purpose other than to restrict the numbers who would be eligible for the pension. Indeed, the reason given for repealing the discretion was that payment to persons other than close relatives went beyond the intention of Cabinet when it approved the expanded carer's pension. A carer is significantly disadvantaged where only special benefit is available and those differences that I have outlined make that clear.

It has emerged that two groups are being excluded by the present relative requirement. The first group comprises those persons who conventionally are related to the person cared for in a way not recognised now by the existing legislation, especially aunt, uncle, niece and nephew relationships. The second group comprises those caring for a person with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Those carers may be partners or friends of the person cared for, but are unlikely to satisfy the relative requirement. For over 12 months the New South Wales and Victorian AIDS councils have sought appropriate legislative change on behalf of this group. Two cases have been particularly prominent, those being David Zuber in Victoria and David Wain in New South Wales where currently there is pending an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case in which the carer seeks recognition as a relative under the guardian ground, which is section 33 (3) of the legislation. However, in general, neither the carer nor the person cared for will have the capacity or the will to pursue an appeal through the labyrinthian social security appeals system, particularly because under the existing legislation the chances for success are slim.

My amendments will make the grant of the carer's pension dependent solely on the needs of the person cared for as well as the capacity and the willingness of the carer to meet those needs rather than upon their status as relatives. I believe that a strong case exists for the removal altogether of the relative requirement and paying the carer's pension to any person who satisfies the present constant care and attention requirement on a permanent or an extended period basis. The special benefit caring for category would continue to be used where care is to be provided only temporarily, for example, during a short illness. This is the option favoured by the New South Wales and Victorian AIDS councils. In these days of economic stringency, perhaps one of the strongest arguments in support of my amendments is the cost saving factor. The alternative to home care, the sort of care that this will enable to be provided and encourage in many more cases, and certainly in the case of AIDS victims, is institutional care in a hospital, nursing home or hospice, particularly where home care is being provided primarily by a friend, partner or the relative to whom only the pension need be paid. The net savings really are quite enormous. For example, the AIDS Research Unit, which is part of the National Health and Medical Research Council, recently estimated the average daily cost of hospitalising a person with AIDS at $570 and that excludes the cost of any special treatment or investigations. Some may argue that these cost savings can be achieved by paying special benefit as is currently the case. However, the significant disadvantages that I have already outlined relating to the special benefit are likely to deter potential carers, particularly those with fixed commitments such as mortgages. As the marginal extra cost of paying carer's pension rather than a special benefit in a particular case is only about $350 to perhaps $1,100 per year, depending on the level of rent assistance, even a small deterrent factor leads to a net increase in expenditure; in other words, a modest increase in expenditure by the Department of Social Security is likely to yield substantial savings overall.

A further argument relates to the availability of public health facilities. Apart from the cost factor, institutionalisation of the chronically and terminally ill increases the strain upon already overburdened public hospital, nursing home and hospice facilities. In the case of AIDS, the development of specialised facilities has not kept pace with the spread of the disease and, unfortunately, this situation can be expected to worsen. Government policy is directed, as it should be, at least as the Government expresses it, towards maximisation of home or community care of the chronically and terminally ill. Voluntary care by friends, partners and relatives is a human resource which should be utilised to the fullest extent. Fundamental to this is the provision of adequate income support. It is irrational to create a two-tier system of income support for long term carers. Income support at pension level is a minimum community standard in a permanent or long term situation. It is inappropriate to pay less merely because the defined relationship is not present.

There are, too, the humanitarian arguments, which I believe should have great weight in these situations. In most cases the chronically or terminally ill will prefer home care to institutionalisation, as I am sure all honourable senators would agree, particularly where a friend, partner or relative is providing the care. The Government should recognise and encourage the contribution made by carers to the well-being of the chronically and terminally ill, in addition to the cost savings generated which I have already indicated.

Apart from the deterrence factor of the lower special benefit rate in fringe benefits, lower rates also worsen the living conditions and increase the financial pressure in the home care situation on people who are already under enormous physical and emotional pressure. Even apparently minor matters such as the non-availability of travel concessions can prove significant. For example, David Wain, whose claim for a carer's pension is, as I said, pending with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, cared for a friend with AIDS, from July last year until that friend's death in January 1987. As a pensioner, his friend was entitled to take a free rail trip anywhere in New South Wales. Several months before his death, he wanted to take a final weekend journey, but he could not take this journey without the assistance of his carer. As a special beneficiary, David Wain was not entitled to a free journey and therefore they were unable to take the trip. That is just a small human story which I think should bear some weight in the argument.

Perhaps there will be some opposition to my proposal on the basis that it might be considered that this measure would open the flood gates resulting in a huge number of claims from people who would then be eligible for the carer's pension, resulting in a cost blowout. I do not believe that this is a reasonable fear. The existing constant care and attention requirement, which my amendment would leave in place, is a stringent and effective filter. Clearly, only full time carers resident in the same home as the person cared for should be eligible. All those who satisfy the constant care and attention requirement are already eligible for the special benefit. Statistics on the payment of the special benefit, therefore, give a good indication of the numbers likely to be eligible. The Department's own figures indicate that, as at 13 February this year, only 728 persons in Australia received special benefit in the `caring for' category. Of course, not all those people would be eligible for the carer's pension due to the additional requirement that the care be required permanently or for an extended period. In fact, the marginal cost of paying the carer's pension to every special beneficiary would probably be less than $500,000 annually-a small sum when the overall savings represented by the home care are taken into account.

To the extent that a more adequate level of income support leads to an increase in the number of carers, the increased social security expenditure would be more than offset by the savings in other areas, particularly in the areas of health and community services. Indeed, this is one of the aims of the initiative which I am attempting to take at the moment. The only dramatic increase which might be expected would be in AIDS related cases. However, the following factors make the payment of the carer's pension particularly appropriate in these cases. Once the disease has progressed to the stage where constant care and attention is required, hospital or hospice care will almost always be necessary unless home care can be arranged. The development of facilities, as I have said, for the treatment and accommodation of people with AIDS is likely to continue to lag behind the need, particularly if the numbers dramatically increase. People with AIDS are less likely to have potential carers in the defined relative category, and the resources of the volunteer networks of part time carers which have been established until now, such as the community support network, are stretched to the limit and there is an urgent and immediate need to encourage potential full time carers.

The Bill before us provides an opportunity for us to take this initiative, and I commend my amendment to the Senate. If it does not attract sufficient support on the humanitarian grounds that I have outlined-and I believe it should-certainly I urge honourable senators to look at the economic benefits of such a proposal and give them serious consideration. As I have already suggested, this legislation makes very appropriate changes, mainly of an administrative kind, and therefore it will be supported by the Australian Democrats, as indeed the other Bills in this disparate package will be supported.

It was interesting to hear Senator Hamer, in his remarks on the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill, criticise certain provisions that apply for Australian seamen. I refer in particular to those comments that seemed to be having a bit of a swipe at what he called a monopoly union in that area. Senator Hamer was very critical of the fact that Australian seamen in relocation have first class travel. I am not sure that access to first class travel has a lot to do with a monopoly union. If that is the case, I do not know to which union members of this place belong so that they also are entitled to first class travel to and from their place of work-and, of course, that is an entitlement for parliamentarians. I just wonder whether I can assume now that Senator Hamer, who believes that Australian seamen should not have such access, will join me in the economy cabin as I travel to and from Canberra. I have not seen him there to date. He is also critical of swimming pools and private bathrooms for Australian seamen. Having had an opportunity to look at the new Parliament House just last week, I noticed that these facilities too will be provided for members of this place and the other place. I do not see why working people such as Australian seamen should not have such access if those facilities are to be available to parliamentarians. I did note, however, that what will not be available to parliamentarians in their new place of work is a child minding facility, which I believe is something we should have. I do not know whether Australian seamen have those facilities; if they do not, I believe that they should have them. I commend the Social Security Amendment Bill, particularly those amendments that I have spent some time outlining to the Senate. I suggest that this would be an excellent time for the Parliament to take this step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that I am one of six speakers still to go and we have only a little more than half an hour left in this debate, I will try to be more considerate to those following me. I refer to the Ministers of State Amendment Bill. Ministers of State, of course, come under a separate requirement and the proposed amendments will increase the amount stipulated in the Bill by omitting $660,000 and substituting $680,000. The whole question of remuneration of Ministers and non-Ministers requires a lot of attention, and I believe that the present system is one of the worst possible conglomerations that one could imagine. It is in much the same category as the area we recently fell into relating to the provision of computer services. It would not work anywhere else in the whole community, but we inflict it on ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult for me to take the Minister of State (Senator Tate) to task because he has been in the job only a short while, but I can certainly take to task some of his predecessors. We are now in the position where part of our salary is taxed and part is not taxed in the initial period, where we have to record certain things but we do not have to record others and where a certain amount of our remuneration is subject to our own contributory superannuation scheme and part is not. I believe that there is nowhere else in business or industry where such a scheme would be allowed to remain. It would be very helpful if the Government considered this issue. I can only say that, should members and senators be unfortunate enough to have me as Minister responsible for this area at any time, I can guarantee that changes of a very considerable nature will be made. It should be borne in mind, though, that these matters are really more or less in the hands of the Special Minister of State or the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In looking back over the last year or two, we of course would concede that the Treasurer and the former Special Minister of State, Mr Young, were probably too busy doing other things to worry about looking after such fundamental matters as those which we are considering now.

On the other hand, the attitude of some people might be that it is a matter of whether there are profits to be made by offsetting, say, customs payments or anything else. If a certain amount can be saved on customs duty that amount may not be needed in the form of an allowance, or perhaps an amount may be provided for a travel allowance or living away from home allowance, although a person does not live away from home. Perhaps one might not put in a tax return for a couple of years, as has been alleged in some cases. Perhaps the Ministers themselves are looking after this matter in their own way. However, the fact that the documents that accompany the Bill show that Ministers magnanimously withheld their 11.7 per cent rise is hardly the point. I believe that we must make sure that the Ministers are worth a rise, that they are doing their jobs, that they are doing them with impartiality and that their standards are sufficient to set an example for others. I have great doubts about this in relation to the members I have mentioned. I believe that, for example, even the private pursuits in Parliament House of Mr John Brown really do not do him much credit and certainly do not indicate that an increase in salary is deserved. However, hopefully by 11 July the electors of Australia will have worked this out also and will make their own arrangements. (Quorum formed) The Opposition does not oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a package of Bills as part of the program that the Government wants us to get through before the election. One of those Bills to which I want to address myself is the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill 1987. This piece of legislation has been a long time in the making. I think a lot of the original discussions go back to when the Hon. Ralph Hunt was the Minister for Transport. He tried to get some semblance of order and cost control into our shipping industry. Obviously some costs, such as capital costs which represent about 50 per cent, are quite fixed and almost beyond our capacity to alter. Then we have fuel costs which add up to about 19 per cent, crewing costs at about 14 per cent and other incidentals, including port charges, at about 20 per cent. It is to these areas, beyond the original 50 per cent capital cost, to which we have to look to make the savings that are so necessary. It seems ironic that a trading nation such as Australia has not paid more attention to its shipping costs to this point in time. We have seen many industries almost go out of business-indeed, some have gone out of business-in times past because of the massive costs associated with shipping both on and off the wharf and in relation to the ships themselves. This Bill tries to address the costs relating directly to the ships.

SPEECH.PARA: It pays attention to two particular aspects: Firstly, the encouragement for more fuel efficiency, which is one of those areas in which we can make savings, and, secondly, the crewing costs. I understand that overseas countries have only 1.5 crews per ship whereas Australia has 2.25. Is it any wonder that we will see a further demise in putting Australian products going overseas in Australian bottoms. It has to be recognised that it also creates a problem with our current account deficit. Being the trading nation that we are, we are sending literally hundreds, thousands or millions of tonnes of products overseas every year-whether it be manufactured product in containers or bulk wheat, sugar or coal. When most of that is sent in overseas bottoms that means that the freight component is being paid overseas and that is showing up in our adverse current account deficit. It is essential that we as a nation try to take control of that situation and make our shipping industry more efficient so that we can make better use of our ships for those reasons.

One purpose of this Bill is, as I said, to encourage greater fuel efficiency. It is to be done by way of grants, as a percentage of the purchase price of new ships and certain secondhand ships. Another purpose is to get the crewing level in line with that of our competitors in overseas shipping and coastal shipping. We are an island nation and our coastal shipping is almost being put out of business because of the costs. Another thing which really has nothing to do with this Bill is that both the previous Liberal and National Party Government and this Government insisted that our shipping company, Australian National Line, pay its way, yet we find that in many instances it is competing against the government-owned railways whose charges are set not necessarily on a cost basis but according to what they think they can do to undermine anybody else, including the truckies and the shipping business. We find that the taxpayers are picking up the tab for the losses on the railway system of Australia while the Federal Government is insisting that its shipping company meet its own cost obligations and indeed pay off some of the capital charges which it has incurred in times past.

As I have said, this piece of legislation is part of the negotiations that have been going on for a long time. One must acknowledge at this point that the Seamen's Union of Australia has also shown some sense of responsibility in recognising that it has to play its part if its members are to maintain their jobs and if we are not to see more and more of our products transported by overseas ships. I will support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 which is included in a package of legislation under the guillotine. It is an important piece of legislation which requires a great deal more debate and attention than is possible, lumped together as it is with amendments to the Social Security Act and the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill and the Ministers of State Amendment Bill. All of this legislation has a debating time of two hours.

SPEECH.PARA: This defence legislation has a number of important features. I think the most important feature deals with the call-out of the Reserve forces and the provision for long term enlistments for Australian soldiers, sailors and airmen. The present provision enables the reserves to be called out in a time of war or a declared defence emergency, but this Bill enables them to be called out when there is a low level threat. The Bill certainly makes provision for that measure to be scrutinised by the Parliament, and the Opposition supports this. Although the Bill enables the Reserve forces to be called out in response to a low level threat, it must be an external threat, not simply an internal threat and not, say, to aid a civil power.

The Opposition certainly believes that this extension of the Reserve forces' obligations is fully justified, and it is well accepted by the Reserve forces. It will mean that the responsibilities of the defence forces will be further extended. Not only will that be good for their morale but it will also provide a greater opportunity for Australia's defence forces to respond to threats of that kind.

The Opposition has been very concerned about the morale of Reserve forces under the present Government. Under this Government for a considerable period they lost their tax exemption for their pay. Although the Government realised that it had made a bad mistake and restored that provision, it certainly weakened the strength of the Reserve forces. The Government has seriously contributed to the morale of the Reserve forces. As I have said, this legislation may help to improve morale and may help to encourage greater enlistment in the Reserve forces. The Opposition would certainly support any move in that direction, although I simply point out that the record and attitude of the Hawke Government in relation to our Reserve forces have been dismal and negative. Much more needs to be done to encourage not only those people who are in the Reserve forces but also those who may be attracted to them. It is important that they be given every encouragement. As I said, this Government has taken a quite different approach to them during the time it has been in office.

The provision for long term enlistment for our service personnel is also important, particularly when one considers the extent of dissatisfaction of our full time personnel. They have certainly not been encouraged as they should. There has been a significant increase in the number of resignations by members of the defence force, particularly amongst officers. For instance, in January of this year over 1,000 resigned compared with only 444 in December. The resignation rate of officers is also unacceptably high.

The housing of our servicemen is another problem which the Government has at long last sought to address but, again, so far it has done very little to rectify that problem. So the provision giving them the opportunity of enlisting for a period up to retiring age is a step forward and the Opposition supports it. The old arrangements, whereby they had to enlist for a specific period and then re-engage, did not give service personnel the career opportunity to which they were entitled.

Other aspects of the legislation are of a relatively minor character and I do not propose to deal with them in this short debate. Again I register the Opposition's protest that such an important matter as the responsibilities, obligations and terms of engagement of Australian service personnel-both full time members of the defence force and our reservists-which raises major questions of defence policy, is unable to be debated properly in this chamber because of the Government's application of the guillotine so that it can rush through a whole lot of legislation this week in order to proceed to an early election. With those comments, the Opposition supports this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is, as has been noted by all speakers, a very short debate on a number of important topics. We have just heard a speech by Senator Durack. I have always felt that Senator Durack could make a tied footy final sound like a day in the public library. We have heard his tones over and over again in the Senate this year. I think that is probably one of the reasons why we are so far behind in our business. It would be nice if we did have a shorter speaking time in the Senate, perhaps 15 minutes, and a greater sense of responsibility on the part of speakers. The reason that we have such a backlog is that we have had so many matters of public importance and so much filibustering during the year.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall confine my brief remarks to the Ships (Capital Grants) Bill 1987. I am the transport spokesman for the Australian Democrats, and I have had an interest in and knowledge of the shipping industry over the years. This Government Bill is a step in the right direction in restoring Australia's position as a viable shipping nation. At one time in Australia ships carried most of the trade, as indeed they should have done, between our cities, the biggest of which are almost universally on the coast. It makes good sense for ships to carry cargo. After all, with ships one does not have to repair road beds or rail tracks, one is away from other modes of traffic, and certainly ships are an energy efficient way of carrying cargo including large bulk items. But over the years because of union problems, inherent in port development, perhaps pressure on the city ports by real estate interests, there has been a decline in shipping and an increase in the use of road and rail. I believe that this is to the detriment of the general community because the roads get clogged with trucking traffic and rail is a far more costly operation in the use of public money than is shipping. Therefore, anything that will encourage and enhance the use of ships in Australia is well worth supporting.

This legislation is supported by the Australian Democrats. Senator Hamer came to me earlier with a number of amendments which he felt would make the situation better for shipping in Australia. I read the amendments and discussed them with Senator Hamer. I was also visited by a group called the Australian National Maritime Association which represents the shipowners. I was surprised to find that the shipowners did not support Senator Hamer's amendments. I have always felt that the Liberal Party was in tune with big business interests, but in this instance the shipowners, who represent big business, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Australian National Line among them, said that they did not want Senator Hamer's amendments because they felt that Australia's shipping industry at the moment was heading in the right direction. If the Hamer amendments were to pass, they felt that it would lead to a breaking down in the proposals which have now been made and the steps towards greater rationality in the shipping industry.

The unions, which have been blamed for much that has been wrong in the shipping industry in the past, perhaps rightly so in some respects, obviously have seen the writing on the wall and are trying their best to make shipping viable in this country. Certainly the shipowners are trying to make shipping viable. This Bill is a step in that direction. The Opposition's amendments will slow down this process, perhaps even throw a monkey wrench into it, and thus make shipping less viable. For this reason the Australian Democrats supports the Government Bill and will be opposing any Opposition amendments. This concludes my remarks. I would like to have studied the other Bills, as I am sure would other members of my Party, but in this brief debate we feel that we have been curtailed in this operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)
