The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two amendments, which have been circulated, to move on behalf of the Government. They relate to the treatment of a person under the age of consent as a de facto spouse. I understand that the amendments have been approved in principle by the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats, and in fact that an Opposition amendment is circulating that is in identical terms to the Government's amendments. I seek leave to move the two amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 15, Part 1 of Schedule 1, omit the amendment of the definition of `de facto spouse' in subsection 6 (1).
(2) Page 16, Part 1 of Schedule, 1, after the amendment of the definition of `Reserve Forces' in subsection 6 (1), insert the following amendment:
``Section 6:
Add at the end the following subsections:
`(10) Where:
(a) a person who is living with another person of the opposite sex as the spouse of that other person on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married to that other person; and
(b) either of those persons is under the age of consent applicable in the State or Territory in which those persons are living:
neither of those persons shall be treated as a married person for the purposes of this Act.

`(11) The rate of a pension, benefit or allowance under this Act payable to a person to whom subsection (10) applies shall not exceed the rate at which it would be payable to the person if the person were married to the other person.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my second reading stage speech on the Social Security Amendment Bill I explained to the Senate how the Government had put forward this Bill in its original form through the House of Representatives. The Government did not attempt to amend that Bill in any way in that House. Far from its being a government amendment, it is indeed the amendment that the Opposition demanded before the Bill came to the Senate. The Senate assured the Minister that there was no way that the Government would get that amendment through this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what we are trying to amend. Let us be very clear on this: The Government put through the House of Representatives an amendment tucked away in a Schedule-it was not mentioned in the Minister's speech or in the substantive legislation-that allowed de facto married rate pension to be paid to underage children. As I said during the debate, it would allow a 14-year-old or younger child, a little girl, who had a crush on a fellow of 14, 15 or 16 and had been getting a bit of a hard time at home for not doing her homework, to say to her parent: `I am off. I am going to live with Joe Blow down the street'. The parent could not say to her `You could not survive. Where will you get money?' because her answer would be: `This Government will pay us a married rate of pension if we are both unemployed because we are living together in a de facto relationship'. This is what the Government put through the House of Representatives. It would enable that little girl to undermine her parent's authority by saying: `We have not got to rely on you. We will get a married rate of pension from the Government'. If underage children want to get married they have to get special permission. Their parents have to give permission as well as a judge. There is quite a rigmarole to go through before that marriage can take place. This Government is not only allowing but, through the alteration of legislation, also encouraging young children to go off and live in a de facto--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true, Senator; that is a deliberate untruth.

—It is part of the amending Bill that this Government pushed through the House of Representatives. It is quite true. The Government is indeed allowing, and by legislation encouraging, young children to go off, live together in a de facto relationship and, in most States, commit the crime of carnal knowledge. I am sure that Senator Button is well aware of that. These children are living together in de facto relationships and this Government is allowing them to be paid a married rate of benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier in the debate, we will not allow that to occur. Yet that is what the Government pushed through the House of Representatives. We must not let the Government hide behind the fact that it now wants to amend the Bill, because that does not give the true position. Had the Government been sincere it would have passed that amendment in the House of Representatives, but it did not do so. It was not until public pressure was such that it was forced to accept the amendment that the Opposition had put forward--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not so.
—Senator Coates says `no'. Can he tell me why this amendment was not brought forward in the House of Representatives?
—I will tell you in a moment, if you give me the opportunity.

—He will tell us in a moment! That will be most interesting. I will be most interested to know why the Government allowed a provision to go through the House of Representatives which makes it possible-it was not possible before-for young people to go off, live together and get a married rate of benefit. Individual cases where young couples had babies have gone before an appeals tribunal. Those were individual cases, each looked at individually and on merit. This provision, which the Government pushed through in the House of Representatives, gives us open slather; it redefines `de facto spouse'. Senator Button knows that I am right. This redefinition takes away any age limit and allows these little children to pretend that they are nice and grown up, and thus it undermines the family authority.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has no standards; its Ministers have no standards. We have the Mick Youngs and the Keatings. Mr Keating claims that he lives in Sydney, yet he sends his kids to school in Canberra and, indeed, he is on the electoral roll in Canberra. Yet, every day he lives in Canberra he is paid his travel allowance. Those are the sorts of standards we have in this Government. We have a Treasurer who refuses to fill in his tax form and receives a special letter from the Commissioner of Taxation pleading with him not only to fill in this year's tax form but also to complete last year's. Those are the sorts of standards that this Government has. We have John Brown, another Minister, refusing to abide by the small print--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Should not Senator Walters speak to the amendments for a change, and never mind this garbage that she is throwing at us? She should stick to the amendments.
—There is no point of order, but perhaps Senator Walters should relate her remarks to the amendments.

—Senator McIntosh says that we should not discuss the standards of Ministers on his side of politics. I know that he is uncomfortable about it; by gee, if they were my Ministers I would be more than uncomfortable about it, I assure him. I would not want brought up the fact that the Minister does not read the small print of his entitlements. That was the excuse that Mr John Brown used for diddling the taxpayers and getting his children free extra travel. I would not like it brought up that our Treasurer refused to fill in his tax form. I would not like it brought up--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Can you tell me how this relates to the amendments?
—It concerns standards-that is how it relates.
—Senator Walters, will you direct your remarks to the amendments, please.

—I am, Mr Temporary Chairman, because I am talking about standards. I am talking about the amendment of the term `de facto'. I am talking about Schedule 1. I am talking about the standards of this Government and of its Ministers. No wonder the Government lowers the standards for the rest of the country when its Ministers behave in this way. Mick Young brings in undeclared goods on behalf of his wife--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Senator Walters obviously does not want to hear a response from anyone on the Government side to the allegations that she made about the need for this amendment and I ask you, particularly in view of that, to ask her to confine her remarks to the amendment, or at least to the Bill, rather than ranging over a broad debate on the conduct of Government Ministers. She challenged me to respond to her on this amendment; I would like the opportunity to do so before the time allotted expires.
—Senator Walters, I have asked you to restrict your remarks to the amendment.

—I believe I am doing that. I have made my point that this Government has no standards. I enforce that by underlining once again that the Opposition has put forward an amendment which the Government has been forced to accept. Had the Government been sincere in wanting the amendment, it would have introduced it in the House of Representatives and would not have left it to this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am relieved that Senator Walters has finally given us the chance to deal with this matter in the last few minutes of this debate. She knows that this matter arose at the very last minute during the Committee stage of the Bill in the House of Representatives. At that point Mr Howe, the Minister for Social Security, said that the matter raised during that debate would be examined. This amendment is a result of that examination. Senator Walters tries to make out that the Government pushed this provision through the House of Representatives against some great public pressure at the time. This matter was raised at the last minute and the Minister said at that time-not even the next day-that he would have it examined. The Government announced its decision about that the next day. Therefore it is a lot of nonsense about public pressure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters also should acknowledge that we are talking about the Government's genuine attempt to clarify the existing law. Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions raised doubts about the intent of the Social Security Act. We are talking about the law as it has been administered under Labor and conservative governments for years. This situation arises because of differences in ages of consent in different States. Senator Walters can raise all sorts of emotional points about people being 14 years old and so on, but the fact is that we are talking about 16- and 17-year-olds who are over the age of eligibility for the unemployment benefit but, in some States, are under the age of consent. The point about encouraging illegality is totally false as well. It is the States' responsibility to administer these laws. The Government has attempted to clarify the existing law to ensure that people are not paid more than they would be if they were treated as single people. It was possible that if they were not treated as if they were married, two people both eligible for benefits would receive single rate benefits which could take them over the married rate and put them in a better position than people who were married. This was a genuine attempt to try to clarify this law. Of course, there was argument about the way that definition should have been worded. This is the alternative proposition put by the Government, after discussion amongst all those involved and interested in this matter. Senator Walters may wish to raise a whole lot of emotional arguments about the Government's intentions but she ought to acknowledge that the facts of the case are that this legislation is intended to clarify the law. If she is concerned about people in that situation she ought to talk to State governments about ensuring that the proper rules are applied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now debating the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill and other Bills. Having been gagged by the Government on the Social Security Amendment Bill we are now being forced to debate another package of Bills that we cannot possibly debate in the time given us. The amendments before us today are mainly to implement the decisions of the May mini-Budget. The May mini-Budget should have been an unnecessary exercise if the Government had not squandered money, had contained its spending and had been responsible in its spending rather than just trying to buy votes. We would not have found ourselves in this position. We would not have had to have a mini-Budget or this legislation which is before us today. We all know that the best Treasurer in the whole wide world, the one who has downgraded our credit rating for the first time in Australia's history, has been hiding behind the fact that the world has not been paying us the prices he wants for our commodities.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that when Mr Cain at the Premiers Conference accused the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of behaving like the builders labourers he hid behind the fact that he was breaking his promises to the States because the world had broken its promises to pay us what he thinks we should get for our commodities. This excuse however has been blown wide open by Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh has his faults-who knows this better than the Senate?-but on this occasion he was honest enough to explain that the Government had squandered $4 billion through a series of high Budget deficits. Senator Walsh at a Labor conference in Hobart, when addressing the delegates, said:

I know some people believe, that budget deficits don't matter. They do matter in the degree to which they lock in future expenditure. If we had a public debt interest payment, the same level of outlays as it was in 1982-
and here I interpose that that was the last year of the Fraser Government-

we would in this financial year have about $4 billion extra to either cut taxes, increase welfare spending or whatever else you wanted to do with it. But because we have run a sequence of high budget deficits, we are lumbered with a crippling public debt interest payment which restricts the ability of this Government and Governments for the foreseeable future, to deliver the programs they would like to deliver . . .

Senator Walsh said that the Government would have saved $4 billion if it had not run a series of high Budget deficits. That $4 billion is a very familiar figure because the May mini-Budget was meant to cut $4 billion off government spending. So, as Senator Walsh said, if the Government had not been so free with its spending we would not have needed this May mini-Budget.

Let us look at the May mini-Budget because it is part of the debate before us at the moment. Like any bankrupt business, the Government is having an auction sale of its assets-$1 billion of assets is up for grabs. The Williamstown Naval Dockyard is up for sale-who will buy it? All the airports around Tasmania are for sale-who will buy them? Part of the Tokyo Embassy and the Paris ambassador's residence are up for sale. But that $1 billion is not a cut in government spending. It is an auction sale-a one-off. It will not do anything next year for our deficit. So that is a quarter of the $4 billion that was not a spending cut. Then we had a whole array of new taxes-an additional half billion dollars of taxes. We have added sales tax, customs duty, fuel rebate schemes-the whole lot comes to another half billion dollars. Those are hardly cuts; they are just added costs to the people. That is more money coming in to the Government. That will only increase inflation. Telecom Australia has already put up its prices and so has Australia Post-hardly cuts in government expenditure. So now we are down to just over $2 1/2 billion of supposed cuts. But $1 billion of those have been taken from the States. Are these hard Commonwealth decisions? No, the hard decisions were given to the States to make. The Federal Government has said: `You raise your own taxes if you want part of that back'. That will help inflation, will it not? The States will have to raise the money. But no hard decisions come from this Government. So we are now left with just a little over $1.5 billion out of the supposed $4 billion of cuts. There has not been a cut by the Federal Government to date. As has been said, when it comes to cutting Federal expenditure it is done with a rather rubbery axe.

Apart from about half a billion dollars of cuts in defence and road construction, the section of the community that will bear the cost of the cuts will be students, the poor, and families. We have before us today the legislation which makes those cuts which will affect those people. Most of the cuts will occur after August, the normal Budget time. So why did the Government need the May mini-Budget? Senator Walsh has said that the Government needed it because of its overspending. However, it also needed the May mini-Budget because it wanted to go to an election. Very few of the cuts will occur before the August Budget. Most of them will occur after October.

Mr Hawke has gone to the people saying that he wants a mandate to finish the job. Let us consider what he has done to families and whether we believe he ought to be given a mandate to finish them off. Already he has done so much to families that there is no likelihood in the world of the Australian people giving him such a mandate. Let us consider what has happened to the disposable income of families under the Hawke Government. Under the Fraser Government there was a steady increase in the disposable income from $297.90 a week in 1975 to $316.80 a week in the last financial year of that Government. Since then, the disposable income of a family on average weekly earnings has almost dropped back to its 1978 level. It has gone from $316.80 a week in 1983, when we left government, to $302.92. That is a considerable drop in the disposable income of a family. That is what the Government has done to families in that area.

Let us consider the family allowance, which the legislation before us is specifically concerned about. The Fraser Government increased the family allowance for a family with two children from $4.30 a month, which it was in 1975 when we came to office, to $32.55 a month-an increase of 657 per cent or, to put it another way, an 89 per cent increase for each year we were in government. What has this Government done? It has not only not increased the family allowance at all, but also taken it away from families with dependent children aged 16 years and over. It has treated the family allowance as welfare and now is means testing it for families with combined incomes of over $50,000. The Government says: `That is quite all right as those families will be getting tax cuts in July, and that will even it up'. But let me tell honourable senators and the people out there that a single person or a family without children on $50,000 a year will get the cuts in July. They will not have anything taken from them. But families with children will have their family allowance taken from them.

This Government treats children as a luxury. It says that children are a luxury and that any assistance given to families with children has to be means tested. Children are not a luxury. Family allowance is paid in recognition of the fact that it costs a family with children, of whatever income, more to live than a family on the same income without children. The Government commissioned a report by Bettina Cass and her chief recommendation to the Government was that the Government should not means test the family allowance. She states under the heading `Horizontal Equity: A Fair Share for all Families':
This principle recognises that at any level of family income, people with children incur greater costs and have greater needs than do people without children at the same level of income.

Bettina Cass said how unjust it would be to means test the family allowance. This is a report that this Government commissioned. When it came up with a recommendation the Government did not like, the Government ignored it, continuing to maintain that children are a luxury in this country, which the taxpayers are not willing to support.

Let us consider further what Bettina Cass says. She says that 38 per cent of families which receive the family allowance have adjusted incomes below $16,000 a year, while about 75 per cent have adjusted incomes below $28,000 and only 7 per cent have adjusted incomes above $40,000. Bettina Cass maintains that the principle of horizontal equity would surely prevent any government from means testing the family allowance.

The Government keeps saying that its July tax cuts will offset this measure for these families but it does not tell us that anyone receiving under $19,500 a year will not be getting any tax cuts in July. That is the sleight of hand the Government is refusing to spell out. Hidden in the small print at the back of the May mini-Budget-not in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-we find that there will be a phasing out of the B class widow's pension. B class widow's pension recipients are women over 45 years old, mainly women over 50 years old, who have been at home looking after their families for, perhaps, the last 20 or 25 years and have suddenly lost their husbands-their husbands have died. In the past these widows were entitled to a B class widow's pension. But this Government says that these widows must go out and work, that these women over 50 years of age, who have not worked since they were young, who have been out of the work force looking after their families, are suddenly going to have to retrain. The Government is providing $2m for retraining. These widows are going to be forced out into the work force. What sort of Government is that? What sort of compassion does that show? It shows none at all. Those women are being forced on to unemployment benefits because--

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that you read the May statement. What you are saying is wrong.
—The Minister had better be careful, because Senator Ryan said that that was wrong.
—You are either a fool or a liar.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not want that remark withdrawn, because the Minister will have to apologise to me. When I spoke to Senator Ryan in this chamber after her interjection on Senator Chaney she told me that I was wrong. I said: `Get it straight. I have spent my whole 12 years in this Parliament on the social welfare committees. I know what a B class widow is'. Senator Ryan replied: `It won't affect women over 50'. I said: `Fine, you go back and check with your Department'. She checked with her Department and she had the decency to come to me and say: `I am sorry, you are right. There is a phase in period only, but after that phase in period, no 50-year-old woman--
—That is not what you said in the beginning.

—I said that it involved a phase out of the B class widow's pension. That is what I said and Senator Walsh cannot hide behind that. Yes, women who are now 50 years old will get the pension, but only during the phasing out period. After it is phased out, 50-year-old women will be sent out into the work force to hunt for jobs. Ye gods, what does the Government expect them to do? Does it expect them to go and look after some other family? Looking after a family is all they have been doing for the past 25 years. The Government tells them to get out into the work force. For the information of Senator Walsh, 50-year-old women cannot retrain for the high-tech industries or any industries. They have been out of the work force for the past 25 years and they do not have the necessary skills. It is all very well for Senator Walsh as a man and for other men in Australia who have been able to upgrade their skills during the past 25 years of their work experience, but they have no idea what it is like for these women. It is not possible for the 50-year-old woman who becomes a widow to be retrained. Under this Government such women have been completely dumped and deserted. They have been told to retrain themselves at the age of 50 and over to get back into the work force. They will suffer the indignity of having to visit a Commonwealth Employment Service office every week to try to get a job for the next 10 or 15 years that they will be in that situation.
—And they will be competing with out of work young girls.

—They will be competing in the work force with out of work young men and girls, for a job that they cannot possibly get. It is a disgrace. The Government does not care one iota about women and it cares even less about the traditional mother who has brought up a family. It is interested only in the feminists who are in the work force and who have no kids because, after all, they are a luxury. The Government could not care less about the traditional family, or the family at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the other areas where the family has been viciously hit. There is no doubt that the family has been the major target of this Government in relation to health care costs, but I will leave that to the shadow Minister who will deal with that matter. Because of this Government's ideology, it will get stuck into the families in relation to health care costs. Statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics demonstrate that over 46 per cent of families, that is, married couples with dependent children, who receive only $126 per week-and Senator Walsh would not understand this-are prepared to take out private health insurance, because they are not prepared to leave the priority of family health in the hands of this Government. The Hawke Government is responsible for more people than ever living below the poverty line. It is responsible for more married women being forced into the work force because of the necessity for two incomes to support their families. It has ruled over the highest level of company and personal bankruptcies in the history of the nation-and the Prime Minister asks for a mandate to finish the job; a mandate to make us all bankrupt, to turn Australia into a banana republic. The Treasurer has already downgraded our credit rating, so has he not almost finished the job? He has presided also over the highest level of personal taxation that Australia has ever seen. As I indicated, the disposable income of families has never been lower. The Government's contempt and lack of compassion for the people of Australia have never before been experienced in this country. We all remember the list of broken promises that will come home to roost. On April Fools Day, before the announcement of the election, the Prime Minister took Australians for April fools and said that there would be no early election, and he gave a commitment to that effect. A month later he chose to announce an election. We all remember well the commitment he made when he said: `Let me make it clear so that even our opponents can understand it: There will be no capital gains tax'. Now we have a capital gains tax, and this Government has broken 20 other promises. I now turn to what the Prime Minister's own electorate thinks about him and what it believes this Government is all about, the compassion that it believes the Government is likely to show to the people of Australia. Several people were interviewed in Mr Hawke's own electorate and one person said:
I draw your attention to the fact that this Government is not a Labor Government at all but is a Government which supports the business circle.
That is, big business. Another constituent said:
The people in areas such as this one, and it's the Prime Minister's own electorate, are the ones that are bearing the brunt.
That is, the brunt of this Government. Another said:
This so-called Labor Government, under the leadership of your local member, Bob Hawke, is annihilating any concept of income support from the Government.
Another constituent stated:
As the Prime Minister, we felt that he's representing a government that's not adopting policies that are in the interests of the people . . .
Another said:
I think it's up to us to use our vote to teach Hawke a lesson.

It will not be only Mr Hawke's own electorate that teaches him a lesson, but all the families of Australia, who would like and expect to be able to believe the word of a Prime Minister. They would like, and they should be able to expect, to have a certain standard from the Ministers of the Crown. They would like, and they have every reason to expect, the government of the day to look after the average person and the average family in Australia, not just themselves. They expect the Treasurer to abide by the law and not to avoid sending in his tax returns. The people of Australia expect the Ministers of the Government to abide by the laws that they set up. They should not avoid customs duties, as Mick Young did. They should declare the goods they bring into Australia. People also expect Ministers not to divulge security secrets of this country, as Mick Young has done, and not to get, as the Treasurer has got, travel allowance which is not due to them. Ministers should not, as the Treasurer has done, say that they live in Sydney while being enrolled in Canberra for voting purposes and while sending their children to Canberra schools-and claiming every day that they are here a travelling allowance to which they are not entitled. That is the least that the Australian people can and should expect from the Government-and the Government has dumped them on every one of those expectations or issues. When the Prime Minister announced this election he said that he is asking for a mandate to finish the job. There is no way that the people of Australia will give this Government a mandate to finish them off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I am debating the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1987. That Bill gives effect to the measures in the May economic statement which affect the social security and veterans' affairs portfolios. In the May economic statement the Government was able to reduce the Forward Estimates of outlays next financial year by some $4,000m. The objective of that exercise was to reduce government spending in future financial years to cut the Budget deficit and, as a result, reduce pressures on interest rates. The measures in the Bill before the Senate at the moment which affect the social security and veterans' affairs areas will contribute some $360m of those total savings in the next financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes in the May economic statement reflect the Government's intention to restructure unemployment and education allowances for young Australians. From 1 January next unemployment benefits for 16- and 17-year-olds will be replaced by a job search allowance. That new allowance will be paid at the rate of $50 per week unless a person's family income is relatively high. New unemployment benefit applicants aged 16 or 17 years will also have to wait 13 weeks instead of six weeks as is the case under the current system. By introducing these measures the Government is indicating that it wants to discourage young Australians from leaving school early without any training. There are basically two reasons for that. If Australia is to become a successful exporting power in the world it must have a well trained and well educated work force. The unfortunate reality is that teenagers leaving school without jobs or training are effectively heading for a dead end. That is the second reason why this Government has introduced those particular measures.

The Government is giving school leavers a clear message: Find work or undertake training. The new job search allowance will not harm jobless young people from low income families. I will repeat that: The new job search allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds will not penalise young Australians coming from low income families. Unemployed teenagers will still be able to receive up to $50 a week, subject to a parental income test. This amount is made up of a minimum of $25 a week job search allowance plus another $25 a week for applicants from low income families. For those young people unable to live at home the Government will increase the young homeless allowance, which it introduced in last year's Budget, to $76 a week. These are some of the major changes which have been made in the May economic statement. The Government reforms will eliminate the financial incentives for young people to leave education and shift on to Australia's social welfare system.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce refers again to continuing industrial disruption in the Victorian metal trades industry directly attributable to the urgings of the Minister's Victorian Senate ticket colleague, John Halfpenny. Is the Minister aware that, despite agreement by union leaders before Mr Deputy President Keogh in Melbourne yesterday to try to bring this disruption to an end, workers at the Australian National Industries Ltd subsidiary, ANI National Forge, today voted to continue the strike which has prevented that company from delivering parts to vehicle makers since 21 May and which threatens its very existence? Is the Minister concerned that the intense pressure on the company may force it to agree to demands, encouraged by Mr Halfpenny, for payment of whole or part of the 4 per cent second tier wage increase in advance of the framework laid down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, with the risk that such a decision might flow on to other parts of the metal trades industry? Given that the Minister, as I have, received a request from the company for urgent assistance, what can or will the Government do to resolve the continuing dispute at National Forge which threatens to disrupt the orderly wage fixing processes and destroy thousands of jobs in Australian manufacturing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the situation described by Senator Chaney in his question. It is true that I have had discussions today with the Managing Director of ANI, Mr Neil Jones, about this matter. Let me say first that Mr Jones has been a person who has always indicated to me on a whole range of issues that governments should keep out of these things and that ANI could solve its own industrial problems and other problems without assistance from government. I am not in any way trying to escape the point of Senator Chaney's question in saying that, but it raises an issue in respect of the industrial relations policy of the Opposition which, as Mr Howard described it not so long ago, could lead to five years of industrial chaos in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Although it is not Senator Chaney's obligation to answer-and I know that he will make me aware of that-I would be very interested to hear what he would do in that situation. He tries to pretend to the Australian people that he would wave a magic wand to settle the dispute at ANI. Of course, he would do nothing of the sort-he could not, and he knows that perfectly well. He knows that in the Fraser Government's seven years in office it tried to wave a number of not magic wands but big sticks to resolve disputes, but the level of industrial disputation in this country under that Government was twice what it is now under the Hawke Labor Government. Senator Chaney is implying by this question that on this occasion he has a magic wand, which may take the form of a big stick, he could use to resolve the problems, but of course it will not; it is not as simple as that.

I return to the specific point of Senator Chaney's question, quite apart from his general implication. Let me say that I have had discussions, as I indicated, with Mr Jones, and I hope to have discussions this afternoon with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations about this matter. We will see what can be done, but I do not intend to reveal the nature of those discussions at Question Time in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, if we can ignore the Minister's attempt to politicise the question. Are metal trades employers, including National Forge, operating within both the spirit and the letter of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision on the second tier wage negotiations? If the Minister agrees that that is the case, does he further agree that the meeting of those conditions by employers is in this case being met by a flagrant breach of the arrangements by the trade union concerned? Does he also agree that there is no apparent remedy available to an employer in this circumstance to protect himself or the company against this flagrant breach of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decision by the workers concerned? I ask the Minister, since he is still in government and will be in government for the next six weeks, what advice he has to offer these employers who are following the Government's own request to employers in respect of how they deal with their own work force but who are now being held up to this sort of industrial ransom.

—The terminology of the supplementary question is revealing, because Senator Chaney did not have as much time to think about it as he had to think about his initial question. He asked: Is there no apparent remedy available to the company? The implication of that part of the question is that somehow under Senator Chaney's charge of these matters a remedy would be immediately available to the company. The second part of the supplementary question to which I want to refer is the suggestion of a breach of arrangements by the union. That is not entirely consistent with my information. It may be that the honourable senator's information is different, but I understand that, in fact, the union takes a different position regarding the situation at ANI, or at least a position that is not identical with that of the work force at ANI-that is, that the work force at ANI is the issue of most importance, not the union's influence. So, once again, I come back to the question: What is the apparent remedy available to the company? The theory of industrial relations espoused by the troglodytes who sit behind Senator Chaney-in whichever forum he sits, whether in coalition with the Queensland Nationals or not-is that, in essence, these matters are best left to what is called enterprise bargaining.
—Agreements are then binding on both parties.

—Maybe. Enterprise bargaining means slogging it out in the market place. I suppose that that is what is happening at ANI. When enterprise bargaining gets a big tough, then honourable senators opposite say--
—You have imposed the system on people.

—No, I have not imposed this system. The honourable senator was in the Fraser Government for seven or eight years. People who were around at the start of the Fraser Government will remember Malcolm Fraser's famous speech about how these issues should be resolved by conciliation but if there was no conciliation, he said, there should be penal legislation which, to use his words, carried consequences. For seven years we had that system that involved legislation which carried consequences, and what happened? The Liberal- National Party Government had a record of industrial disputations that was twice as bad as the record of the present Government in the last four years.
—You are not going to answer the question, so why don't you just sit down?

—Senator Chaney asks why I do not sit down. That is the best interjection Senator Chaney has made. It reveals his true purpose-to get me to sit down and not answer this question. Not only did the Liberal-National Party Government have a level of industrial disputation during those eight years that was twice the present level but also it had wage levels that sent the economy of this country down the tube.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. We can tell that the Leader of the Government is debating the question, because he is shouting and waving his arms around. I draw your attention to the fact that the Standing Orders preclude the debating of questions and I suggest that you call the Minister to order and have him answer the question.
—There is no point of order.
—I am just rounding off, Mr President. I can tell Senator Chaney, in conclusion, that during the next five weeks he will not, when he wants to shut me up, be able to take a point of order.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that follows on from an answer he gave Senator Lewis two days ago. If the Department of Veterans' Affairs were to agree with the Opposition and give in to the demands of the medical profession, what would be the likely cost to the Government and how does this fit in with the Opposition's policy to close public hospitals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Childs has suggested, it is true that Senator Lewis asked me a question on Monday of this week which suggested that there may be some support from the Opposition for the outrageous demand of $119 per hour that was being made on the Government in respect of fees in the hospital system. He did so in his capacity as shadow Minister for the Territories as well as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I responded by pointing out to him the difficulties that the Government had in trying to reconcile the claims that have been made on the Government by the visiting medical specialists at the repatriation hospitals. In response to the question asked by Senator Childs, I point out that the costs are borne by government-that means, of course, either a Liberal government led by Mr Howard or the present Government led by Prime Minister Hawke. If we were to accede to the demand that was originally made of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to award the Macken fees, the cost to the Department would be some $30m. In a period in which the Prime Minister has suggested that there should be equity and restraint-which of course has been applied to trade unionists, pensioners, Commonwealth beneficiaries, and even to members of Parliament-I submit that that was an outrageous claim to make, having regard to the current economic circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: I am led to believe that the Opposition has a more benign attitude, a more understanding attitude, of this claim and what its implications would mean. However, if I were to move beyond the matched rates to any substantial degree in respect of the repatriation hospital system, that would have an immediate flow-on effect in relation to the State hospital systems. That would probably mean that doctors throughout Australia would be able to demand $100m from the public sector. I believe that that would be completely unacceptable to all State governments in Australia, whether that be the National Party Government in Queensland, the Labor Government in New South Wales or the Liberal Government in Tasmania, for example.

As I have been asked questions on this matter several times in recent weeks, I shall take this opportunity to inform the Senate that the Government has now agreed to make an offer to the visiting medical officers in South Australia. We hope that its implications will have a flow-on effect to the doctors at Heidelberg, Greenslopes and Hobart of $69 a sessional fee hour, which would represent an increase of 33 per cent on the current rates that are being paid on the contracts which expired in December 1986. The Government has made a substantial concession, having regard to the economic environment to which I have referred. I am sure that this measure will enjoy the support of the major ex-service organisations. It will certainly remove any threat to existing functioning of the repatriation hospitals throughout Australia. I am hopeful, therefore, that the doctors will appreciate that the Government has moved considerably from its previous offer. Therefore, this outcome should enjoy the support of the visiting medical specialists in whichever State they operate. The Government is also prepared to say that if the States in their budgeting arrangements are able to offer a higher fee in the negotiations of contracts pertaining to the way in which the State systems operate, the Government will be prepared to move even further in a matching rate arrangement. In other words, the Government again commits itself publicly to work in co-operation with the States, of whatever political complexion, to provide a matched rate for each of the respective States. At this stage they do vary for a whole variety of historical reasons, although there is a co-operative approach. I hope that this approach will enjoy the support of veterans' organisations, patients, the war widows, and ex-service personnel, who comprise the majority of patients in the repatriation hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to the Government's decision to try to buy some industrial peace with the Queensland coal unions for the purpose of the election campaign by its promise of a High Court of Australia challenge to that State's anti-strike legislation. Has this price been sufficient to persuade the unions to call off next week's planned 24-hour strikes? Have the unions given undertakings not to disrupt the coal industry during the High Court's consideration of this matter? Finally, have the unions undertaken to abide by the decision of the High Court?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike our opponents, who are all too keen to provoke and generate industrial confrontation in order to secure some marginal and transient political advantage, we are a government which is determined to act in the overall economic interests and for the overall economic benefit of the nation. That was the overwhelming basis on which we, as I explained yesterday, made the decision to initiate a High Court challenge to ensure as best we could, in the absence of our new industrial legislation, that it would not be possible for the Queensland Premier to employ the Queensland Act against, in particular, the Queensland mining unions. As I explained yesterday, massive economic consequences are likely to flow from any sustained disruption in the Queensland coal economy, constituting as it does an earner of some $3.2 billion in export earnings in the last calendar year alone. It is not a risk that this or any other government could possibly afford to take.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that there has been a course of discussion with the unions about this matter, extending back now for a period of some weeks. I am confident that, as a result of those discussions and the further discussions that I have had since the decision was taken yesterday, there will be no further industrial action for the foreseeable future by the Queensland coal mining unions or indeed any other responsible unions in that State. They are determined not to respond to crude and vulgar provocation of the kind that we have become all too used to from not only the Queensland Premier but also our opponents opposite. They are determined to bring to bear a restrained and mature approach to this problem. As I understand it, they are satisfied that the High Court challenge that we are initiating will give an opportunity for the legislation to be tested and, hopefully, defused in the short run, pending some longer term enactment of the new legislative regime applicable to these matters. As a result, I believe that the confrontation of a kind that would be so desperately damaging will be avoided.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Senator Gareth Evans did not answer my final question, namely: Have the unions undertaken to abide by the decision of the High Court of Australia?
—Australian unions are a law abiding group which always abide by the decisions of the courts of this land. I have no reason whatsoever to believe that in this instance they will behave otherwise.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and also concerns the role of unions in Australia. Various spokespersons of the New Right often argue and suggest that unions no longer have a legitimate role to play in the industrial relations environment. Does the Government agree with that view? Further, does the Government agree that in the late twentieth century Australia's unions should be swept away and individual employees left to negotiate their wages, hours and conditions on a one-to-one basis with their employers and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think everybody would acknowledge that employers now are far more intelligent and reasonable towards employees than they were, say, a century ago. But there is still a minority of ratbag employers around, and I will be drawing attention to a particular ratbag employer in a few minutes. Those who assert that unions are anachronistic are therefore guilty of ignoring the fact that there are still some ratbag employers around. I have here copies of two letters which were circulated by a Western Australian employer to 13 of his employees. I will just quote a couple of extracts from one of them. It is headed `Policy Note: Negligence fines'. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: As you are aware the restaurant industry is currently suffering the worst recession in living memory.
I interpolate that, as a question of fact, it also happens to be wrong. Leaving that aside, it continues:

The difference between survival and non-survival is cost-efficiency: This applies in all things but nowhere more so than in the `little things' e.g. electricity, ground maintenance theft, and waste of time and materials.
The letter continues:

Accordingly I have now introduced a system of fines as detailed below: The fines will be imposed on the basis of personal responsibility for the act of negligence, but where there is dispute as to who is responsible . . . the Staff member actually in charge will be fined as the team member ultimately responsible.

Appended to the letter is a schedule of the fines. For leaving a light on, the fine is $5 for each light; for leaving an appliance on it is $5, as it is for parking on the lawn at the pavilion; for leaving indoor tables outdoors-a pretty serious offence-a $20 fine; for leaving waste in the kitchen, a $10 fine; for leaving internal doors unlocked, a $15 fine; for leaving a cool-room door ajar, a $20 fine; and for leaving the external door unlocked a $50 fine. Both letters, by the way, are dated 11 April 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought exactly that, that it must be a typographical error and that this is something that has come from the archives and is dated 1887, but it is dated 1987-only two months ago. I table both letters. The second one, from which I will not read because it is a bit too long, sets out a seniority ladder for sackings. It says that if theft of any of the cutlery or crockery or whatever at these restaurants continues the most junior employee will be sacked, if it still continues the next most junior will be sacked, and so on until there are no employees left. Thus one employee is to be made the scapegoat every time the employer, acting as the judge, of course, and the prosecutor, decides-
—Come on! You have got to be joking.
—No, I am not. I have the letters here.
—This is a leaked document from the Liberal Party.

—It may well have come to us from the Liberal Party, but I will come to that at the end. I understand that it was a practice in nazi slave labour camps that if anything was stolen one prisoner would be taken out and shot. This is not quite that but, if anything is stolen, one employee will be sacked without any evidence whatsoever that the employee sacked had anything to do with the theft. This demonstrates quite decisively that, while there are ratbag employers such as this around, no reasonable person could argue that there is not a useful role for unions.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point that I want to make is that this employer, whose signature appears on the letter, is one James MacDonald, who is the principal of what appears to be a company called Sereaglio Park. He is perhaps better known as No. 1, the leader, on the National Party Senate ticket in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to the recent report of the Government's higher education administration charge monitoring committee whose recommendations include, amongst other things, a system whereby part time and external students would pay no more than full time students during the duration of their studies for the same course and an expansion of the categories of students exempt from payment of the charge. It also pointed out the difficulties of women in a range of special categories. Will the Minister guarantee that if the Government is re-elected it will adopt the changes to her Party's policy with regard to the implementation of the charge, as has been recom-mended by the committee?

—It is the case that the monitoring committee which I established to look at the impact of the higher education administration charge on the enrolment of certain groups has reported to me. That report has been discussed with a number of groups, including the Caucus committees and other interested education bodies. The recommendations include the particular one to which Senator Macklin referred in his question. The recommendations of the committee will be considered by the Cabinet in the Budget context.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not proposed during the election campaign to give any guarantee to students with regard to these proposed changes?
—The Prime Minister will be making the election speech on behalf of the Government, and Senator Macklin can wait until then.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANSFER OF COMMONWEALTH RESPONSIBILITIES TO THE STATES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Hawke Government considered the option of funding further tax cuts-that is, over and above the substantial 1 July tax cuts-by shifting Commonwealth responsibilities on to the States, as proposed by the Queensland Government at the Premiers Conference and, more recently, by the Liberal Opposition? What are the implications of such a policy proposal? Does the Government have any plans to implement such a proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not have at the moment any plans for major shifts of the type to which Senator Maguire referred. It is always possible, of course, that in relation to some relatively small programs a judgment could be made that it would be administratively more efficient to transfer them to the States and to roll into the normal States grants the funding that previously went to them. Indeed, a couple of fairly small programs had that done to them in the May statement. The Government does not have any plans to make major changes of the sort which were suggested by the Premier of Queensland. It is, of course, possible to make cosmetic reductions in public expenditure if such major changes are made. For example, it is being argued by some now that the Commonwealth Government should completely withdraw from health funding. There would be a cosmetic reduction in public expenditure if that were to happen, but that would be more than offset by the increase in private expenditure. Some go even further than that and argue that the State governments as well as the Commonwealth Government should withdraw from health funding, apart from funding for pensioners and similar groups.

ANSWER.PARA: The implications of the proposals that have been put up, but not by the Government, are very hard to assess because it is difficult to know what they mean. For example, in a Press release issued today by the Leader of the Opposition it is reported that the two leaders-that is, Petersen and Howard-agreed that any important variations between their basic policies for Australia's economic recovery could be resolved co-operatively and translated into urgent legislation immediately after a new conservative government is sworn in. Mr Sinclair, who is the actual leader or the titular leader of the National Party of Australia, is not a sponsor of the Press release and he apparently was not at the meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a wimp of an agreement it is, too.
—An agreement, yes. That is not surprising because Mr Sinclair said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio on 29 April:

ANSWER.PARA: A coalition gave us an opportunity to go into Government and to make sure that the right policies were in place to take effect as of day one. Now it will be necessary to go into the election campaign with our separate policies and then after the election to enter negotiations with the Liberal Party, form a Coalition, and then work out which of the policies that have been presented to the people are going to be in fact put in place.

The policies that will be presented to the people and put in place will be worked out after the election, Mr Sinclair said. In the little private meeting that Petersen and Mr Howard had today, from which Sinclair was excluded, it was stated:
. . . any important variations between their basic policies . . . could be resolved co-operatively . . .

We all know what that means; it means yet another abject surrender by the Liberal Party to the National Party. That is what the resolution of policy differences means. The Liberal Party is yet again running up the white flag. The following is what Petersen said about Howard on 1 March on the Sunday program:
He made an utter and complete mess of it when he was Treasurer . . . .
Even Petersen is not wrong all the time. The following is what Petersen said about Howard and Sinclair:
You can't have two policies in one basket; it's like having two apples-one good and one bad. Pretty soon both turn bad.
I do not think anybody would disagree with that statement either.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. I hope he will not give such a long chat-up as Senator Walsh has just given. I refer the Minister to the Grassy Hill lighthouse and reserve at Cooktown which, for the information of the Senate, was the site where Captain Cook climbed to look for a way through the Great Barrier Reef in 1770 after putting into Cooktown for repairs. In view of Australia's coming Bicentenary and the enormous historical importance of this site to the people of Australia, will the Minister review the decision of his Government to sell this site at a price that the small Cooktown Shire cannot afford and instead move to ensure that this lighthouse is preserved and passed on to the Cooktown Shire Council for a nominal lease, thus guaranteeing its safe keeping?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a number of reasons I am very pleased to respond to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. I am very surprised that a person of her calibre and political maturity has not yet heard the news in respect of the area to which she referred in her question. Obviously it means that with all the toing and froing that has been going on between the Queensland Nationals and the Nationals, and the Liberals and the conservatives generally, she has not had time even to read the newspapers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services met with the Federal member for Leichhardt, John Gayler, and the State member for Cook, Mr Scott, when he was in Cairns last week to discuss the Cooktown lighthouse. It was decided in such august company that there would be recognition for the heritage and environment value of the property and that it should be transferred to an appropriate authority-either the State or local government entity-for a token fee. This, of course, is an indication of this Government's commitment to the protection of our heritage. This decision was announced by John Gayler, the local member, and reported widely in all of the local media on 20 May 1987. This Federal Labor initiative recognises the history of the lighthouse-as does Senator Bjelke-Petersen-and its importance to the local community. The Commonwealth has not made any money out of the deal in spite of the fact that the lighthouse was acquired from the State Government of Queensland at its market price. So we have put our money where our mouth is in respect of this important piece of our history.

The National Party Government in Queensland has not given any commitment to contributing to the preservation and upkeep of this important and historic property. Therefore, I ask the honourable senator whether she would be kind enough to raise the matter with her husband, the Premier, and suggest that the Queensland Government take on the responsibility of maintaining this important property.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABOLITION OF MEDICARE: EFFECT ON BUDGET

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Has the Government evaluated the potential savings to be made if Medicare were to be dismantled? What is the Government's assessment of this measure to the Budget? Is the Minister aware of other estimates which differ from those of the Government? Will the Minister account for any discrepancy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West's question referred to the potential savings that could be made if Medicare were dismantled. I am not sure whether there is a precise definition of just what that means or whether it is possible to present a precise definition, but on the entire health function the Commonwealth is currently spending about $7.3 billion a year. That covers nursing homes, medical benefits, pharmaceutical benefits and the grants paid to the States for the operation of public hospitals or for providing free treatment in public hospitals. In addition to that, as I mentioned earlier in Question Time, the States spend a large amount of money from their resources on principally hospital maintenance but also some other health matters.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Commonwealth and the States were to withdraw from providing any funds, other than for the support of pensioners and such groups, some $5.8 billion would be saved, about something over half of which would be savings to the Commonwealth. The effect of people then taking out private health insurance to cover their increased personal liabilities would, as I mentioned the other day, push up the consumer price index by more than 6 per cent. If governments were to withdraw their funding in that way, the CPI would be increased by something more than 6 per cent. There is considerable disagreement within the Opposition about the savings that would be made if Medicare were dismantled. I have a transcript from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation World Today of 1 June in which Michael Dodd stated:
Senator Baume-
that is, Senator Michael Baume-
you are a very new shadow health Minister-
And it shows. The transcript continued:
firstly do you stand by the claims that you will save at least three billion dollars in the health area?
Senator Michael Baume said:
I would think there is every prospect of that . . .
On the same day when interviewing Mr Howard on the same subject John Laws asked:
How much of that will you save?
Mr Howard said:
I can only talk in the order of about $2 billion.
Depending on whether one wishes to believe the shadow health Minister or the Leader of the Opposition-they reckon that $2 billion or $3 billion--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the deficit they left us-give or take a few billion.

—When one is presenting a prospective deficit of $16 billion, I suppose it really does not matter very much whether one is out by $1 billion in the costing of one individual policy item. If such a change were to be made-this means that the Commonwealth only would withdraw from health funding and would still leave a lot of money to be spent by the States-as Dr Blewett and Mr Keating revealed last Monday, the consequence would be a $27 a week slug for every family to cover the additional private health insurance which it would be obliged to take out. Another perspective on that underlying reality is the fact that the consumer price index would rise by more than 6 per cent in one hit.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and also refers to yesterday's announcement that the Federal Government, having squibbed on its own Industrial Relations Bill, proposes to squander taxpayers' money by launching proceedings in the High Court to strike down Queensland anti-strike legislation. Is it a fact that industrial legislation imposing maximum fines of $50,000 for individuals and $250,000 for associations in respect of secondary boycotts was passed by the Queensland Parliament as long ago as November 1984, and that following the South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute in 1985 the Act was further amended to require seven days' clear notice of strikes? Why, until now, has the Government not taken any action in the High Court or elsewhere to strike down the Queensland legislation? If the Government were to obtain the declaration that it now regards as so urgent, what action would it then suggest be taken to protect the $5 billion coal export industry and in particular Queensland exports of $3.2 billion which continue to be threatened by an appalling strike record, or would the Government choose to throw itself on the mercy of a labour court in a desperate plea for another dose of industrial realism to avoid the massive economic consequences, to borrow the Minister's description, which have characterised the industry for so long?

—The short answer in respect of taking the action we are taking now rather than having done so earlier is that the legislation in Queensland has been further amended in recent months to make it even more unnecessarily provocative in its scope and potential application. Furthermore, it has become apparent that, even more so than in previous times, we have a maniac with a match running around next to the tinder box only too determined to set it alight. In those circumstances it is not an exercise in anything other than economic responsibility for the Government to take every course of action open to it to minimise the prospects of such an eruption occurring.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and follows an answer given by Senator Gareth Evans last week to a question asked by Senator MacGibbon. I remind the Minister that a number of Australians are currently stationed or deployed in Fiji and the surrounding area as part of Australia's contribution to the stability of the area and in case a need develops to evacuate Australians quickly. The Minister will be aware of the problems with repatriation benefits for those in other peacekeeping and occupational areas which have occurred in the past and which I personally have had to raise with his Department. Will the Minister advise the Senate of the eligibility for repatriation benefits of members of the defence forces serving in the Fijian area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the question on this topic that was asked of Senator Gareth Evans by Senator MacGibbon one day last week. It showed a lamentable lack of knowledge of who is responsible for the treatment of injuries arising out of war service. The question was asked of Senator Evans in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, whereas if Senator MacGibbon had known about ministerial responsibilities he would have put that question to me. It shows his ignorance of the repatriation system and particularly of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I am not surprised about that. I have received a large number of letters from National and Liberal Party members in both Houses making submissions to me in respect of the Government's attitude to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Fund. That does not come within my area of jurisdiction but is part of the area of responsibility covered by the Minister for Defence. Obviously Opposition members do not know the processes of government.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in respect of the question put to me by Senator Coleman, which flows naturally from the interest expressed by Senator MacGibbon, I would point out that there are eligibility provisions in the Veterans' Entitlements Act which would cover any personnel serving on behalf of the Australian Government in Fiji. There are three specific questions involved. If any Australian servicemen or servicewomen were sent to Fiji as part of the regular defence forces, provided that they had served for three years they would generally be covered in respect of injuries or death as a result of that service. If they had not served that period of time, the responsibility would rest with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs of the day to designate that force as part of a peacekeeping force, provided that it is gazetted by the Minister that in respect of service outside Australia such personnel would be eligible for benefits and treatment in accordance with the normal provisions of the repatriation legislation. I have done that in respect of six or seven peacekeeping operations that have taken place in years past which were not gazetted by previous Ministers for Veterans' Affairs. However, if it were determined by the Minister for Defence that it was a hazardous zone, other benefits would accrue to the person affected by involvement in Fiji. Since 1972, when the Whit- lam Government extended repatriation benefits to peacetime personnel, some 80,000 personnel have received certain benefits covered by the Veterans' Entitlements Act as a result of their peacetime service or of activities in a peacekeeping force. Those arrangements could apply to any person who, as a result of Government decision, goes to Fiji.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Education. I draw the Minister's attention to the appalling situation that currently exists with the delayed payment of allowances under the assistance to isolated children scheme. Can the Minister confirm that of the 12,339 applications received by 15 May 1987, only 4,324 applicants have been paid-that is, the great majority have already gone without payment for five months? Can the Minister also confirm that the figures for New South Wales, with 3,156 applicants but only 322 payments made so far, are correct, and that in my own State of South Australia barely a quarter of the 665 isolated children's scheme applicants have so far been processed? Can the Minister inform the Senate how much longer the parents and children who rely on this scheme must wait, and is it true that the Department has been directed to give priority to Austudy applications before assistance to isolated children's scheme applications? Will all payments be completed before 11 July?

—I was expecting an apology from Senator Teague, not a tirade about the late payments of this form of assistance. It is the case that there have been delays in the payment of this benefit to isolated children; it is the case that special arrangements have been made to assist where delays have occurred; and it is also the case that applications are being received, assessed and processed for payment as quickly as possible, and manual payment systems are being used to make first and second term payments. Yesterday I called for a briefing on where we were with this matter, and instructed that all outstanding payments be dealt with as quickly as possible. Now that virtually all the Austudy payments have been made, it will be possible to give very prompt settlement--
—There must be an election in the offing.

—No wonder Opposition senators interject when their leader, John Howard, goes around offering to cut $8 billion off Commonwealth payments, as a result of which there would clearly be no Commonwealth funds available to assist isolated children. No wonder they want to distract attention from the fact that, although some of the payments have been delayed by us, every student eligible for payment will be paid very shortly whereas, in the highly unlikely event of the Liberals coming to government, with $8 billion of Commonwealth outlays there would be no money for children in our schools, isolated or otherwise.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. When will all payments be completed, and will that be before 11 July?
—It is my expectation that they will be completed in the next couple of weeks.

—Further to Senator West's question, has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the article on the front page of yesterday's Age newspaper headed `Liberals would pull Medicare apart', where it is reported that Senator Michael Baume admitted that five million people may be worse off under the Liberals' proposal to dismantle Medicare? He further added that eight million people would be better off because they would no longer subsidise Medicare. Can the Minister explain to the Senate why the Government insists on Medicare, particularly because of its emphasis on fairness and protection for those five million on lower incomes and pensions, and why the blatant intention of the Opposition, when it shamelessly claims to disadvantage five million people, is totally opposed by this Government? Can he explain how the Opposition's claims will add dramatically to the cost of health for all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been made aware of the article and the reported admission by Senator Michael Baume that five million Australians would be worse off under the Opposition's health policy. That is a very modest figure according to the calculations that have been carried out by independent public officials without any political bias in the Treasury and the Department of Health. For Senator Baume to make the concession that five million Australians would be worse off under the Opposition's health policy, is an extremely damning indictment of the proposals that have emanated from the Opposition benches in relation to the health care of Australians. As far as this Government is concerned, it is quite intolerable that Australian families faced particularly with chronic illness or the results of a traumatic accident, whether it be industrial or on the roads, should have added financial burdens of the sort brought about by Opposition policies. A detailed analysis of the Opposition's health policy which was undertaken by Treasury and Department of Health officials-and I emphasise that these are independent public officials-shows that the extra cost for families would be in the region of $27 per week. To bring about a successful shift from the Government-subsidised Medicare system to the private health insurance system, requiring a cost of some $27 a week, it is quite clear that the Opposition-and it has not mentioned this-would have to strike a Medicare levy for the remaining Australians within the Medicare system possibly as high as 5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: One recalls that under Mr Fraser the Medicare levy went up to 2.5 per cent in order to try to shift Australians across to the private health insurance system. This Government believes that Australian families should not have to pay $27 a week in order to purchase protection against chronic illness and the results of traumatic accidents, as I have outlined. The Medicare system is based on the premise that people should make a contribution to the health care of all Australians in accordance with their income and the idea that poor people and those with below average incomes should pay as much as those who are wealthy-$27 per week per family, a flat rate with no equitable impact on the households concerned-is an intolerable proposition. The Opposition proposal is something that we have seen before. This attempt to shift some 60 to 64 per cent of Australians into private health insurance funds was precisely what was attempted by Mr Fraser when he introduced that scheme in 1976. That scheme, which is now being proposed by the Opposition, lasted only 21 months and was followed by a succession of changes-in July 1978, November 1978, September 1979 and September 1981. We all recall the constant hardship and confusion caused by the continual revamping of the various health schemes under the conservatives.

It will be recalled that ultimately the effect of that policy, which the Opposition now wants to reinflict on the Australian people, was to have two million Australians stranded between Medicare and the private health insurance funds and quite unable to afford the sort of protection which their families deserved. Some two million people dropped out of the system without having the sort of medical and health care to which they were entitled. Now Senator Michael Baume wants to bump that figure up to five million Australians who will be worse off. This Government and, I am sure, the Australian people as well, believe that the Medicare system-it has had some imperfections along the way but these have been admitted and addressed-is far better and far more equitable than that proposed by members of the Opposition which would leave five million Australians worse off.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: INTERNAL REVIEW

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Was McKinsey and Co. recently paid $400,000 to undertake yet another internal review of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation? Did this payment have ministerial approval? Has this McKinsey review been used to justify a further internal rearrangement of the CSIRO in which no real input was allowed from any other than the directors of that organisation, and one of the consequences of which may well be the destruction of the world recognised division of mathematics and statistics in CSIRO? Have all the details of McKinsey's analysis of the administration of the CSIRO been suppressed and kept secret, especially from the CSIRO staff, and will the administration of the organisation actually increase under the McKinsey plan? When the CSIRO Board meets on 17 June, will the Federal Government make known its views on this further proposed reorganisation?

—I do not know whether there is anything terribly secret about the McKinsey organisation undertaking a consultancy in respect of the CSIRO. I read it in the newspapers and it should not surprise Senator Puplick. The details of this matter are appropriately for the Minister for Science and I ask Senator Puplick to place the question on notice.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, concerns exploration by Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd for uranium, gold and diamonds in the Rudall River National Park in Western Australia. Does the Minister agree with the assessment of a senior source in the Australian Mining Industry Council that the mine is `a three-act nightmare'-that is, uranium in a national park and on Aboriginal land? Could he confirm his earlier statement quoted in the Times on Sunday of 19 April that the Government does not plan to change Australian Labor Party policy by encouraging CRA to mine the Kintyre region in order to relieve pressure for uranium mining in Kakadu National Park?
