Has the Minister consulted with members of the Pangurr Aboriginal community in the area, whose water bore is threatened by the mine and who have complained of fixed wing aircraft and helicopters buzzing the community? Finally, have core samples from four drilling rigs inside the park been flown direct to Melbourne and, if so, have any assessments been made or published about them?

—I am happy to repeat what I told the Senate on 25 March this year in relation to this matter when I said that both the Western Australian Government and CRA have discussed their interests in this deposit with me but I made it absolutely clear, and they understand and accept this, that under the Government's uranium policy, the Kintyre deposit could not proceed to development. As I have told the Senate on several occasions, the three-mines policy remains quite firm and there is no proposal to alter it. I said that in March and I repeat it now. I am not aware of the Commonwealth having consulted with the Pangurr Aboriginal community and in any case such consultations would be the responsibility of the Western Australian Government. I am not aware of whether core samples from the area have been flown to Melbourne or elsewhere, nor whether any assessments have been published about them. I do not know whether, as Senator Vallentine asserts, the Australian Mining Industry Council regards the Kintyre deposit as a nightmare. All I can say is that ALP policy does not prohibit the kind of exploration activity being undertaken by CRA. As long as this remains a purely exploration exercise, I certainly will not lose any sleep over it.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and while she is shuffling her papers I would like to welcome back to our midst the guardians of truth and defenders of democracy, the ladies and gentlemen of the Fourth Estate. Will the Minister advise why the report compiled by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Australia, on cruelty involved in the killing of wallabies in Tasmania has not been released publicly? Will the Minister make the report available immediately? Given that it is now almost six months since the 11-member kangaroo advisory committee meeting on 10 and 11 December 1986, why have the final minutes not been agreed to or adopted? Will the Minister make available the tape recording of this meeting? Finally, when will the Queensland Government release the supporting documentation for its 1987 kangaroo management program?
—I will have to follow the example of my leader and suggest that Senator Sanders put those questions on notice. I am sure that Mr Cohen will answer them as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. What has been the response to the Government's provision of a young homeless allowance? How many young people are currently receiving this allowance? What steps is the Government taking to make the community aware of its availability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Zakharov will be aware, because she is very interested in the circumstances of disadvantaged young people, the young homeless allowance was introduced by our Government on 1 July 1986. It is a measure of the compassion that our Government has shown towards young people in desperate circumstances that it accelerated the introduction of the young homeless allowance before the other aspects of the rationalisation of youth allowances were introduced. Before the young homeless allowance-under the previous Government, in which Senator Chaney was a Minister-nothing was available to tertiary students who were homeless and secondary students had to prove a capacity for self-support, including the possession of $1,800 in assets, to qualify for the independent rate of secondary assistance. Of course, as Senator Zakharov may be aware, very few qualified under such harsh conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: Under our Government's scheme, young people may be eligible for a payment of $73.28 a week if they have reached school leaving age and are unable to live at home because there is no family home, because they have been refused permission to reside there under any circumstances or because it would be unreasonable to expect them to return home due to domestic violence, sexual harassment or any other exceptional circumstances, and if they are not in receipt of support from their parents or any other continuous source. My Department has received 4,198 applications for the young homeless allowance so far this year. Resulting from these 2,190 applicants are receiving regular fortnightly payments. About 500 have been deemed ineligible and the remainder of applications are recently received or awaiting additional information. These figures need to be seen in conjunction with social security payments to young homeless unemployed people. The latest information I have is that 903 young homeless people were receiving payments from the Department of Social Security as at the middle of March this year.

As to the promotion of this scheme and information to the community about its existence, the scheme, as I said, was launched in 1986 with substantial publicity. The launch was followed up through educational and welfare institutions and career advisers. The young homeless allowance is now administered within my Department as part of the Austudy scheme and is publicised in conjunction with that scheme. In conclusion, the scheme has proved to be successful. Thousands of genuinely homeless young people are now receiving this benefit. When Senator Chaney or his ilk like to leap on the bandwagon and say that we are not doing enough for disadvantaged youth, they conveniently ignore, as I am afraid sometimes the media ignores, the existence of this benefit. It is a substantial improvement for young people in very difficult circumstances. I for one am proud that the Government has taken this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At Question Time, Senator Tate said that I had admitted that five million Australians would be worse off under the Liberal Party health plan. I made no such admission. What I said-and it is important that this be clear in the mind of the Government if it wants to continue to misstate what I said-was that eight million Australians stood to be better off, depending on their tax position, under our health plans. I said that three million underprivileged people would be better off because they would still pay nothing but would get better access to health services, and then I said that five million may-and I stressed the word `may'-be worse off depending on their tax status, so that 70 per cent of Australians would benefit from our health scheme.

—by leave-Concerning the media package which was passed by the Senate yesterday, about which I have great regrets on the whole, I wish to make it clear that I would have supported the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill had there been an opportunity to deal with it separately. That Bill was formed in response to a request from some South Pacific neighbours for Australia to assist in the improvement of their international telecommunications systems. I believe that this kind of assistance is valuable in building good relations. It is much more useful than military aid of any kind in any direction. But I voted against the whole package because of my opposition to other Bills therein, particularly those concerning ownership and control. Democracy is not well served by the increasing monopolisation of the media, because information from a wide variety of sources is fundamental to people's ability to make sound judgments on all issues.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I do not mind Senator Vallentine making speeches, but she should do it at the appropriate time. This speech should have been made yesterday when the communications legislation was before the Senate. This is not a personal explanation.
—I support that point of order.
—Senator Vallentine, you sought leave to make a personal explanation. You are beginning to debate the issue that the Senate debated yesterday.
—I just wanted to state why I could not vote for a particular aspect of that legislation because it was in a package.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1987SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1987CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987CUSTOMS TARIFF (COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1987HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987LOCAL GOVERNMENT (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was speaking in support of the Hawke Government's Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. The Government is taking further measures to crack down on welfare fraud in the Australian community, just as we have cracked down repeatedly on tax avoidance and tax fraud over the period that we have been in government. The measures taken on welfare fraud in last year's Budget reduced the number of unemployment beneficiaries by 27,000, saving $100m in a full year. There has been a very large reduction in the extent of welfare fraud as a result of the initiatives of this Government. The efforts taken by the Hawke Government in this area are to be expanded by tripling the number of unemployment beneficiaries interviewed. They will have to submit to personal interviews to determine their continuing eligibility for benefits. From December, the assets test will be applied to unemployment beneficiaries and sickness beneficiaries over the age of 25 years. That will close a loophole in the pensions assets test whereby some people, I regret to say, were taking early retirement then claiming the unemployment benefit. Effectively, it was a means of getting around the assets test on the age pension.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the legislation before us an extended penalty period will apply to recipients of unemployment benefits who cannot prove that they have been actively seeking work. The Hawke Government has an impressive record in providing social welfare to those in genuine need. Redistribution of income and resources towards low income households has been significant under the Labor Government. This Government has promoted fairness in the community at every opportunity. Through tax reform and expenditure programs the Hawke Government has attacked poverty and promoted greater social justice. Since March 1983 when the Hawke Government was elected to office, it has increased social security payments by more than $1,500m above what was required to keep pace with inflation. In other words, the total allocation for social welfare in the Budget has increased by more than $1,500m ahead of cost of living increases as measured by the consumer price index. These are tremendous increases in social security payments.

Unemployment has been the greatest cause of poverty-a scourge. The Hawke Government has directly attacked this principal cause of poverty by creating over three-quarters of a million new jobs since the National Economic Summit Conference was convened in April 1983. That compares with the destruction of 186,000 jobs in the last 12 months of Mr Howard's attempt at running the country as Treasurer in the Liberal Government. Some of the specific social security initiatives taken by this Government include increases in rental assistance for pensioners renting from private landlords from $10 a week to $15 a week. I am very pleased to say that from 1 July the separate income test for rent assistance will be abolished. So, a number of pensioners will receive rental assistance as a result of the abolition of the separate income test. But we have gone beyond that. We have also extended rental assistance to the unemployed. In the 1985 Budget we introduced rental assistance of up to $10 a week for persons out of work for over six months and renting in the private market.

In regard to the children of pensioners and beneficiaries, the record of the Hawke Labor Government since 1983 is second to none. I refer to the additional pension or benefit which is available in respect of the children of social welfare recipients. In 1983, when this Government came to office, the additional pension or benefit for such children was $10 per week per child. That was the record, the legacy, of the Howard Treasury. By the end of 1986 the Hawke Government was not paying just $10 per week per child; it was paying $17 per week per child. That is a 70 per cent rise in nominal terms. Most importantly, it is an increase well ahead of the consumer price index or cost of living increase of 29 per cent to the December quarter last year. So, in effect, pensioners and beneficiaries with children have received an increase over and above the cost of living rise of $4 a week per child in that period under the Hawke Labor Government.

Yet this morning-Senator Robertson was here to hear it-we heard absolute drivel from Senator Walters, a senator from Tasmania, who I find is increasingly out of touch with reality. When talking on this legislation this morning Senator Walters said: `This Labor Government treats children as a luxury'. Yet when Mr Howard was Treasurer and had his last go at running this country pensioners and beneficiaries received $10 per week in respect of dependent children. Under this Government the figure is not $10 per week per child; it is $17 per week per child. So, where is the luxury Senator Walters was talking about? We do not regard the children of pensioners and beneficiaries as some sort of luxury. We have given them a $7 a week rise, which is a 70 per cent increase in nominal terms and a $4 a week rise ahead of the increase in the cost of living. That is our record in regard to the children of pensioners and beneficiaries. They are not a luxury and they have not been treated as such by this compassionate and fair Hawke Labor Government. Senator Walters's nonsensical claims are once again disproved by the figures. The figures show just how out of touch is the increasingly irrelevant senator from Tasmania.

There will be more assistance for families in the Government's forthcoming family package which will be announced shortly. I am sure that there will be significant increases in social welfare payments for needy families in the family package. I turn to the mother's or guardian's allowance paid to single pensioners. Not so long ago the allowance was $6 per week. This Government has doubled the mother's or guardian's allowance to $12 a week. So, once again there has been a significant increase in a social welfare payment under the Hawke Labor Government.

Once again the figures disprove the nonsense talked this morning by Senator Walters, who said `This Hawke Government treats children as a luxury' and, in her convoluted use of the English language, went on to say `The family is a major hit point for this Government'. The figures clearly show that, far from being a major hit point, families have done extraordinarily well under this Labor Government. It just goes to show that the Liberal Party regards social welfare recipients as some sort of underclass. That is the Liberal Party's attitude. It does not regard them as ordinary Australian families. It regards them as an underclass and is not prepared to talk about them when considering the true position of the family. They are some of the figures I wished to put on the record today to prove to the Senate that this Government's record in regard to social welfare is second to none.

I turn to the specific provision in the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill which provides for an income test on family allowances. This is a measure which I have supported for some time. It will further the promotion of fairness in the community by the Hawke Government. Again, our record of promoting fairness and social justice in the community has been very strong. It is correct and proper that high income households should be subject to an income test on family allowances. It is important to put the family allowances program into some perspective. It has become such a large program in the budgetary system that it is very difficult to know exactly how to reform it. It has become so large that some really strong decisions have to be made within the next few years. The program will cost some $1,365m this financial year. As I said, it is a very large program and requires much serious thought in future years. It provides assistance to 3.9 million children and to just under two million families-a major and very costly program.

To give honourable senators an idea of the dimensions of the family allowances program, I point out that to increase the allowance per child by 25c a week would cost a staggering $50m a year. To provide a $1 a week increase in the family allowance would cost $200m a year-a very substantial amount of money. As I said earlier, the program is so large that in reforming it one has to take great care and consider very diligently indeed what is being proposed.

I have said that the Government is to introduce a family assistance package. The package is on the drawing board and will be available shortly. I hope and trust that the package, which will be introduced by the Hawke Government in the next two months, will provide a further boost to the circumstances of pensioner families with children-an area of great priority in the community. Possibly there will be some scope for a boost to payments for working families with relatively low incomes. The legislation provides that the family allowance will be income tested in the case of a one-child family with an income of $50,000 a year. The allowance will be available to households above that income level because there is a tapered cut-off of 25c of allowance lost for every $1 of extra income. That is the withdrawal rate.

Some family allowance will be paid to a two-child family earning up to $55,156 a year, on my calculations. That is not a low income. It is quite high. It is the absolute cut-off point for family allowances in the case of a two-child family. In the case of a three-child family, which is very close to my situation, the income cut-off point is $59,528-again, a high income. I think it is only fair and proper that families with incomes above those levels should not receive the family allowance. they are not low income families; in fact, they earn well above the middle and low incomes that are earned by many Australians. The Liberal Party of Australia continues to complain about the income test on family allowances. It wants to assist the very high income families in Australia and, once again, the conservative parties are showing their true colours by their bleatings about the family allowance when, as I pointed out earlier today, some allowance will still be available for a two-child family on an income not exceeding $55,156.

In many other ways the Hawke Labor Government has promoted fairness and social justice in the Australian community. In many other instances the Labor Government has assisted the poor and needy groups in the Australian community. In that respect I refer to the indexation of pensions for the cost of living rises. The measures that we are debating this afternoon are contained in the May economic statement, and that statement maintained pension indexation for Australian social welfare recipients. It has given them continued protection from cost of living rises and it is very pleasing to note that on 25 June, which is only three weeks away, Australian pensioners and beneficiaries will receive an increase in their payments of about 5.5 per cent. I understand that that payment, which compensates pensioners for cost of living rises, will amount to about $5.95 for a single person, making the standard rate of single pension $112.15 per week and, for a couple, pensions will rise by 9.90 per week, making the combined pension rate from 25 June, $187. Those payments will be available to aged, invalid and widow pensioners as well as to supporting parents. Also, it will be available to married persons receiving unemployment and sickness benefits as well as to single persons aged 21 years and over who receive unemployment benefits and who have no dependants. It is very pleasing to note also that those increases will apply to persons receiving service, disability and war widow pensions paid through the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The Government will not stop there and say that that is all we will do for Australia's pensioners. From 1 July, the Government will introduce more measures that will have a profound effect on improving the standard of living of Australians who rely on the social welfare system, because on 1 July there will be further significant increases in extra incomes allowable to pensioners before they lose part of their pension as a result of the extra earnings. From 1 July the allowable extra income for a single pensioner will be increased from $30 to $40 a week and, for a couple, the allowable extra income will increase from $50 to $70 a week. They are tremendous increases that will allow many Australian pensioners to receive substantially greater incomes before moving from a full to a part pension.

We are going further than that. We are taking extra measures to improve the circumstances of the neediest Australian families who depend on social welfare. As a result of the Government's 1 July package, the amount of income that is disregarded in the case of pensioners who have dependent children also will be increased to improve the circumstances of needy pensioners. We will increase the amount of $6 per week income which is disregarded to $12 per week per dependent child in pensioner families; so, in that one move, again the Hawke Government is showing its true colours in promoting fairness, compassion and social justice in the Australian community by doubling the amount of income that is disregarded in the case of dependent children of pensioners.

As a result of the changes in the basic income test for the pensions and the doubling of the income disregarded, compared with the current situation where a couple with one dependent child can have an extra income of $56 per week before they lose part of their pension, from 1 July it will increase not to $66 per week, not to $76 per week but, rather, the figure will be $82. That is a significant increase in the amount of extra earnings that are available to pensioners before they lose part of their pension. They are further examples of what the Hawke Government has done for Australian families and what it has done across the board for those who rely on Australia's social welfare system for their economic welfare. They provide further assistance and tangible benefits for those families, which again exposes the absolute nonsense mentioned earlier today by that irrelevant senator from Tasmania, Senator Walters, who said that the Labor Government did nothing for families, that it ignored families and that it regarded children as a luxury in this country. Those examples provide further tangible and substantial improvements in the amounts of money and concessions available to those needy Australian families who depend on the Australian welfare system.

In relation to the bottom line of all this, the relationship of pensions to average weekly earnings, I will refer to the relativity of social welfare payments to earnings of those Australians who are in the work force. When Mr Howard was Treasurer the proportion of average weekly earnings constituted by the age pension in Australia was 22 per cent. That was the record in 1982 and, as of the past few months of 1986, under the Labor Government that figure was not 22 per cent, it was not 23 per cent, but, rather, it was 24 per cent, which shows that this Hawke Government is on track and is on target in moving pensions up to the pledged amount of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. So, that is the record of this Government and that shows what it has done to improve the welfare of Australians who depend on the social security system.

Turning to what I think is a scandal which existed under the Howard-Fraser Government, I refer to the treatment of single adult unemployed people in Australia. They were treated as an underclass in this country. The single adult unemployment benefit was held arbitrarily a long way below the aged pension in this country. It is very illuminating to note that, when Mr Howard had his last go at running the country, the single adult unemployment benefit for a person aged 21 years and over and who had no dependants was $64.40 a week. That figure compared very unfavourably with the single age pension of $77.25, so there was a gap and an unfair discrimination of $12.85 per week against those very needy Australians who depended on unemployment benefits. I am very pleased to note that, as a result of the initiatives taken by the Hawke Government, both through indexation and through discretionary increases in that benefit from time to time, that gap now has been narrowed very substantially, so that while there was a gap of $12.85 per week when Mr Howard was Treasurer from 25 June when the benefit is increased in line with pensions and so forth the gap will be reduced to $7.45 per week. So, a single adult unemployment beneficiary aged 21 years and over will receive $104.70 per week, compared with the standard age pension of $112.15 per week. That is a very substantial relative improvement in a most discriminated against category in the Australian community, the single adult unemployed, and that improvement in their circumstances has resulted from the phenomenal increase which has been granted in that benefit under the Hawke Government.

Again, the Government has shown its compassion and it has demonstrated its commitment to fairness and social justice by granting a 62.5 per cent increase in that unemployment benefit up to and including June this year. That increase of over 60 per cent in the amount of benefit pay- able to those persons compares with the cost of living rise of around 30 per cent. That is a substantial real increase in the circumstances of those Australians, and it reflects benefits which have increased well ahead of cost of living rises. That is the record. These are some of the major initiatives in the social welfare area of the Hawke Labor Government.

The Hawke Government has maintained its commitment to social welfare by preserving the full indexation of pensions against cost of living rises; it has introduced new initiatives, such as the young homeless allowance, to target specially disadvantaged groups in the Australian community; and it has been cracking down on welfare fraud, just as it has been cracking down on tax fraud. Cracking down on welfare fraud will help strengthen the social welfare system in Australia by giving it greater integrity. The measures introduced in the May economic statement will restructure the system of social welfare payments while protecting those Australians in genuine need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate today to speak on the legislation before us to implement the May mini-Budget statement, brought down only three weeks ago. I think it is very important that the people of Australia know what is happening here today. As I said, the Government made a mini-Budget statement just three weeks ago and today we are dealing with a package of six Bills which are necessary to implement that mini-Budget statement. The Bills we are debating were presented to the Senate in a package which included other Bills, known as the media Bills, which went through the Parliament last night. In this debate we are dealing with the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1987, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs Tariff (Commonwealth Authorities) Amendment Bill 1987, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The Manager of Government Business (Senator Gareth Evans) placed this package before the Senate yesterday along, as I said, with the media package of Bills, and various groups of senators had to make up their minds what to do. It is important that we look at how this occurred. The National Party group of senators were obviously unconcerned about this particular mini-Budget package in their rush to get the media package up, on and through to deliver the television services of this country into the hands of media barons. In any case, the past record of National Party senators as part of the former coalition showed that on Budget legislation they would obviously abrogate their responsibility to review and, if necessary, reject or improve legislation coming before the Senate as Budget Bills. The group of Independents in this chamber, however, appeared to fail to understand what the Government was doing in putting together these two packages of Bills, moving to declare them urgent and then having a guillotine or time limit put on those Bills. Senator Georges, Senator Siddons and Senator Vallentine-the Independents-joined the National Party senators in voting with the Government to do just that. The result is that we have six Budget Bills which we have to debate in a period of four hours, with one hour to deal with any amendments which might be moved.

I would like to quote the words used by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he brought down his May statement to illustrate why I think it is important that the people of Australia realise what is happening here. These are not six Bills of little consequence. To quote the Treasurer's May statement, they are Bills which implement:
. . . measures which will reduce next year's prospective Budget deficit by more than $4,000m.
These measures mark the culmination of the most intensive and exhaustive review of Commonwealth programs in living memory.
They involve a massive reordering of Government spending priorities . . .
They build on the process of national economic change which the Government undertook in the Budget last year.

I repeat: These are not inconsequential Bills. Yet only four hours has been provided to discuss them in the second reading debate-courtesy of this Government, which is rushing pell-mell into an early election; courtesy of the National Party here in the Senate, anxious to deliver the media legislation up to Sir Joh and his minions; and courtesy of the Independents who, for whatever reason, decided to join that unholy alliance. Before the expiry of this five hours, which is the total time given for dealing with all of this legislation, the Opposition Liberal Party members will have joined that unholy alliance and, again, will have failed in their responsibility as an Opposition in this place to do anything to review seriously, amend or even reject any of this legislation. It was bad enough in the Budget session of 1986 to see the Opposition coalition, as it was then, take such an irresponsible attitude; now we see this irresponsible attitude on the part of almost the entire Senate-with the exception of the Australian Democrats.

Most of my remarks in this debate will refer to the first of this series of Bills, the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill, which clearly demonstrates-perhaps most clearly of all these Bills-the irrationality and irresponsibility of the process in which we are engaged. This Bill introduces enormous, significant and wide-ranging changes concerning responsibilities, access to information and the Department of Social Security's ability to act. It is causing enormous concern out in the community for a large number of reasons which cannot possibly, in this truncated debate, be properly canvassed. Some of the measures of the mini-Budget as a whole have already been mentioned, and no doubt they will get considerably more airing throughout the debate. These measures in a macro sense, if you like, just as the Treasurer said, have the potential to make a significant impact on the economic direction of this country. Throughout the discussions on this statement we have talked in terms of hundreds of thousands of dollars, billions of dollars and so forth. We have referred to such things as a reduction of $47.5m for recurrent funding in 1988-89 for technical and further education; a reduction in student assistance provided by Austudy of $59m; and the complete abolition of the unemployment benefit for young people under the age of 18. We have heard of figures such as a reduction of $95m in the family allowance and a reduction of $17m in the supporting parent's benefit. The list goes on. These reductions and changes are expressed in terms of millions and millions of dollars. It is true enough that, in a macro sense, they form a major part of the economic direction of this country.

One of the problems with all of this is that these decisions have been made with that overall macro view, and far too little attention has been paid to the impact and effect on individuals at, if you like, the micro level. It is in that area that we believe this sort of legislation needs much more scrutiny, and that the development of this sort of policy direction needs much more scrutiny. It is an area to which the Australian Democrats have drawn, and will continue to draw, the attention of the Government and of policy makers in general. As recently as last Monday night, Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance-who, of course, is a member of the Government committee which made the decisions on these massive changes-expressed some hope that:

. . . we will hear no more of the sanctimonious sermons from Senator Powell about how the Government should have more equity in the taxation and social security systems and should collect more taxes from people who can afford to pay in order to distribute higher social security benefits to those who need them.
I hope that will happen but I do not expect that it will.

I decided to take pity on Senator Walsh today and not deliver another of my, as he calls them, sanctimonious sermons. I am relieved from the need to do that by the fact that just today I received a communication from a constituent from my home State of Victoria who, in fact, does the job very well for me. This person, a female, is in fact a constituent in the electorate of Batman, which happens to be the electorate of the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe. This is not a fancy, typed letter on letterhead with a reference number or anything like that but is hand written on a very inexpensive writing pad, in ink. It is a letter that does what the policy makers and the Government should do far more often, as I have suggested; it looks at the impact, in one area in particular, of the mini-Budget decision and the Bill I am debating at present on a micro, personal, individual level and in a very rational way. I would like to put on the record some of the impacts of that legislation that are drawn to the attention of the Senate not by me but by a constituent of the Minister.

A covering letter pointed out that most of these measures and impacts have not received the publicity following the May statement that a great many other issues in that statement have received. This constituent's concern relates to the abolition of the supporting parent's benefit and the widow's pension for those whose dependants are over the age of 16 years, and the widow's pension class B for widows who are 45 years old or more. She refers to the fact that supporting parent beneficiaries or widow pensioners must now apply for unemployment benefit or must work if they can get it and that the unemployment benefit for 16- to 18-year-olds has gone and that, if the parent is a sole supporting parent, their benefit has gone too. It points out the difficulties for such a family. In relation to a student with a sole supporting parent on a benefit, the student is currently eligible for Austudy at the rate of $40 a week-if there is a 16-year-old at home-but the parent loses the family allowance and the family income supplement, which pays $22 to $30 for a dependent non-student. A student can get $30 a week more if he proves there is a breakdown in the relationship with the family and cannot live at home. This constituent asks: Is the breakdown of families encouraged by this measure?

The job search allowance is presumed to keep 16- to 18-year-olds at home, and the loss of unemployment benefit is presumed to keep 16- to 18-year-olds at school, but for a student with a sole supporting parent, the benefit has gone and there is a drastic reduction in the income. So, this constituent asks: How can students stay at school? A 16-year-old now in year 11 has 1 1/2 years to go to complete year 12. This constituent has made a calculation regarding the family situation-a sole parent with one child-and points out that, if one is on a supporting parent's benefit or a widow's pension, the more income that that parent can earn by working, the more the income increases up to a complete cut out total of $306.40 a week. But in the changed circumstances, a person on unemployment benefit and working part time will increase his income only to a cut out point of $182.20. Therefore, only $50 can be added to the benefit through work; increasing earnings from $70 up to $182.20 gives no increase in income. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table that sets out clearly the disadvantages of the new system as against the advantages in relation to this family, a sole parent with one child.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in this area that the communication points out very clearly the individual impacts and what is considered to be an inbuilt disadvantage system under the new process. One or two of the amendments that I propose to move address some of the specifics of this situation. A point has been made already in this debate about the impacts of, in particular, the loss of the class B widow's pension. One point that has been made to me consistently in this very short period of time- only three weeks since the statement was brought down-in relation to women in that category and also in the sole parent's benefit category is that, while many people can understand that in the long term this may be the sort of reform that can be supported as long as there are inbuilt support mechanisms and long term arrangements for those whose expectations must change, currently there is a lot of talk about retraining and about people going back into the paid work force but women just cannot see where their place is and where they can be retrained. There is a great deal of scepticism about how the system will work at an individual level. In fact, the last sentence of the letter to which I have referred states:

SPEECH.PARA: There are no illusions left about the present government having any care for people.

As I said, there are a number of amendments which, in the normal course of events, had this legislation been before us in the way in which Budget legislation is usually before us and given a reasonable amount of time, the Australian Democrats would have considered. We would have had an opportunity to discuss those amendments with the Government, the Opposition and the departments concerned. As has happened in the past with Budget and other legislation, some improvements and changes could have been made to Government thinking and some support might have been gained perhaps from the Opposition although, as I have said, in relation to Budget legislation, that has become all too rare. In this instance, it has been only about a week since this legislation was passed quickly in the House of Representatives where, of course, the Government has the numbers, and we are now faced with this truncated debate, so it will not be possible for the Australian Democrats to have a proper discussion on the amendments that the Australian Democrats wish to move; they cannot be properly debated and acted upon in any way. However, I want to place on the record some comments about the amendments which we have prepared and which we would want to move in Committee.

There are 19 amendments in this package, their purpose being to address those aspects of this Bill that are seen to be giving too much increased power to the Department of Social Security. In fact, it seems that under this legislation the Department of Social Security will have more powers to act in regard to people with whom it deals than other relevant Government departments have to deal with people involved in tax fraud or even some criminal activities. The first amendment deals with the changes to the legislation relating to benefits for people who are separated but who continue to live under one roof. This is typical of the sort of impact that this legislation is having at the individual and micro level. The Government appears not to understand the circumstances of many families where the marriage might have broken down but where the couple concerned, either for economic reasons or for reasons to do with the welfare of their children, have decided to remain living under one roof. We believe that that amendment is necessary to take account of what is very often a necessary living situation, one which we do not believe has been taken into account sufficiently in the amendments proposed under this legislation. We believe that the 6-month and 12-month rules should be deleted from the legislation.

A further couple of amendments that I wish to move relate to the secrecy provisions in the Bill. We believe that the Secretary should be required to certify that the release of information held by the Department is necessary in individual cases and not in classes of cases. It is of great concern to us that the proposals in this Bill provide for a far too free release of information which certainly should be available only on an individual basis. A further couple of amendments deal with the percentage of people with permanent incapacity caused by medical factors in receipt of the invalid pension. Those aspects of the legislation relating to the invalid pension are not acceptable to us; they do not take account of the realities of the situation for individuals. Our amendments are designed to address that problem. We believe that non-medical factors as well as medical factors need to be taken into account to a further extent than allowed for in this legislation. Further, the removal of access to the invalid pension from those pensioners who are living overseas is a problem. Currently 6,000 invalid pensioners are living overseas. We believe that if they are currently in receipt of that pension they should remain in receipt of it while they satisfy the necessary requirements. There is an element of retrospectivity in the proposals in this legislation, and we have an amendment appropriate to that.

A further couple of amendments deal with the matter of eligibility for the class B widow's pension, and another amendment provides for a relaxed income test for persons who lose the supporting parent's benefit due to the dependent child turning 16. These are our attempts to ameliorate the problems relating to the removal of these benefits under this legislation. It is necessary to be very careful and very compassionate about the transitional provisions that are involved here. We believe that these amendments are necessary in that regard.

A further amendment enables back-payment of the sickness benefit for a period greater than four weeks in special circumstances. The Democrats believe that a number of aspects of this Bill need to be improved by the implementation of a further discretionary power to take account of special circumstances for those people who are working with Department of Social Security clients on a daily basis and at the personal level and who are aware of individual needs. We believe that our amendment regarding the sickness benefit is important to the implementation of that discretionary power.

Other amendments relate to the 13-week waiting period for the unemployment benefit. We can see no merit whatsoever in the extension of that waiting period, particularly as it seems to be somewhat of an anomaly, especially in the case of an unemployed person under 18 years of age, who of course can get the Jobsearch allowance after that period. It seems almost to indicate that for some reason it is considered that $25 a week needs to be paid to encourage and enable young people to seek work, but not until 13 weeks are up. We believe that there is no logic in that approach and that that part of the legislation should be deleted.

There are great concerns in the community about the provisions in the legislation which have to do with debt recovery and the seeking of information on and the determination of penalties for overpayments, and a great many other punitive areas. I will propose a series of amendments to cover these matters. One of the amendments seeks to omit the clause which deals with the recovery of overpayments from third persons. In fact, it seeks to leave in place a section in the current legislation which deals with the recovery of overpayments from financial institutions, including the provision in a sub-section for a limited protection from garnishee orders. There is concern that these measures in the Bill are far too draconian, giving too much power in an area where the rights of individuals have not been taken sufficiently into account. One major problem that has been expressed is that innocent third parties are at risk, and the Democrats have amendments to cover that area as well. We have also proposed an amendment which would allow discretionary power for the payment of unemployment and sickness benefits to persons who are out of Australia on compassionate grounds. We have been made aware of a number of individual cases in that regard. We do not believe that this is a measure that would cost the Government a lot of money, although it is certainly one which, in the interests of compassion, should be taken into account.

I wish to comment briefly on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, as it is part of the package of legislation that we are considering. This Bill gives effect to one of the mini-Budget health care cuts, that is, the reduction to 75 per cent of the schedule fee of the rebate which Medicare will pay towards the cost of treatment for private in-patients in hospitals and the abolition of the $20 maximum patient contribution which has applied. The Australian Democrats were pleased that in the May statement the general rebate of 85 per cent was not lowered, that the levy was not raised again and that no other moves were made which would have fundamentally undermined the Medicare scheme.

However, contrary to the claims of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the mini-Budget package contains changes which threaten the concept of universal health care. While the immediate increase in costs brought about by this Bill will be borne by the private insurance funds, it is no secret that the additional expense will be passed on to consumers through increased premiums. The elasticity of demand for private insurance is a mysterious thing, but it is likely that this, especially in combination with the effects of other mini-Budget changes, will increase the demand on the public system, without the Commonwealth having made any additional money available to the States. People without private insurance who elect to be treated as private patients will now face much bigger costs than they did in the past, but those people really cannot expect as a matter of policy or equity the public system to pay for their private choice.

The Australian Democrats will support this Bill, as we support a health system designed to guarantee health care to all Australians on the basis of their illness rather than on the basis of their income. However, huge problems with Medicare remain, and the mini-Budget moves contain welcome attempts to stop the rot and cost to the system of so-called entrepreneurial medicine. However, it is not enough for government to cut out high-tech diagnostic and treatment services. The money saved must be redirected into positive moves for health promotion and illness prevention. Perhaps some of the reduced cost to revenue could be seen as offsetting all that income in taxes that this Government would have to forfeit if it had the courage to take on the tobacco and alcohol companies and stop the promotion of products which cause enormous morbidity and mortality in the community.

The Democrats object to the mini-Budget illness measures, such as the reduced funding for the Occupational Health and Safety Commission, given Australia's record in preventing work related injury and illness. The Democrats recognise the possible increased costs which are likely to be passed on to patients through the reduced Medicare rebates. However, the role of medical practitioners in setting their own fees is critical, and the community should be aware of the time and labour saving technology available to doctors for many procedures and that, if the medical profession were prepared to accept the financial restraint that has been imposed on others, the hardship faced by our aged and chronically ill as a result of the mini-Budget would be somewhat lessened. We are concerned at the impact on the chronically ill of the decision to reduce the consultant physician's rebate for fourth and subsequent visits. We believe this is an issue which needs considerable attention. Arthritis sufferers, diabetics and sufferers of a number of other chronic illnesses are particularly at risk here, and we would like to see the Government pay some attention to that. In the longer term the Australian Democrats want to see changes in the structure of private health insurance arrangements which will ease the burden on the ill and the funds which support them. In the absence of the sort of overall change in health service direction that we would like to see in Australia we are prepared to support this Bill. I regret the fact that the Senate will not have the time to address duly the issues in these Bills in this debate on significant Budget measures of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating together a group of Bills of which one is the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1987. It is to that Bill that I wish to address my remarks primarily today. The Bill seeks to give effect to two sales tax measures that were announced in the Government's May mini-Budget which, I might remind the Senate, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has now described as the Budget for 1987. That is one of the reasons that he is not terribly concerned about going to an election almost a year ahead of its statutory time, at the most inconvenient possible moment that one could anticipate in terms of a government that might be wishing to seek to have economic management as part of its policies. It is quite obvious that any government that would go to an election when, instead of electioneering, it should be preparing a Budget at one of the more critical times in Australia's economic history simply does not know the meaning of the term `economic responsibility' nor its responsibilities as a government.

SPEECH.PARA: Only one conclusion can be drawn from the fact that we are having such an early election at such an extraordinary time, and that has to be that the Government is running scared, that it is extraordinarily fearful of what it will have to do later in the year and that it quite simply does not have the guts to tell the Australian electorate before it goes to an election what it has in mind for the electorate after the election. The idea that the Prime Minister is putting around, that the May mini-Budget, of which the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill is one measure, could in any way be seen as a responsible Budget for the nation for this year is just so unbelievably stupid that one wonders how the Prime Minister could have expected any Australian to have swallowed such a story.

The May mini-Budget, by definition, was not concerned with the revenue side of the Budget. It was supposed to be concerned with expenditure, but it was not even concerned about expenditure for the year ahead, other than announcing some phoney, shonky cuts off some very dubious forward Estimates. We still do not know the Government's spending program for 1987-88. We know nothing at all about its revenue program. We therefore know nothing at all about its borrowing requirement for the year ahead. We therefore know nothing about the deficit that the nation will be facing. The one thing of which we can be certain is that it will pile still further debt on top of the $105 billion of foreign debt that this nation has already stacked up-almost three-quarters of that during the four years of this Government. Nor do we know how much additional debt will be stacked on to the Government's accumulated national debt of well over $100 billion-over 35 per cent of the total gross domestic product of this country.

Indeed, in the mini-Budget the Government claimed that it was chopping $4 billion off government spending in the year ahead. That was a deliberate distortion of the truth of the situation. Of the $4 billion, almost $500m constitutes not expenditure cuts but tax increases. Most of those tax increases will flow from the Bill that the Senate has before it for debate at the moment. I might point out in passing that, of the $4 billion, another $1 billion was related to the Government's proposal to sell assets. There is nothing further removed from cutting government spending than selling government assets. They are two totally different sides of the coin, yet the Government has tried to mislead deliberately the Australian people so that $1 billion worth of assets sales, which will not be achieved anyway on the Government's record, somehow or other, by a flick of the magic wand that the Prime Minister is so prone to wave in front of the public, will be seen to be $1 billion of expenditure cuts. What absolute nonsense!

The Bill before the Senate gives effect to two sales tax measures announced in the mini-Budget, and collectively these two measures are designed to raise about $420m in a full year. The two measures are: Firstly, the removal of the present sales tax exemption for certain Commonwealth Government commercial authorities and, secondly, an alteration to the sales tax concessions that are available to passengers and crew members of ships and aircraft arriving in Australia.

So far as the first of these two measures is concerned-the removal of the sales tax exemption for certain Commonwealth commercial authorities-the Bill lists, I think, 29 Commonwealth authorities which are not to be exempt from sales tax. Only seven of these are regarded as being able to make use of the exemption. Of those seven the two most important ones by far are Telecom Australia and Australia Post. The effect of the Bill in this area is to make Commonwealth authorities, such as Telecom and Australia Post in particular, no longer exempt from sales tax on their purchases of sales taxable items and to make them subject to the normal sales tax provisions as though they were privately owned operations.

This measure adds yet another tax to the enormous litany of new taxes that the Hawke Government has introduced since it was elected in 1983. Indeed, if one looks at the amount of tax legislation that has been passed into law since the Government came into operation in 1983, one finds a staggering 800-plus pages of new tax law. That means that in the last four years alone, the Hawke Government has added 70 per cent of new tax legislation to what we had had in the accumulated history of the Commonwealth up to 1983, a period of 82 years or so. The tax law of this country has not far short of doubled in the four years in which the Hawke Government has been in office.

It is very salutary, because we often forgot some of these things, to look at the new taxes that have been introduced since this Government took office. I will run through some of the main ones. It is not a fully inclusive list, but it included, in July 1983, four months or so after the Government was elected, the introduction of lump sum superannuation tax. All of those people who were subject to lump sum superannuation tax as a result of that measure remember full well the written promise by the then relevant shadow Minister prior to the 1983 election-John Dawkins-who, in writing, assured people potentially affected by such a new tax that there would be no such tax. A month later, in August 1983, we saw introduced the automatic bi-annual indexation of traditional excises, on beer, cigarettes and petroleum. This means-I will tell people in case they have forgotten-that each six months the tax on those products goes up without the matter coming before the Parliament, because the Hawke Government's automatic indexation applies each six months regardless of the wishes of the Parliament and without being made known to the Australian public.

In February 1984 the one per cent Medicare levy was introduced. I remind the Senate that immediately prior to the last Federal election the Government gave a solemn promise that in the life of this Parliament the Medicare levy of one per cent would not be increased. What happened? Within 18 months of that promise being made it was broken massively, with a 25 per cent increase in the levy. In July 1984 a resource rent tax and an excise on new oil were introduced. In August 1984 a 10 per cent tax on wine was imposed, another massively broken promise. In July 1985 the concessional expenditure rebate and negative gearing provisions were abolished and the Medicare levy limit was removed. In September 1985 entertainment expenditure was disallowed and a capital gains tax was introduced. We all remember what the Prime Minister said during his election campaign about a capital gains tax. He said: `Let no one in Australia be mistaken; there will be no capital gains tax'. Within months we had a capital gains tax.

In July 1986 the fringe benefits tax and the bureaucratic substantiation provisions were introduced. In August 1986 new sales taxes were introduced and wine tax went up to 20 per cent. There was a large increase in the excise on petrol. As I said earlier, in December 1986 the Medicare levy was increased to 1.25 per cent. In July 1987 the corporate tax rate was increased from 46 per cent to 49 per cent and the foreign tax credit system was introduced. Those are just some of the new taxes that this Government has introduced in four short years. They do not cover at all the increase in the tax take from taxes that had previously existed. In four short years this Government has far and away outstripped anything we have ever known in terms of the capacity of a government to rip taxes off the Australian public to the extent that Federal Government taxes alone, let alone State or local government taxes, constitute more than a quarter of the total gross domestic product of this nation.

The proposal in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill is yet another instance of this litany of new taxes. I would like to deal separately with the two elements of the Bill. The first is, as I have said, the removal of the sales tax exemption for Telecom Australia, Australia Post and one or two other Commonwealth commercial authorities. In total, approximately seven will be affected. The first thing to be said about this measure is that it will increase Commonwealth coffers by another $400m per year. The automatic effect is that the cost will be passed on to the people, because the only way that authorities such as Telecom, despite very impressive increases in their productivity record over recent years, can handle such additional imposts is to raise their prices. That, of course, feeds into the general inflationary spiral in this country. This will happen at a time when, as a result of the policies of this Government, Australia now has an inflation rate which is four or five times higher than the inflation rate of the rest of the Western world. Day by day that figure is making Australia increasingly uncompetitive.

The one thing we must do in this country today, if we are to survive in an increasingly competitive world, is get ourselves in a more competitive and more productive situation. We cannot do that if more and more government taxes and charges feed into the cost system of this nation. That is precisely what is happening with this measure; it is precisely what has happened constantly over the last four years. This does not apply just to Federal Government taxes and charges but also, and equally important in many ways, this measure will increase taxes and charges of Labor State governments around this country. So the measure will increase inflation, and it will also have a very considerable effect on Telecom. I will read some extracts from a very important speech that the Chairman of Telecom, Mr Bob Brack, made in Adelaide on 25 May 1987, just a couple of weeks ago. I will quote only parts of his speech, but he pointed out:

Telecom Australia is rated in the top ten of the world's telecommunications networks. Since it was set up in 1975 it has expanded the network by 75 per cent and increased customer penetrations from just over 60 per cent to more than 90 per cent of homes. It has done this with about 3 per cent growth in staff numbers.
Commenting on the mini-Budget, Mr Brack stated:
The Government's further demands on Telecom in the recent May Statement represent a watershed in our development. Not only is Telecom required to repay $81 million of Government loans-
that is another impost on Telecom which is not part of this Bill-

but it is to pay sales tax and customs duty with an estimated impact of some $400 million in a full year. As you know, Telecom has announced that it will need to increase prices significantly, cut its orders of Australian industry and reduce its staff numbers to meet the financial demands of the May Statement.
Mr Brack continued:

The pressure from Telecom's competitors in actions under the Trade Practices Act to force deregulation of customer premises equipment, the first phone and PABX maintenance, will undoubtedly lead to a considerable expansion of the proportion of the business under active competition.

It is now imperative, in order to level the competitive playing field, that the many Government controls on Telecom to which our competitors are not subject, be removed. Only then can Telecom adequately respond to the competitive challenge and the commercial expectations. Telecom's viability as an enterprise and hence its value to its owners, all Australians, is at stake.

Mr Brack was referring to two things: Firstly, the impost of the May statement and, secondly, the restrictions that are imposed on Telecom by virtue of the fact that it is a government owned enterprise. In commenting on the impact on Telecom of the May measures Mr Brack said, as I just mentioned, that amongst other things it will be forced to cut its orders to Australian industry. Elsewhere in his speech he comments on how much Australian industry participation there is in Telecom's activities. He states:

Telecom is a strong supporter of Australian manufacturers and equipment suppliers. This financial year Telecom is responsible for contracts with the private sector in excess of $2000 million. Some 90 per cent of telecommunications materials and equipment purchased by Telecom is obtained from Australian suppliers, achieving around 70 per cent local content on major contracts. Telecom's purchases account for three quarters of the total output of the Australian Telecommunications Manufacturing Industry.

So what does this Government-this Government that tells the Australian people that it is interested in the development of Australian manufacturing industry and will assist it to become more viable and competitive-do? It imposes a cost on Telecom that will lead it to make a major cutback in its requirements from Australian manufacturing industry. Also, this Bill and other measures will impose restrictions on Telecom that will put it at a disadvantage compared with what would happen if it were free of some of the government-imposed shackles.

Let me name some of them, as the Auditor-General of the Commonwealth, Mr John Monaghan, has recently made public. He referred to ambiguity and inconsistency in specification of competing commercial and social objectives of Telecom; restrictive scope for financing investment; remuneration packages for senior staff that are not competitive with the private sector; legislative or policy requirements to maintain uneconomic services; entrenched inefficient work practices and difficult industrial relations in areas where political sensitivities hinder effective remedial action. That is a damning indictment of a government which claims that it has fostered beneficial industrial relations. But one sees from a comparison of this Government's industrial relations record with the record of the Prime Minister when he led the Australian Council of Trade Unions that this Government has hardened the divisions and difficulties in industrial relations. In six weeks' time the incoming Liberal Government will put that item at the top of its agenda to enable Australia to get back to a sensible, workable and profitable for all parties industrial relations system. Those are some of the restrictions faced by Telecom. At such a time it is unbelievable that the Government should seek to impose an additional burden of this nature on that corporation and on other Government business enterprises.

The second aspect of the Bill which will alter the sales tax concessions available to passengers and crew members of ships and aircraft arriving in Australia is equally ludicrous. The proposal will bring in only about $20m in a full year, but its impact on a wide range of small business will be significant indeed. The existing customs and sales tax laws exempted from duty goods arriving with the traveller from overseas that were for personal use. These included limited quantities of tobacco and alcohol, goods to the value of $200, personal effects and goods that were otherwise duty free or dutiable at 2 per cent. In addition, a concessional duty of 20 per cent was allowed on other goods to a value of $160. In addition, migrants settling in Australia were allowed free entry for motor vehicles. This Bill will abolish the concession for migrants' motor vehicles and replace the existing passenger concessions with an across the board free entry allowance of $400, $200 for persons under the age of 18, although it will retain the existing quantity restrictions on tobacco and alcohol.

The $400 limit is likely to have a significant impact on the Australian duty free industry and will cause some significant problems in other areas as well. For a start, it will cause turmoil at the customs barrier points at major airports in Australia, in particular at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, but not just at that airport. The Government is going ahead like a bull at a gate with this new proposal in advance of giving any consideration to automatic duty collection machines being installed, as has been suggested by the Australian Tourism Association. There is no doubt that congestion at the major airports will be monumental. It will have a detrimental effect on the tourism industry. Most tourists come to Australia by air and the ease of getting through the sheer mechanics of entry into a country at airports is important in creating an environment that is conducive to tourists. Therefore, by cluttering up the whole system these provisions will have a detrimental effect on tourism at a time when that industry is being promoted, and rightly so, by the Government as one of the major planks that we need to develop to correct the horrendous balance of payments problem which has accumulated inexorably over the four years in office of this Hawke Government to the stage where this country's foreign debt has increased from less than $28 billion to a figure that is now well in excess of $100 billion. To bring that figure down to understandable terms, that is a foreign debt facing every Australian family equivalent to $26,000-an almost fourfold increase in four years. It took this country 83 years to accumulate a debt of $28 billion. It has taken four years for that debt to go from that sum of $28 billion to $105 billion. With this measure, which will introduce a paltry $21m, this foolhardy Government will put the tourist industry under strain and at risk.

It is not just the tourist industry that will be affected. Many other industries rely on sensible and proper procedures for entry to Australia. For example, there is the area of Australian duty free operations. The Australian Duty Free Operators Association has made representations to the Government and to others, including me, expressing extreme concern at the effects that the new system of Australian passenger concessions will have on the industry. It points to the chaos that will be caused at airports. It also points out that the problems of cost in terms of supervision and control over the entry into Australia of narcotics and quarantinable products will greatly increase.

The Government's decision follows an Industries Assistance Commission report and investigation into this area carried out as recently as November 1985. In that report the IAC made several sensible recommendations, which the Government has neglected to take up. It has not only rejected the recommendations of the IAC but the recommendations of the Australian Customs Service. In view of the growth of tourism into Australia and the number of Australian tourists who go overseas, no-one would suggest that something did not need to be done about duty free concessions. The Opposition believes that the worst possible way in which that problem could have been tackled is the way in which this Government has gone about the matter. We believe that the Government should withdraw this proposal and take another look at the matter to see whether it can find other ways of saving $21m. It should be cutting another $21m out of its bloated expenditure so that this measure would not be necessary in any event. Senator Puplick, on behalf of the Opposition, will be moving amendments to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill and other Bills in this package. I foreshadow those amendments as those items relate to various matters touching this Bill. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill because it is a Budget measure, but we feel that it is a stupid Bill and that the Government should re-examine its contents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —A test of any society is its treatment of the deprived-those who are sick, the unemployed and the injured. In this country we pride ourselves on having a compassionate society, a kindly and caring community which provides hospitals, community services and pensions. The Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1987, the first in the package we are discussing, deals with that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We have just heard the usual competent and direct speech from Senator Short, the shadow Minister for Finance, whom I know personally to be a man of compassion. However, because he is a member of a `dry' shadow Cabinet, he was unable to speak in a compassionate way on these Bills. The Opposition's interest in these Bills is on the techniques of taxation. The compassion which shines forth from this side of the chamber, our great and compassionate heart, does not appear on the Opposition benches. Senator Short, whom I know personally has a great capacity for mercy and compassion, is unable to let that shine through because of the Opposition's approach to this matter. Indeed, when we have before us Bills dealing with sales tax laws, customs and excise, tariff legislation, health legislation, social security and veterans' entitlements, he is compelled to deal with such measures by considering only the hard, dry economics of the matter.

It is interesting that Senator Short should berate this Government for increasing the range of taxes in the community. Of course, that is true. Under this Government there has been an increase in the range of taxation imposed upon members of the community, but it has been imposed on those who are better able to bear that taxation than those who formerly bore it. For years the wage earner who gets his or her envelope at the end of each week has had taken from that envelope a considerable sum of money, and part of that money has subsidised those who were not paying their fair share. Senator Short spoke about the increase in the rate of sales tax on cars. That is correct; the sales tax on luxury cars-and I emphasise the word `luxury'-has increased from a standard 20 per cent to a standard 30 per cent. It is the Government's proposition that those who are best able to bear the cost of running the community must do so. That is what expenditure and tax are all about. The tax that the Government levies is directed towards providing money for all that we need-roads, defence forces and the capacity to live as a community. Those things must be paid for. The proposition that is put forward from this side of the chamber-and it is a fair proposition-is that those who are able to pay and who make use of the services of the community should pay. For that reason, this Government introduced a capital gains tax with the exemption of the family home. This tax enables the Government to collect revenue from an area which people with any sense of fairness would say should have been taxed long ago. Such taxes are taken in comparable countries, such as the United States of America and the United Kingdom and in Europe.

On the other hand, this Government has increased the tax-free threshold to $5,100, which means that people who are on pensions and low incomes and who would otherwise have to pay tax do not need to do so now until they have earned $5,100. This Government has done these things. When Senator Short criticises this Government's taxation policy he is criticising one of the most radical and one of the fairest reforms ever introduced in this country. That should be remembered. It ill-behoves anyone to criticise a government which has undertaken an exercise in equity, in fairness and in making sure that those who enjoy the fruits of this community pay according to their ability so that we can all go forward as a nation.

This Government has devoted much attention to getting the economic balance right. This balance has been hard to establish, given the massive fall in the prices that we have been able to obtain for our goods overseas. We have always sold commodity goods overseas-wheat, wool and the products of mining. Those products have served Australia well over the years and will continue to do so, but they now need to be supplemented by income earned overseas from value added goods, manufactured goods. That is what we must turn our minds to. We do not have manufactured goods of the quantity and quality required to win overseas markets because of the history of this country. When the Opposition criticises this Government it should remember that the industrial structure of Australia as it now operates was set up by the coalition in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. This Government has had to wrestle with that massive problem and it has done so very well indeed.

The Opposition has done what anyone could do-it has come along and criticised those aspects of the Government's administration which, when looked at on their own, do not perform as well as they might. But one cannot look at a particular country's history in terms of one, two or three years. One must look at it in terms of the many years that have gone to produce the present situation-those many years in which the coalition unfortunately so ordered and administered the country that it produced the present problems. This Government has massively changed that situation and it is now proceeding to bring the country to the state which it deserves, given its many resources and the great determination of its people.

In this context, Senator Short talks about industrial relations. It is now recognised by all those who approach this matter fairly, whether they be unionists, business people, members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions or members of the Confederation of Australian Industry, that the accord which has been developed through the ACTU has served this country mightily. I see Senator Cook and Senator McIntosh in the chamber. They played a part in this area. It is a matter of sadness that the Opposition has indicated that when it gets into government-and that will be a long way down the line-its industrial and economic processes will be based on conflict and aggravation, so that people will be driven to desperation, instead of on maintaining the present position in which management and employees go forward together. The Opposition will take an adversary approach, one of conflict, bitter fighting and dispute, which will not serve this country well at all. That approach came from the admirable Senator Short who has compassion and insight but, because of his Party's policy, has to intone in this chamber today that plan for conflict in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very sad.

—It is very sad indeed. Very much more in sorrow than in anger we must point out the unfortunate steps being taken. It is not yet too late for those opposite to turn back and realise the dreadful leap into the dark they are taking. There are men and women of good will on the other side. If they really think about it and look at the great achievements the accord has brought this country their position will change. The other thing that Senator Short has done is criticise the Government, saying that it has not brought down a Budget this year and that it will go to an election before doing so. He also says that it will be an early election. By the time this election comes on it will be two years and seven months since the last election. If that is early, what was it that Prime Minister Fraser visited on this country when he called elections? The time since the last election is well within what is reasonable. It has been called, no doubt, at a time that is propitious for the Government, and what is wrong with that? The Government chooses a time when it is apparent to the public that the Government's policies are working on the basis of a unified team ready and willing to go forward, a team that is well ranked behind the leaders. Senator Short says: `What will be in the Government's Budget?'. Clearly it will be a responsible Budget and at least we can promise a Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the tax policy? I am not talking about the tax policy that will come from this side of the House because people know what our tax policy is; and that is, that from 1 July this year there will be reductions in taxation across the board so that nobody has to pay more than 49c in the dollar. Senator Short says that companies have to pay 49c. That is the top rate that they have to pay. If they earn the money that attracts that rate, why should they not contribute to the community in which they operate and have been given prosperity, and a community which looks to them for some contribution towards proper functioning?
