But the fact is that there are just no taxation policies at all from the other side. Obviously, those opposite are still working them out. Would it not have been proper for them to have brought their taxation policies into the Parliament before it rose so that they could be debated? Our programs have been before the Parliament for years. We have brought in the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and so on. They have been debated.

Why is the Opposition so reluctant to open up to the glare of the public, six weeks before the election, its tax policies? Why does it wait for the election mode to come upon us so that the tumult and shouting may disguise the many errors that no doubt will be in its policy? No doubt there will be great errors in its policy because any policy that is produced has to be tested and its difficulties have to be pointed out. No opportunity has been afforded to apply that test to the Opposition's tax policy. Maybe the tax policy can be produced on Monday because it will never be brought into operation. The Opposition may think: `We will bring in the tax policy on Monday, put it before the public, give it the razzamatazz half time talk and hope something will happen. But in our heart of hearts we know that it will never be tested because we will not be in government to put it to the test'. That is probably the situation that pertains. If not, why have we not been blessed with some sort of hint of the taxation policy? At times there has been a hint that there will be a broadly-based consumption tax, which immediately would raise the level of inflation and put this country into the rocky situation it was in before the present Government came into being to sort things out a little.

I will return to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. This Government, I hope and trust, during its struggle to bring economic sanity to this country has not forgotten those people who are most in need. One of the problems when we talk about social security is that there is a temptation to tell little anecdotes about how people have rorted and ripped off the system. If people rort or rip off the system they deserve what they get. But it would be wrong for this country and for us to attribute what is properly attributable to those who rort the system to those who are genuinely in need. Vast numbers of people-too many, and this Government is intent upon reducing the numbers-are in need. It is wrong for the community to attribute to them the sorts of opprobrium and criticism that are properly due to those who rort the system. The reality is that in the community there are the poor, the unemployed and those who through injury at work and elsewhere are not able to work in the way they used to, to go to the shops or into offices and do a day's work-which by and large is the ambition of most people in the community.

As this election campaign we are about to go into proceeds I certainly hope, from the Government side of the Parliament, that that compassion which must be held for those sorts of people becomes apparent. It is interesting in that context to see just what this Government has done while it has been in office. At times an impression is given that all the Government and the Opposition talk about in Parliament is macro-economic policies, balances of payments, interest rates, the value of the dollar and so on. So the picture is given that the whole of Parliament is consumed simply with looking at those things. But the reality is that under this Government pensions have risen. People, although still in straitened circumstances at times, have gained greatly over what was the previous situation. Perhaps some examples may be helpful. There has been an increase in the rate of the single unemployment benefit by 62 per cent between April 1983 and June 1987 for persons aged 21 years and over without dependants.

Limits on extra income for unemployment and sickness benefit recipients have gone up by $10 to $30 a week before part benefits are payable. There has been a doubling of the mother's or guardian's allowance for single parent families receiving social welfare assistance, going from $6 to $12 a week. Extra income limits for pensioners with dependent children are to be doubled from $6 to $12 per child from July 1987. There has also been the job start allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds which is directed to encouraging people to get work. It was pointed out in debate earlier today that not enough work is around. Under this Government a massive number of jobs, 750,000, have been created. Although more jobs need to be created, the Government takes the approach that a person should be fitted to the job and that education, apprenticeships and training should be the order of the day. In that context Austudy is to increase by up to 33 per cent, effective from 1988.

This Government has bent its intent towards helping those desperately in need. It is reversing the situation which obtained in the Fraser-Howard years. The impact of the initiatives taken so far by the Labor Government has been to increase the real disposable income of people on social security by up to 20 per cent since it came to office. The Government is reversing, not worsening, the situation under the previous Government. This Government has a proud record in the social security area. Hopefully, it will be able to do more when it is returned to office in July. Certainly it is the intention of the Government to give those who are genuinely in need, those who are entitled to pensions, those who deserve the sympathy, gentleness and compassion of this society, what they need.

That will not be done if we go into a mode, as suggested by honourable senators opposite, of coming down hard on recipients, of making those least able to do so pay for the necessary adjustments that must be made in the community. This Government is about making those necessary adjustments in terms of equity, about requiring those who are able to contribute to do so according to their means and about giving help to those who deserve help because of their misfortune. This Government has done that by creating jobs-well above the 500,000 jobs it promised-by training people for the jobs that become available, by distributing tax fairly across the community, by managing the economy and the country in the way it has and by approaching industrial relations in a way which will lead to the production of goods that are more suitable for export than they are now. In all those ways the Government is trying to bring about the just, gentle and compassionate society we all so desperately seek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it today a package of Bills which derive from the Government's economic statement brought down on 13 May. These Bills include two welfare Bills, the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill and three tax and customs measures, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff (Commonwealth Authorities) Amendment Bill. Senator Cooney in his opening remarks sought to draw attention to the social impact this Government has had and to present himself, his Government and his ministerial colleagues as essentially caring people full of heart. He said that the test of a good society was what it did for the sick, the unemployed and the injured.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I do not intend to dwell at length upon the social welfare aspects of this package of legislation, I do, however, intend to make just a couple of remarks about what indeed the Australian Labor Party has done for the sick, the unemployed and the injured, both in this Commonwealth Parliament and in New South Wales. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be particularly familiar with what the Labor Government has been doing to the workers in that State. As far as the sick are concerned, this Government has an extraordinary record in terms of the number of people it has put on the queues waiting for services in the hospital system and in terms of the extent to which it has depressed the quality of medical care available in the community while increasing its cost. In terms of what it has done for the unemployed, it has a record which the Young Labor Association has denounced and would constantly have the Government try to conceal. It has fiddled the jobless figures by withdrawing unemployment benefits from particular classes of young people and transferring people to bogus make-work schemes and has brought about a situation in which 20,000 young Australians are seeking places in higher education that they will not get as a result of this Government's policies.

In terms of the injured, Senator Cooney is a member of a political party which, in New South Wales, is in the process of destroying the rights of injured workers to seek redress under common law for compensation for their injuries. Senator Cooney no longer has a direct interest in this matter but I am sure that if he had continued to be a practitioner in this field he would have been outraged, as most civil libertarians and people of real social concern and conscience in New South Wales are outraged, by what the State Labor Government has been doing to the rights of injured workers.

Senator Cooney talked about the value of taxation reform, bearing in mind that the July tax cuts, so-called, will not provide real taxation benefits for the majority of the work force and, in particular, will exclude well in excess of 70 per cent of the female members of the work force from any direct benefit. Attempts have been made to portray this Government as a government of social concern and compassion. As we know, Senator Cooney is a person of great social concern and compassion, of great heart and great warmth. Unfortunately, like people on both sides of the Parliament who like to think of themselves in that light, it is evident that Senator Cooney has as little success in persuading his colleagues to adopt some of those policies as is manifestly the case with other people around the place.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the senator with the warm inner glow, though.

—Senator Cooney is indeed the senator with not only the warm inner glow but also the warm outer glow, from our observations. Nevertheless, that is not quite good enough. I, however, wish to address my remarks to the three customs and sales tax Bills. The primary Bill, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, makes arrangements for the payment of customs duties by Commonwealth authorities, for the imposition of a $200 fee on an application for a refund of customs duty-I know Senator Cooney will be absolutely outraged that people will have to pay enormous sums of money to have their rights protected-and makes a new arrangement for strengthening the operation of the diesel fuel duty rebate system. The Customs Tariff (Commonwealth Authorities) Amendment Bill touches particularly on the position of Telecom Australia and Australia Post as far as the impact of sales tax and customs duties legislation is concerned. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1987 deals with a number of matters, including the attempt to destroy the duty free industry in Australia. In relation to the motion for the second reading of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, on behalf of the Opposition I formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:

(1) notes with concern the Government's measures to introduce further imposts at a time when the business community and the general public are already suffering under excessive government taxes and charges;

(2) condemns the Government for the adverse impact on families, business and the farm sector of the increases in telephone and postal charges which will result from the withdrawal of the customs and sales tax exemptions for Telecom and Australia Post;
(3) deplores the Government's decision to introduce a $200 processing charge for applications for a refund of duty, and
(4) expresses its concern at the proposed imposition of severe restrictions on the duty-free concessions available to passengers entering Australia which-
(a) is contrary to the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations contained in report No. 374 of 1965; and

(b) will result in further inconvenience to international travellers to Australia, divert attention of customs officers away from essential narcotics surveillance activities, impact adversely on the duty-free industry in Australia, and damage the tourism industry generally''.

This amendment seeks to add certain words at the end of the motion because, as Senator Short mentioned, it is a series of budgetary and financial measures and we do not propose to oppose the legislation, but nevertheless we have moved this amendment which is in four parts. In relation to paragraph (3), during the Committee stage we will move amendments to specific parts of the legislation referred to.

I turn now to several of those individual items. The first matter of significance deals with the impact that this package of Bills will have in imposing additional costs on people as a result of the increases in telephone and postal charges that will result as a direct consequence of the withdrawal of the customs and sales tax exemptions from Telecom and Australia Post. On 14 May, the day after the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Telecom issued a Press released headed `Telecom hit in Treasurer's economic statement'. The release was issued on behalf of Mr Bob Brack, the Chairman of Telecom, and in part it stated:

Telecom had advised Government that the local call fee must increase by 3c, with increases in STD rates as well. Rental charges and connection fees will also have to increase substantially. Unless these tariffs are approved by 30 June, higher increases will be necessary. Telecom is also examining the connection fees associated with high cost services which are currently provided at subsidised rates. Telecom can no longer afford to carry the extent of the subsidy it has in the past.

Telecom announced that it would have to react to the increased imposts placed upon it by introducing increased charges in local and subscriber trunk dialling telephone calls. It announced also that it would deal with rental charges, with connection fees and with the policy of cross-subsidisation. Australia Post has announced that it must look at an increase of at least 1c in the cost of posting a standard letter. These are direct consequences of the Government's decisions now provided for in this package of Bills. We condemn the Government for seeking to use these statutory authorities in order to pass the costs on to Australian consumers in an arm's length fashion, that is to say, by trying to blame Telecom and Australia Post for taking the sort of steps that they have to take in order to respond to the burden now placed upon them by the Treasurer's statement. I mention this not just in terms of those imposts, but also I refer to a speech delivered in Adelaide on Monday 25 May by Mr Brack, the Chairman of the Australian Telecommunications Commission, in which he stated:

The Government's further demands on Telecom in the recent May statement represent a watershed in our development. Not only is Telecom required to repay $81m of Government loans, but it is to pay sales tax and customs duty with an estimated impact of some $400m in a full year. As you know, Telecom has announced that it will need to increase prices significantly, cut its orders of Australian industry and reduce its staff numbers to meet the financial demands of the May statement.

At the same time Senator Cooney tells us that this Government is concerned about the revival of the Australian manufacturing industry and that it is concerned about increasing the number of jobs available in Australia but, according to the Chairman of Telecom, the direct consequences of the May economic statement on Telecom are that it will require an increase in the taxation burden on individuals, produced indirectly; it will reduce the extent to which Australian manufacturing industry will be able to benefit from Telecom orders; and it will lead to a reduction in employment by Telecom, which is one of the major employers of labour in Australia. Even if one looks, as Senator Cooney has sought to look, at the social implications of this package of legislation and relates those not only to the welfare measures herein contained, but also to the taxation, customs and excise matters that are contained in the package, it can be seen that the impact on Australian society as a whole will be quite adverse.

I turn now to the next part of the Opposition's second reading amendment which deals with the introduction of a $200 processing charge for applications for a refund of customs duty. As I have indicated, when we get to the Committee stage of this debate the Opposition will move an amendment to that part of the legislation and, in particular, it will move an amendment to clause 7, proposed sub-section 163 (1d), which deals with this matter. The $200 fee is part of the overall policy that this Government has put in place of discouraging Australians from seeking proper redress against the bureaucracy and against the Government when they feel that they have been adversely affected. The chamber will recall that the first step in this process was dealt with as a consequence of last year's Budget, and there was a massive assault on the Freedom of Information Act by way of increased charges under that Act. During its current inquiry into the three-year operation of the Freedom of Information Act, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has had evidence presented to it that these charges have resulted in a lower rate of public usage of the Act. Of course, that was the intention of the Government when it introduced these charges. The chamber will recall that a second step in this process was to impose a fee, I think $200 on that occasion also, for people to have their taxation assessments reviewed not by the taxation boards of review but by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Again, as a result of the imposition of a very substantial fee, people would be discouraged from seeking redress and having their taxation assessments looked at. I think that the fee rose from a nominal $2 which had to be lodged with the taxation boards of review, to a fee of $200. There has been an attempt to emasculate the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to discourage people from seeking the judicial review of administrative decisions to which they are entitled. There is now an imposition of a $200 fee for people who seek a refund of customs duty which may have been improperly imposed upon them. As Mr John Moore, the shadow Minister, said in the House of Representatives in the debate on 27 May:

Clause 7 of the Bill contains the supposed cost recovery provisions, which impose a charge of $200 upon the processing of applications for a refund of customs duty. The Australian Customs Service receives thousands of refund applications yearly. The necessity for the refund system arises as a result of an overestimation on the part of customs agents of customs duty payable.

He went on to indicate that there are a number of reasons why customs refunds are repayable and that some of them resulted from error on the part of Customs officers. That is to say, from time to time, errors are made. Goods can be improperly classified under one tariff item when in fact they should be classified under another and a duty is imposed. Normally there would be a process whereby people could challenge a particular arrangement and whereby, if a person is entitled to a refund of duty, then such a refund is paid. There could be instances in which people wish to query valuations. For instance, often the case arises of unsolicited gifts being sent from overseas to people in Australia. These presents are given a particular classification and people are charged duty on that basis and there is a process whereby they may seek some refund of the duty. We in the Opposition take the view very clearly that if an error has been committed on the part of the bureaucracy, it should not fall upon the taxpayer to have to pay a fee to have the decision reviewed. When we come to our specific amendments to clause 7 of the legislation we will deal with that matter in a little more detail.

The third part of the Opposition amendment relating to an item in this package to which I wish to turn is the imposition of savage cuts on the Australian duty free industry. On 6 November 1985, the Industries Assistance Commission, in its report on passenger concessions, examined this matter in very great detail. Honourable senators will recall that it made a series of recommendations, one of which was a recommendation against the introduction of a system of inward duty free shopping. In line with the recommendation of the IAC, that proposal was opposed by the Opposition. Nevertheless, the Government, as the first part of its assault upon the private sector operators who have made the duty free industry in Australia as successful as it is, went ahead and forced the introduction of inward duty free shopping with the support of the majority of the Australian Democrats. But the recommendation of the IAC inquiry was in fact that there should be a $1,000 limit. The IAC said that for persons resident overseas entering Australia for a period of six months or less there should be a series of concessions available. It said that for persons ordinarily resident in Australia the re-importation of goods under certain conditions should be allowed, and that goods in accompanied baggage-that is, what people bring back in to the country, essentially duty free-to the value of $1,000 for adults and $500 for persons under 18 should be permitted. I was a participant in the inquiry before the IAC. In fact I appeared before it. One of the things that struck me was the vehemence with which the Federal Treasury argued for the total scrapping of the duty free concessions. Its submissions to the inquiry and its presentations, both on the draft report and as a result of the final report, were in fact that the concessions should be eliminated, that the duty free industry should be wiped out in Australia. It did not succeed in persuading the IAC to that point of view. The Commission recommended the $1,000 limit. But Treasury is known, I suppose, around the place for its persistence in these matters, and one can see the hand of Treasury getting into the duty free industry in its recommendation of the reduction from $1,000 to $400.

This has come as a particularly savage impost, particularly as it has come virtually out of the blue to an industry which thought that, on the basis of the IAC inquiry, it was able to undertake some long term planning about its future and about investment. This measure, of course, impacts with enormous ferocity upon the 65,000 Australian tourists who are currently estimated to be overseas at the moment and who may be especially disadvantaged when they return to Australia. If they return after 1 July in the belief that they are entitled-as, indeed, they were when they left Australia-to a concession of a certain level they may find that, having acted in good faith, a decision was made while they were overseas which means that they are to be savagely attacked on their return in terms of the value of the duty free concession. They will get hit twice if they seek some relief from the impact of the customs duty imposed upon them on the basis of natural justice. Presumably they would run into the $200 fee, which is elsewhere provided for in this legislation, if they try to defend their rights. It is perhaps typical of the cavalier attitude which this Government takes towards the rights of individuals.

The shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, in the debate in the House of Representatives on 26 May 1987, described this particular piece of legislation as a `monumental stupidity'. He indicated that the Treasurer wanted to bring in an extra $20m or $21m in the following year in revenue by abolishing or reducing duty free concessions for travellers. But, as we have clearly indicated in our amendment, the impact of this measure not only will be unfair upon the traveller but also will impose an enormous additional burden upon the already strained resources of the Australian Customs Service. Instead of paying primary attention to the prevention of the importation of narcotics and catching the people involved in that awful trade, and the other areas for which it is responsible, it will now be turned into a revenue collector. Our airports, of course, will be choked and crowded. The IAC report drew particular attention to the difficulties already being experienced by the management of the barrier services. In section 7 of its 1985 report it drew attention to the congestion, to the difficulties and to the management problems involved. It referred to long delays, queues, aggravation, a poor image for the Australian tourist industry, and frustration which, of course, is already apparent at Australia's airports because of our time scheduling problems and because of the simultaneous arrival in Australia of a large number of international flights in a fairly short period, particularly early in the mornings, at airports such as Kingsford-Smith Airport. All of those problems will be enormously added to by this new impost which the Government has decided to place upon the industry.

Let us look at the Press reports. The Sun-Herald of 24 May 1985 contained an article headed `$400 limit for travellers dismays duty free trade'. In that article a number of people in the consumer electronics area, the camera area and the jewellery area expressed their dismay at this particular decision. The Daily Telegraph of 19 May contained an article headed `Travellers in for duty free shock'. I have already alluded to the potential fate of those 65,000 Australians currently travelling overseas who may be caught by this particular problem. The Australian Financial Review of 26 May contained an article under the heading `Duty free limit to hit jewellery stores'. May I say specifically about jewellery stores that the sale of expensive items of jewellery in Australia is one of the very significant undertakings of the duty free industry in this country. We should look at what is happening with the Australian gemstone industry-the enormous discoveries and development of the diamond potential of Argyle and the Kimberleys area, the development of the sapphire industry around Inverell, in my own State, and the development of cutting and processing techniques for Australian fine jewellery. We should look at the growth that is going on in the gold industry at the moment. Bearing in mind what an earlier IAC inquiry into the development of the jewellery industry in Australia had to say about promoting the value and the quality of Australian jewellery and of using stones mined in Australia, both precious and semi-precious, one can see that this is an area that in fact we ought to be encouraging. Yet high value items of jewellery, over the value of $400, which were very much the mainstay of a number of operators in the duty free industry, will be adversely affected. This is to occur against the background of an article that appeared only last weekend in the Sun-Herald newspaper dealing with the amount of revenue being lost on jewellery smuggling into Australia, which has been estimated in terms of hundreds of thousands of dollars. Jewellery smuggling is already taking place, and it will be extremely easy in this new situation. In fact, an impetus is provided by this legislation.

Simple tricks will be available. A person will be able to buy an expensive watch or piece of jewellery before he departs from Australia. He can take a watch out of the country, whether in his pocket or in the sealed duty free bag that he carries, while he is wearing the cheap and nasty watch that he picked up for $2 in the local supermarket. While he is overseas he can chuck away his cheap and nasty watch and put his expensive watch on his wrist, and he can come back and claim that it has always been in his possession, that it was the item that he took out of the country and brought back. A person can wear expensive jewellery or he can say that the camera he purchased was always in his possession. This provision will simply impose on the Customs Service a problem of recording and of knowing what was taken out of the country compared with what is brought back, and the value of such items at any stage-and all of this for the paltry sum of revenue involved, and because the Treasury has sought to impose a regime against the duty free industry in this country, its ultimate aim being to eliminate the industry altogether. I note that Mr Peter Spies, the excellent Chairman of the Australian Duty Free Operators Association-a very worthwhile organisation-has estimated that several thousand jobs could be lost in the industry as a result of these changes.

Once again, Senator Cooney's plea about the social impact of legislation and the heart that this Government is supposed to bring to its decisions is exposed for the sham it is. As a result, it has been my pleasure to move this second reading amendment on behalf of the Opposition. They draw attention to the further taxes involved, to the impost on families, small business and farmers, to the increases that flow in telephone and postal charges, and to the Government's attempt to eliminate people's ability to pursue the rights of administrative review of errors made by the bureaucracy by imposing additional fees. They condemn the attack on the duty free industry both as being contrary to all the expert advice received by the Government and as being an impost on a small business, diverting Customs officers and damaging our tourist industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to address in this gagged debate on a package of Bills the amendments to the Health Insurance Act 1973 contained in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. This Bill amends the Health Insurance Act to reduce the amount of Medicare benefit payable for medical services provided to private in-patients in hospitals and day hospital facilities and removes the $20 limit on patient contributions for such services. This, of course, is a discriminatory and unfair attack on those people who have private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech said that the Government gave careful consideration to the Medicare arrangements and was most concerned to ensure that these amendments did not in any way change the main principles of Medicare. Let us consider what these principles must be if these amendments do not change them. The principles surely must involve discrimination against those who are prepared to help themselves, because these amendments discriminate against those people who take out private health insurance. Unfairness must certainly be a principle to which the Government adheres, because this provision unfairly hits a special charge on those people who have private health insurance, a special charge that is not imposed, for exactly the same service, on people receiving treatment under Medicare. The legislation will involve the principle of longer queues in public hospitals, as it forces many people who have private health insurance but who are nonetheless low income earners-in fact, a large number of those with private health insurance-out of private health insurance by increasing the cost. Apparently, that is one of the essential points of the Government's Medicare proposals. It is as a result of Medicare that we now see these enormous queues at public hospitals while there are something like 9,000 empty private hospital beds. Of course, the legislation will lead to higher costs-and that obviously is one of the principles of Medicare. When we consider what has happened under this Government we see a massive increase in the health cost burden faced by this Government, and that means by the taxpayers of Australia.

The Minister said that the changes in respect of professional services rendered to an in-patient in a hospital or day hospital facility will reduce the Medicare benefits from the present 85 per cent of the schedule fee with a maximum gap of $20 to a flat 75 per cent of the schedule fee. He says that this will mean a significant saving to the Commonwealth Budget of about $105m. We could transpose the words in that sentence to read: This will mean a significant added cost for patients of $105m. The Minister said that people who have private insurance may have to meet a small increase in contributions. After I pressed the Minister on the point that this would inevitably lead to a higher cost for private insurance, we now have this grudging admission from the Government that it will lead to higher private health insurance costs.

We must recognise that this is in the context of an increase of a dollar or so a week in health costs as a result of last year's Budget. We are now to have an increase of up to $1 a week under this piece of legislation, depending on the level of reserves within various health insurance funds, and we must remember that many health insurance funds must have quite high levels of reserves because of the aging nature of their clientele. They must be protected against a run on their funds, their reserves, as the average age and the average health requirement increase. There are also to be cost increases of 50c to 75c as a result of the New South Wales Government's promise to increase hospital charges in that State following the Premiers Conference. The New South Wales Government said that the reduction in funding to it must inevitably lead to these enormous increases in costs. On top of that, there was a 25 per cent increase in the Medicare levy last December. We have had cost rise after cost rise in the health insurance area as a result of this Government's policies within the last six or seven months.

On top of that, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has come out with figures showing that health care costs to the public have been rising at double the rate of inflation over the past 12 months-and that excludes the Medicare levy, because the Medicare levy is excluded from the cost of living index. So we see this massive assault on the pockets of people, particularly those who are privately insured, by a Government which is, in effect, admitting that health care costs have got away from it and that the Medicare system-as the whole of Australia knows-is in an intolerable mess.

Let us consider what has happened to these costs since the Government came to office. In the last full year of the Fraser Government the cost of Commonwealth funding for health purposes totalled $4.4 billion. The cost for the current financial year, ending 30 June, was just under $9 billion. That is more than double. It means that under this Government health care costs have risen at the rate of $1.1 billion a year. The rate of increase under the Fraser Government was about one-third of that amount. There is no doubt that health care costs have gone through the roof, although in fact the standard of care being offered has diminished, due largely to the inability of so many people, particularly the frail and the aged, to get access to a public hospital when they need it. I will deal with the question of hospital queues later.
At this stage I want formally to move an amendment to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. I move:
At end of the motion add ``, but the Senate-

(1) is of the opinion that the Bill unfairly discriminates against hospital patients with private insurance who will receive only 75 per cent of the scheduled fee for medical services, while Medicare patients will continue to receive 85 per cent, so forcing up the cost of private insurance and assisting the Government's objective of forcing more Australians out of private health insurance and making them wait in pain for up to two years in the 100,000-long queue for public hospital beds;

(2) agrees with Mr John Singleton, who heads the Hawke Government's advertising campaign and who was sacked from the ALP-owned radio station 2KY in Sydney `for telling the truth about Medicare', that:
`Medicare might be great in theory but ultimately all you get for nothing is nothing';
`Every day the media reports how Medicare is and will continue to be a disaster . . . you only have to look at the waiting list at hospitals to see that';
`Our hospitals are sick';
`Medicare will not work, cannot work and it is not working';
`If you don't have private health insurance all you can do is hope for the best . . . hope that the hospital has the bed, the facilities and the experience you need . . .'; and

(3) requests the Government to withdraw the Bill and resubmit it in a form that provides fair, equitable, efficient and readily-available hospital services which do not discriminate against individual Australians and which do not push the frail, aged and chronically ill to the end of long queues for public hospital beds''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very comprehensive.

—Thank you, Senator Kilgariff. This matter of John Singleton's views of Medicare cannot be pushed aside by saying that they simply formed part of an advertisement. In the advertisement he says: `if I wasn't a member of a private health fund I would not write this ad'. According to Mr Singleton, that was his genuine view. The damning comments that he made about Medicare in that advertisement, following which he was sacked from 2KY, are of course accurate, and it must be a great embarrassment to the Australian Labor Party to know that the man who is trying to sell Medicare to the people of Australia, trying to encourage them to believe that it is worthwhile, is the man who said: `If I wasn't a member of a private health fund I would not write this ad'. That, quite properly, destroys the credibility of Medicare. That is further demonstrated by the fact that so many Australians, particularly those in lower income groups who have great difficulty in affording it, have in fact joined private health care. Under this Government, that is the only way they can be assured of adequate health care treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to pursue the question of the Government's trying to get its message across about Medicare. This has led the Government to make a series of deceptive and misleading statements, which can be judged by the Australian people on 11 July. The Government has released a document called `the Opposition health alternative-an analysis'. The question is posed: `Can you afford $27 a week?' It is very interesting; it was introduced at a press conference by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who, quite frankly, on this effort should stick to trying to fill in his tax returns-he is not too good at that either-rather than trying to work out alternative health schemes and the cost of them.

But the interesting thing about this paper introduced by Mr Keating and Dr Blewett is that it gives no indication of who prepared it. It was an analysis by whom? There is no name on the document. An attempt is made to pretend that it was done by officers of the Department. If so, it is a disgracefully politically prejudiced document. At whose expense was this document printed? Was it in fact another of those public relations publications by the massive Government operation aimed at encouraging people to think pure, to think clean, to think Hawke? The fact is, though, there is no name on this document. We do not know whether this is just one of the propaganda efforts of this Government. We do not know who authorised it for election purposes, as clearly it is an election document, and we do not know who should face up to the fact that it is incorrect and that it deliberately seeks to mislead. We do not know who the people are to blame for this totally phoney document.

The reason that this phoney document was introduced, from which Mr Keating and Dr Blewett got some publicity the other day, is that Labor Party research shows that people, and quite properly so, are concerned about the worsening Medicare mess. The Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 demonstrates what this Government is having to do, piecemeal, to try to correct that mess. We are now into Medicare mark IV. We have had basic changes in principle: For example, when Medicare first came in it was a matter of principle that, if one were privately insured and also contributed to Medicare, then Medicare should contribute towards one's stay in a private hospital. The Government has abandoned that basic principle. Now, a private patient who pays for private health insurance gets nothing back from Medicare in respect of a hospital bill-not a cent. In other words, those people who privately insure are subsidising this Government's Medicare system, because they are being ripped off in order to help paper over the excessive costs of health that have emerged from the Medicare mess. Some eight million Australians are privately insured-that is half our population. A half of the population is being ripped off by this Government due to an unfair and discriminatory health system. This Bill makes it even more unfair by reducing to 75 per cent the amount of Medicare cover for medical assistance while one is in a private hospital, as compared to the 85 per cent that one would get as a Medicare patient. This is discriminatory and unfair. It follows precisely the Government's previous record in relation to health.

I refer again to the document entitled `The Opposition health alternative-an analysis' that was released by the Government. It is a crooked, unsigned and misleading document, which is being waved around by Ministers and back benchers in the Labor Party, who probably do not know much better. There are some self-evident quaint things in it. They are claiming that Medicare has brought massive increased efficiencies to the hospital system because in the public hospital sector, for example, it says that statistics show that in 1983, prior to the introduction of Medicare, 2.38 million people received treatment in Australia's public hospitals and occupied 17.8 million public hospital bed days, but in 1986 under Medicare 2.47 million people received public hospital treatment yet they occupied only 16.9 million bed days. Quaintly enough, this document does not work out what sort of an improvement that is. I can tell the Government that I have done the sum for it, and it shows that despite massive technological improvements in our ability to get people ready for remedial and recuperative treatment, there has been only a modest 9 per cent improvement in the number of bed days required in the public hospital system.

Let us now work out what it has been in the private hospital system. In that time private hospitals have increased their rate by 22 per cent. Those sums were not worked out in this crooked document. The Government did not take any notice, did it? It would not work out the sum for us; it gave us the broad figures and hoped we would skim across them. This is typical of this document. When one has a good look at it one sees what the reality is. Once again, the reality is that the private sector, the competitive sector, is outperforming the public sector. Let us now look at another Labor lie in this document. On page 14 it says:

In 1983-the last full calendar year prior to the introduction of Medicare-each Australian used an average of 7.70 medical services. In the 1986 calendar year, the average was 7.68: an almost identical utilisation rate.
The Minister, Dr Blewett, repeated these figures in the other place and said, as recorded in Hansard:
I will not claim that Medicare is leading to less servicing of patients, but there has been no change in the pattern of servicing of patients under Medicare.

That is totally false. That figure cited here for the number of services that each Australian used in 1983 is a lie. Each Australian did not use that number. Between 1.8 million and 2 million Australians were excluded from that sum by whichever person prepared this dishonest political document. Every year in the Budget we have seen evidence that utilisation of medical services under Medicare has increased. If it increases every year how can it be that this Minister and this document-this deceptive and dishonest document-can pretend that utilisation has decreased? At least the Minister had the honesty, when he was trying to mislead this place, to say that the utilisation was 7.7 services per enrolled population. This deceptive document leaves out the word `enrolled'. There is the key. This Government will do anything to deceive and pretend to the people of Australia that this disastrous health system, this Medicare system, has been wonderful. It is interesting to note, is it not, that this Government thinks so highly of this Medicare system that it is saying that it will remain the same? It will stick by it; Medicare will remain unchanged. The media asked Mr Keating: If it is to remain unchanged will the Medicare levy remain unchanged after the election? He could give no assurances of any kind that there would be no change in the Medicare levy. Once again we have the Labor Party going into an election and not giving any assurance-it is almost like its tax policy before the last election-that there will not be an increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your tax policy?

—Our tax policy will be presented before the election, not like Labor's last time. The Labor Party went into the last election with no tax policy. We will be going to an election with a tax policy on which people can make a choice, not like the deceptive and dishonest effort by the Labor Party which went into the last election saying: `We don't really have a tax policy, but we will have a meeting and talk about it after the election'. We will not be doing anything as dishonest as that. We will be letting the people of Australia know, just as we will be letting them know our intentions about health in the near future, what our policy will be. All we have from this Government is a refusal to admit whether it will increase the Medicare levy after this election. That is the typical arrogance of this Government. Its record would clearly indicate that the Medicare levy under this Government is in for a big rise. After all, it cannot keep slugging the private sector, the privately insured people, in a discriminatory way. It cannot keep doing it forever the way it has over the last 12 months, adding something like $4 a week-to whom? Only to those people who are privately insured. In other words, it is a deliberate attack on the freedom of choice for health care, forcing people out of private insurance and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the next Labor lie in this document. We keep on getting them. Dr Blewett states:
Under the failed health schemes of the previous Government 2 million people did not have access to doctors.

We heard that again from Senator Tate today in this place at Question Time. I must say that Senator Tate is a man for whom I have the highest personal regard, and it is very disappointing to see a man of his integrity being prepared to mouth the rubbish handed to him by Dr Blewett, on whose behalf he has to appear in this place, when it is self-evident that that stuff that Dr Blewett has been handing out is as deceptive, as disgraceful and as dishonest as this nonsensical booklet which has been put out and to which, as I said, no one will put his name.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I have listened to the honourable senator and I have tolerated, as I understand the Standing Orders allow, a general claim against the Government concerning certain things, but the sheeting home of claims of dishonesty to the Minister from the other place, even with the imputation that it also applies to Senator Tate in this place, I think should be withdrawn.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, to save time I am happy to withdraw.
—The honourable senator is sailing pretty close the the wind. I ask him to withdraw that.

—I will withdraw any imputation against any individual senator or Minister elsewhere. All I will say about Dr Blewett is that if he did not know that what he was saying was totally false he is a monumentally incompetent Minister.
—They are afraid of you, Senator Baume.
—I think the honourable senator is right. Dr Blewett said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the failed health schemes of the previous Government 2 million people did not have access to doctors.

We heard Senator Tate say here that 2 million people were frozen out of health care under the previous Government. That is total bunkum. I will tell honourable senators what the Australian Bureau of Statistics shows about those people, but before I get to that let me give the details. I presume the Minister is referring to 1.8 million, because 1.8 million persons, according to the ABS, chose not to purchase health insurance in those days. It does not mean that they did not have access to hospital and medical services. To pretend that they had no access is deliberately misleading and totally false. Many of these-we have the statistics in case anyone wants to interject-were young and healthy but decided against health insurance on cost benefit ground. I will remind honourable senators that in those days health bills were a tax deduction. If one was fit and healthy it may well have been one's judgment that there was no benefit in joining a health fund because one would then be subsidising the heavier health bills of other people. The fact is that a large proportion of these people were in Queensland and were entitled to free hospital treatment anyway. So to say, as Dr Blewett did, that two million people did not have access to doctors is a straightforward and uncomplicated blatant mistruth. It is an attempt to deceive the people of Australia. It can be self-evidently shown by the figures of the Bureau of Statistics that 35.6 per cent of these people Dr Blewett says had no access to doctors were residents of Queensland where there is a free hospital system, a free out-patients system and people have access to doctors at any time. This is another of the Labor lies we have to put up with in the run-up to this election.

Another 23.2 per cent of the people surveyed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics gave the reason for not purchasing health insurance that they were healthy enough. In other words, for financial reasons that arrangement suited them-they received a tax benefit and they considered that they would save money by not joining a health fund and they probably did. Some 14.9 per cent of the people surveyed stated that they were entitled to benefits under pensioner repatriation or health care card arrangements. Why would Dr Blewett tell the people of Australia that such people did not have access to doctors when the Government was providing 15 per cent of them with access to doctors because they had pensioner repatriation or health care card arrangements? Did Dr Blewett not know that? If he did not know it, what an incompetent Minister he is. If he did know it, why did he set out to deceive the people of Australia?

The remainder of the group surveyed gave cost as a reason for not joining a health fund but, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey, almost half of these people were Queensland residents who were choosing to take advantage of free hospital in-patient and out-patient services. So the figures add up. Some 35.6 per cent were residents of Queensland and said that they did not have to be insured, that they had access to health care. The Minister is totally wrong on that score. Some 23.2 per cent of the people surveyed gave the reason that they were healthy enough and that they preferred to take self-insurance and 15 per cent said that they were entitled to benefits under the pensioner repatriation or health care arrangements. Here we have the continued deception by this Government in its desperate attempts to fool the people about the nature of this present Medicare disaster.

The reality is that under Medicare we have had continually rising public hospital queues and no wonder when the Government does what it can to force people out of the private hospital system on financial grounds. I have a document called `An Analysis of Public Hospital Waiting Time Bulletin No. 26, March 1987' published by the Victorian Department of Health. In the last eight months there has been a doubling, across so many areas, of the monthly delays and waiting times for getting into hospitals. I will quote just some of them. In Essendon, Melbourne delays for ear, nose and throat operations increased from 10.8 months in May 1986 to 26.9 months in March 1987. The list goes on and the waiting times have doubled-I certainly picked out the biggest one.

My time has almost expired but I want to stress that despite what the Government is saying, the real cost of health care in Australia will fall under the Liberals' health policy because the Labor Party's Medicare system is discriminatory: it involves people paying up to four times what they should-firstly, by the Medicare levy; secondly, through their tax which pays two-thirds of the Medicare bill; thirdly, if they are married the spouse has to pay another Medicare levy to get nothing extra and, fourthly, if they are privately insured, they have to pay for the fourth time. The Health Legislation Amendment Bill continues the discriminatory attack on privately insured people which has been maintained by this Government ever since it got into office. That attack is for one simple reason: It is self-evident that Medicare is an intolerable mess.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume raised points when speaking to this legislation package which includes the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1987, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs Tariff (Commonwealth Authorities) Amendment Bill 1987 and the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. I intend to confine my remarks-as did Senator Baume-to the health legislation and to Medicare and try to refute the claims made by Senator Baume. I will not try; I clearly can. Senator Michael Baume stated fairly stringently what the Government understands about Medicare. I will not quote him because that might create the impression that those claims are true. He is absolutely wrong and shameless in attributing to the Government such-
—You demonstrate where I am wrong.

—I am about to-patience, sir, patience. The reason the honourable senator can claim that the country or the Government is confused about Medicare is for one reason only and that is that the honourable senator is confused about Medicare. It is clear that he does not understand what the figures mean; he does not understand what Medicare covers and he has no qualms about creating an impression in the community that his confusion is a fact. It is a fact that it is his confusion; it is not a fact that it applies to this Government. The confusion about Medicare is in his mind. His confusion is betrayed by all of his comments in a recent speech. Further, his confusion is about who is saying what about Medicare for the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in answering a question today said that there is confusion in the Opposition about who is responsible for the Opposition's health policy. There is confusion about not only the Opposition's health policy but also about what the Opposition could possibly save. Senator Walsh mentioned figures and I would be delighted to mention them again. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was asked what he thought the savings would be if Medicare were scrapped or re-arranged according to some plan that the Opposition seems to have in mind. He estimates that it would save about $2 billion. Later the same day, Senator Michael Baume was asked: `Do you think the savings would be $3 billion?'. Senator Michael Baume said: `Yes, I think there would be every prospect of that'. So the confusion within the Opposition about the policy goes even to the savings if Medicare were abolished. The Opposition tosses off a mere $1 billion. For most of us out of approximately a $7 billion Budget, that is a very significant amount. The confusion is that members of the Opposition do not even agree amongst themselves about what their policy is. It is fairly clear that when Mr Porter was the shadow Minister for Health he was in the process of writing a health policy. It is now clearly understood that it has all been recalled and that Senator Michael Baume is charged with coming up with something that might be the Opposition's health policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.

—My goodness me, we will not hold our breath. Quite clearly, Senator Baume is so confused about what he says about Medicare that I would not hold my breath at all or have any expectations that the Opposition will have a health policy. It does not know anything even about--
—Let us have some facts.

—That is a fact. The honourable senator said that abolishing Medicare would save $3 billion; Mr Howard says that it would save $2 billion. That seems a fairly interesting fact. The Opposition has a $1 billion discrepancy. I will get to the more substantial matters of what the honourable senator wants to talk about in terms of the items under Medicare. It certainly seems that the honourable senator not only does not understand but also does not care to be accurate in his claims or figures. Misrepresentation is clearly the name of his game.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators on this side of the chamber were saying by way of interjection: `Where is your tax policy? Where is your health policy?'. Where are any of the proposals that would make sense of why the honourable senator would want to claim a $3 billion or $2 billion saving? What is the honourable senator planning to use to fund health care and what is he planning to do to cover the five million people who the honourable senator said today may be disadvantaged under his proposal? That is a great way to go to the electorate-`I plan to disadvantage five million Australians'. That should be a vote winner wherever the honourable senator tries to take it. Of course, if he takes it to the eastern suburbs of most States--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. That is a deliberate misrepresentation.
—I refer the honourable senator to Hansard. He said: `Five million people may be disadvantaged'.
—For goodness sake.

—I do not say that without quoting what was attributed to the honourable senator. In fact, that is what I said and the honourable senator repeated it so I thank him for re-endorsing what I said. The answer given by the Special Minister of State, Senator Tate, clearly dealt with that matter. Firstly, the Opposition is confused and, secondly, it has extraordinary gall to run around the country suggesting that it is prepared to stand on the issue of a dismantled Medicare package that will disadvantage five million Australians. I think that is a very curious way of trying to run an election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some of the points that the honourable senator insists the Government refute. For the time I am very happy to refute the points. To start with I refer to waiting lists. The Opposition claims-Senator Michael Baume has said this in this place-that 100,000 people are on waiting lists. There is absolutely no basis for this estimate. It simply demonstrates the depths to which Senator Michael Baume will go to make a point that is quite irrelevant to the substance of a Medicare debate. But he will not let that interfere with the Opposition's claims. He has conveniently forgotten statistics from the Commonwealth Department of Health which show that, under Medicare, the average length of stay in all hospitals has fallen and the number of patients receiving hospital treatment has risen compared with the figures for 1983. Public hospitals are now treating about 60,000 patients a week. That represents a considerable productivity gain over the health fiasco under the Fraser Government.

It also ignores the fact that at the recent Australian Health Ministers Conference all Ministers agreed that the States and Territories have primary responsibility for the administration and delivery of public hospital services. They also agreed that the following factors affected waiting times: Nurse shortages resulting in bed closures; supply of some specialist medical services such as orthopaedic surgery; and advances in technology allowing a greater variety of procedures, such as coronary bypass surgery and lens implants. I note that Senator Michael Baume has now retreated, no doubt with his tail between his legs. The list includes hip and other joint replacements to be more readily performed, and greater public awareness of new improved technology leading to greater demand. It was agreed that it was up to the States and Territories to develop programs to overcome waiting list problems, and the Federal Minister for Health was very supportive of all those agreements.

I cannot understand why the Opposition continues to quote figures from March, as Senator Michael Baume did. Is the Opposition so behind that it does not have updated figures? New South Wales already allocated $27m, and Victoria $32m, to develop new programs such as nurse recruitment, leasing of private beds, expansion of domiciliary nursing services, increases in day surgery, and more specifically focused facilities such as, for example, special orthopaedic requirements. These programs are already making considerable inroads into waiting times. For example, the Victorian initiatives have reduced waiting times for orthopaedic surgery at the Royal Melbourne Hospital from approximately 17 months to two months. In overall terms, elective surgery capacity has increased by about 4,000 a month. In New South Wales the number of beds has risen by a figure of 356, the number of patients has increased by 5,500, and there has been a significant reduction in waiting times for ophthalmology and orthopaedic and vascular surgery in a number of hospitals. These facts are up to date, make a mockery of the Opposition's claims and show the Opposition's complete ignorance of the issues.

Senator Michael Baume quoted figures from March. My figures relate to May and June. Given the problems faced by hospitals, particularly in Victoria and New South Wales consequent on the industrial changes and difficulties as a consequence of industrial action by nurses-these matters have been dramatically addressed and redressed-it is important not to continue to misrepresent grossly the figures regarding waiting lists and to claim that they contain 100,000 people. That claim is totally unsubstantiated and further amorphous claims have been made about waiting times up to March. I urge Senator Michael Baume to read the figures I have just given which will bring him up to date on his continued furphy against Medicare.

Senator Walters referred to an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of March 1983 that indicates that approximately 46 per cent of families with dependent children, with gross incomes of less than $126 a week, take out private health insurance. She used these statistics in seeking to justify her argument that everything about Medicare is wrong or that Medicare is to blame. To put the matter into perspective, I point out that these families represent less than 0.5 per cent of the population. Furthermore, families on $126 a week are exempt from paying Medicare levy under the Medicare arrangements introduced by this Government to ensure that people on low incomes are not disadvantaged financially in terms of the health cover of whatever sort they choose or need. Senator Walters has conveniently forgotten that as a result of the draconian Fraser health schemes the ABS report of March 1983 showed that 55 per cent of families with dependent children in the lowest income group had been forced to purchase private insurance. As with Senator Michael Baume's policies, the disadvantaged were squeezed between the poor card and unaffordable insurance. There was no universal and equitable system. There is now, and it is Medicare.

Senator Baume seems to have no idea of what choice means. It means that people, apart from those on the lowest level of income, who contribute to the costs of health services can settle for the adequate and sufficient health care services which they can enjoy under the Medicare levy or can purchase private health insurance. But to suggest that they do not have a choice, or that if we take away the Medicare levy they will have more choice, is to misunderstand totally the difference between Medicare with a private insurance option and the options under Fraser, when the choice was private insurance or nothing.

Senator Baume further confused the issues concerning bulk billing arrangements, on which he did not elaborate-he cannot continue to do that-in a number of ways. Again, I shall highlight the contradictions in his claims. The Opposition insists that bulk billing, amongst other things, is responsible for the increase in costs under Medicare and anything else associated with Medicare that seems to Opposition members to be bad and worthwhile doing away with. Curiously, though, honourable senators opposite have no evidence with which to refute the Government's figures, to prove that there has not been an increased utilisation of services under bulk billing and Medicare. In 1983, the last full calendar year prior to the introduction of Medicare, each Australian used an average of 7.70 medical services. In the 1986 calendar year the average was 7.68, an almost identical utilisation rate. Opposition senators insist that that is a false figure because it does not include those people who were not included as being insured. Well, of course not. Those figures are adjusted to take account of the fact that there is no evidence as to how those people utilised services, precisely because they were not included in insurance statistics and there could be no guesstimate of those figures. The Government's figures are utterly honourable. The Opposition seeks to suggest that, because 1,800,000 people were not included, those figures have not been adjusted properly to make adequate comparisons. That is clear evidence of a failure by the Opposition to understand the data.

The Opposition also seems to suggest that those figures are false because a number of people opted out of insurance because they were healthy. That may be so, but that says nothing about those people who stayed out of private health insurance because they could not afford it. Nobody has ever claimed that all those people were forced out of private health insurance because of the costs. There was a clear understanding that some people had opted out because they had made a choice; they had taken a gamble about their own good health compared to the costs. But to suggest that somehow the Government did not understand that is a gross misrepresentation of the Minister's and the Department's clear understanding of those facts. It makes nonsense of the Opposition's claim that the Minister did not take those matters into account in putting forward the figures. In fact, they are not his figures but estimates of the medical services. They have been adjusted to take account of those differences.

More importantly, there is a further contradiction in the Opposition's policy that staggers me. Those opposite insist that they will dismantle Medicare, and do away with bulk billing, except-bless me!-for people who pass some sort of means test. The Opposition will reintroduce a means test with its stigma, the poor card, which has gone under Medicare. The great advantage of Medicare is that people no longer have a mark on their forehead that says they are poor. There is no longer a poor card that says that a person will be given assistance because he or she is judged unable to be treated on an equal footing with anybody else in this country. The Opposition wants to reintroduce a stigma, a two-tier system of citizens in this country. It wants to dismantle the Medicare system which, because of its universality and equitability, has done away with all that. At present all citizens have equal access to the very adequate health services in this country, but the Opposition wants to reintroduce the means test, bring back the poor card and the stigma.

But curiously enough it wants to do this so that it can continue bulk billing. I do not understand how Opposition members expect to take it away but keep it at the same time nor do I understand how they can claim that they will have bulk billing only for pensioners when about 70 per cent of all bulk billed services are actually for pensioners or health care cardholders anyhow. If Opposition members looked at the data they would clearly understand that their claims for savings and all the other gains that they think will result from the dismantling of Medicare and the doing away with bulk billing will not actually happen. Opposition members have completely misrepresented or misunderstood the argument. They claim they will do away with bulk billing in order to save costs but they will allow it to continue for those people whom they will means test and stigmatise, and that turns out to be 70 per cent of the people who are currently enjoying bulk billing services. Apart from anything else, that sort of argument seems to be the best way of refuting Opposition claims. If Opposition members are as wrong as that about a very simple matter quite clearly anything more subtle is beyond their grasp. A recent survey of Sydney general practitioners by the Australian Consumers Association showed that bulk billing works to the advantage of pensioners, welfare beneficiaries and families in less affluent areas. Presumably these are precisely the people whom the Opposition will means test and allow to be bulk billed. How it can then expect to make any of the savings that it insists it will make is beyond me.

Let us turn to Opposition claims about savings. It has got those figures wrong too. Senator Giles suggested that the best way of describing Senator Michael Baume was as `innumerate and rapidly becoming non-tabulate'. I think we must agree about that because he does not understand the figures and he does not appreciate that what he proposes to do in dismantling Medicare will dramatically increase costs for Australians who will have to pay much more for their basic health cover. It is estimated that the increase will be at least $27 a week for basic health cover and possibly $37 a week for top cover. Why Senator Baume would want to campaign on a `break down Medicare and make everyone who can afford it pay more' basis seems a ridiculous position to take. That summarises exactly what the Opposition is saying about Medicare.

Let us have a look at the $3 billion savings and the costs to individuals. Any attempt to remove $3 billion from the health system means that the cost of basic insurance for health will rocket to $27 a week for families. I repeat that figure-$27 a week for basic health insurance cover. Those figures are based on 64 per cent of the population opting out, as they did in 1976. The Medicare benefits for these people which currently costs $1.3 billion would be transferred to private funds resulting in an $8 a week increase, just for medical cover. But the balance of the $3 billion savings would have to come in cuts from Commonwealth funds to State hospitals. A $1.7 billion cut in budget support would add a further $9.80 a week to hospital insurance costs. To this we must add existing costs for basic private health insurance. If one adds up those figures-$9.60, $9.80 and $8.00, as I have just spelt out-the total is $27.40. I recall Senator Walsh's answer in the Senate today to a question from Senator West when he said that the Opposition had given no thought to the effect on the consumer price index of forcing all those people on to private insurance and forcing the cost of that private insurance very high. As I recall, Senator Walsh said that there would be at least a 5 per cent increase-

TALK.START.PARA: —If all government health funding were withdrawn, the increase in the CPI would be more than 6 per cent.

—It means an even more than 6 per cent increase in the CPI. How the Opposition can argue that that kind of increase in inflation from just one item-private health insurance-can be tolerated is remarkable. The Opposition has no idea what it intends to do. It insists that somehow it will save $3 billion, or perhaps it is only $2 billion, by dismantling Medicare and presumably that is because this is the only area in which it is prepared to have even some guesstimates of figures. As my colleagues have said before, it certainly has not told us anything else that it will do in the way of taxation changes. It has certainly not told us how it proposes to get the savings necessary to finance all its other claims and it has not told us what would happen if, as a consequence of all these changes, the CPI increased by 6 per cent. That, of course, would have dramatic effects on a number of items-far too many to contemplate. I do not understand how the Opposition could possibly support such a policy. Again, I think that this highlights the utter confusion in the Opposition about Medicare and the consequences of dismantling it. It also has no understanding of the benefits of Medicare or of its costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area in which Senator Baume betrayed a clear misunderstanding was when he insisted that Medicare made no contribution to patients in hospital. That again shows his complete misunderstanding of two aspects. The first is that 75 per cent of medical costs of private patients in hospital treatment is covered by the Medicare return. That is a considerable amount of money. It is a contribution from Medicare to those patients who are in hospital. As well, the contribution from the Commonwealth to the States under the Medicare agreements provides a considerable amount of money to cover the costs of hospitalisation of all those patients who are treated in public hospitals. To not understand that is to not understand one of the basic tenets of Medicare and again illustrates Senator Michael Baume's complete failure to grasp what Medicare is about. It is disappointing to listen to Senator Baume who has not shifted his argument at all since he became the shadow Minister for Health. I would have thought that we could give him a period of grace so that he could learn how to spell it and understand what it was all about, but he has not done that. He has mastered nothing at all. His speech in this place today was precisely the same as the drivel he contributed to matters of public importance debates on health and the family some months ago. There is clear evidence that he has not shifted his ground at all. His only defence is to keep bagging the Government-I do not mind if he bags the Government-but he keeps bagging it with wrong figures and wrong facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. On behalf of Senator Michael Baume, who is not here at the moment for important reasons, I take exception to Senator Crowley's remarks. The figures and statistics that Senator Baume produced today were accurate and factual. It is a total misrepresentation on Senator Crowley's part.
—Order! That is a debating point, Senator Short, not a point of order.

—I urge Senator Short to read Senator Michael Baume's contribution today on these matters. The facts are as stated in this document and put on the record by the Government in any number of places. They are not grasped or refuted in any proper or adequate way by Senator Baume. He merely repeats claims about people on waiting lists. The data that he has takes him up to March 1987. Our data goes up to the present and clearly refutes his claims about waiting lists. These claims were wicked and scandalous in the first place, but they are better refuted by the most recent data which shows a dramatic improvement as hospitals attempt to deal with the significant problems, consequent on industrial and other matters that I listed earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes in this legislation are part of the May statement by the Government and are consequent on that statement. They are part of the massive and marvellous efforts that this Government has made to turn around the economy. Despite demanding tough things of people in the community, the Government has got the economy on the right track. That kind of recovery will benefit all Australians, not only in the Medicare and health legislation areas but, as a consequence of all the other legislation in this package, in so many other areas as well.

Senator Baume's contribution today did no more than to recapitulate the mistakes and errors on which he insisted in the first place and from which he does not learn and because of which he will not change. That portrays a lack of understanding of what choice is about and a confusion about the savings from bulk billing. He claims he will do away with it but then claims that he will not do away with it. That clearly indicates that the Opposition's policy in Medicare as in every other area is in total disarray. It is no threat to the Government, which will be proud and pleased to go to the people asking for yet another endorsement of Medicare which is already in place and which, on any evidence, is strongly supported by the majority of people. They have seen its benefits and know how it helps. They know too that it contributes to the maintenance of an excellent medical service, whether through our hospitals, private or public, or through our community or general practice services. Medicare is something this country is proud of and will re-endorse in the next election. I urge support for these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that I have to speak I would like to address the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill and bring to the notice of the Senate the Government's ineptitude in handling the Australian economy, bringing this legislation in at such a late stage and dissolving the Parliament so quickly thereafter. This Bill gives effect to the announcement in the May statement that sales tax exemptions will be withdrawn from certain Commonwealth authorities which carry on commercial functions. I do not mind the fact that government authorities have to pay sales tax but we must remember that in bringing down this May mini-Budget this Government has not looked at the costs that will be incurred by those authorities and passed on through the community. This Government is the biggest taxing government in peacetime history, with receipts from tax accounting for some 25 per cent of gross domestic product in 1986-87. In 1984-85 spending reached something like 30.4 per cent of GDP.
