SPEECH.PARA: Under the Fraser Government, expenditure in real terms increased at an average of only 2.1 per cent; under Hawke it is something like 3.9 per cent. As a share of GDP, the average of the Hawke Government has been 29.9 per cent. Under Fraser it was only 27.7 per cent. This Government has allowed our dollar to slump to ridiculously low levels. It has lost our AAA rating. Home loans interest rates are going as high as 15 1/2 per cent, Bankcard charges as high as 22 1/2 per cent and prime lending rate up to 21 per cent. This Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill will not help the Australian people, as I have already said. This Government claims that the sales tax measures will raise something like $310m in 1987-88 in direct tax and a further $395m in 1988-89. That burden has to be placed on to the Australian people who will pay those taxes. It means that in the next little while when this flows through to the community people will be slugged once again. It is a matter of great concern to all people in the community that this is the first Australian Government that has lost the AAA credit rating given us by two international credit rating agencies. It is a government which has allowed our inflation to rise against the rates of all the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, which have falling inflation rates.

So the Government stands condemned for bringing in legislation two days before the dissolving of the Parliament. It is just patching up legislation at a time when everyone must be wondering why we are having this early election. What has this Labor Government got hidden under the bed? Most probably it is the industrial relations legislation which is not under the bed but lying on the table in the other place. But this is not a time to bring on and guillotine a debate on something that will affect all people. Telecom Australia has already indicated that because of this legislation the cost of local telephone calls will rise from 18c to 21c. The maximum connection fee for country subscribers will rise from $1,380-odd to $6,250. With all that, there is an unemployment problem because there is talk of the sacking of 3,000 Telecom staff. Obviously unemployment figures will rise and the cost to the Government of paying unemployment benefits will rise as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe the Telecom figures?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his interjection. Telecom, as I have just said, will raise its charges. The Premier of New South Wales will raise charges in a lot of government instrumentalities because of the Government's May mini-Budget. So this Budget will not help people in the community to the extent that it should. Of course it was a sham anyway because it is what one calls a Clayton's Budget-a Budget when the Treasurer in Federal Parliament says `I am going to cut $1.6 billion off my spending but I expect the States to cut $2 billion off their spending'. As I said I would speak for only six minutes so that Senator Vigor could follow me in the debate, I will just say that the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill will not do what the Government intends and definitely will have far-reaching consequences for people in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the miscellany of Bills which the Government has put under the same header as a related package. The package includes the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill, which the Australian Democrats oppose. It includes also the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill, which seems to have stirred up a nest of hornets amongst various duty free shops and will produce quite unworkable situations in Australian Customs Service offices. The package contains also the Health Legislation Amendment Bill and a number of other measures. One of the things that I would like to raise in the last minute or so of this debate is the problem-and I do not think that the Government will be very happy about it-with the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill which is to give better cash flow to the Government. That Bill proposes to rip $27m off local government. It will result in an increase in local rates and will break the Government's promise at the last election for local government to get two per cent of income tax. The Government suddenly has become aware of the cash flow problem.

SPEECH.PARA: From a number of submissions in the Customs area I have become aware of a number of people from quite a number of areas who had clearances through Customs for computer goods and high technology goods but said that their pre-clearances had been changed, that samples would be required and that there would be delays in delivery. This could cause a base distortion of the trade figures if it is happening on a broad scale. It is the first time that I have ever had a number of phone calls of this type from people in different quarters complaining that the Customs Service is delaying them. Underlying this matter is a possible scandal. The Government is trying to push the Customs legislation through at this stage. The negative cash flow related to holdups in customs on imports is really quite unreasonable if the Government is fast doing what has been suggested. We will pursue this during the Committee stage of the Customs legislation to check up on this matter. I warn the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that we would like some answers.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say how pleased I am to see in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill that the Government has decided not to proceed with cuts in subsidies towards training volunteer counsellors in the Nursing Mothers' Association of Australia. The Nursing Mothers' Association has a very large membership Australia-wide and makes an enormous contribution to public health through counselling services to mothers who are breastfeeding infants. The Association is self-supporting and the service is entirely voluntary. The only contribution from the Commonwealth is partial support for a professional person to provide courses to volunteer counsellors. All overheads are met by the Association through donations by, and commercial sales to, members. I would like to congratulate the Nursing Mothers' Association on its enormous contribution to the welfare of babies in Australia over the years and to its commitment to community health care.

SPEECH.PARA: Also in this package of Bills is the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff (Commonwealth Authorities) Amendment Bill, which proposed amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 to implement the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May economic statement relating to Commonwealth authorities being required to pay customs duties. The effect of requiring statutory authorities to make customs duties payments is to impose an indirect tax on consumers of their services. It is a tax on all people. It is a dishonest way for the Government to raise taxes and perpetuates its reputation of being a high taxing government. The measure is expected to raise $75m per annum, mainly from Telecom Australia subscribers and partially from Australia Post. The effect is a tax on communications services. All honourable senators were taken aback by the Press release issued by Telecom within hours of the announcement of the customs duty and sales tax arrangements. I have a copy of Telecom's Press release of that occasion and seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TELECOM HIT IN TREASURER'S ECONOMIC STATEMENT
Telecom is taking urgent action to meet the demands placed on it by the government's economic statement.
Telecom has announced that it will need to increase prices significantly, cut its order to Australian industry and reduce its staff to meet the financial demands of the May economic statement.
New customers in higher cost areas will experience very considerable delays in connection of service.

Telecom's chairman, Mr Bob Brack, said: ``We have been forced to take these measures because of the decisions made by the Government which will cost telecom close to half a billion dollars in 1987/88''.

Mr Brack expressed his disappointment that the government had hit telecommunications so heavily. He said the government had failed to recognise the importance and significance of national telecommunications to the Australian economy and the part it played in improving Australia's international competitiveness.

``As a result of the government decision removing Telecom's exemption from sales tax and customs duty we will have to significantly increase charges for basic telecommunications services which we had planned to hold constant for 1987/88.''

``Telecom had advised government that the local call fee must increase by 3 cents with increases in STD rates as well. Rental charges and connection fees will also have to increase substantially. Unless these tariffs are approved by 30 June, higher increases will be necessary. Telecom is also examining the connection fees associated with high cost services which are currently provided at subsidised rates. Telecom can no longer afford to carry the extent of the subsidy it has in the past''.

Mr Brack said that the imposition of sales tax and custom duty on Telecom signals that the government no longer considers that the national telecommunications carrier should receive certain cost advantages which, since Federation, have allowed lower prices for basic telecommunications for all people and businesses in cities and, more particularly, the bush. As the government is now viewing Telecom as a commercial operation it is imperative that the significant constraints imposed on Telecom by government controls be removed.

Telecom is now carrying the costs imposed on its competitors, but no account has been taken of the additional costs which Telecom carries, but its competitors do not. If Telecom is to be able to compete then these costs must be reduced.
Telecom is also required to pay back 81 million dollars of past government loans. As a result it will have to reduce its 1987/88 expenditure program

``This will happen in a year when Telecom, in keeping with community price constraints, had already slashed its programs so that its plans avoided increases in basic tariffs and absorbed the significant effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar on basic network material'', the Chairman said. ``It should also be recognised that Telecom has achieved high levels of productivity and efficiency improvements over the years.''

He said the cutbacks would have to be made in the short lead time areas, in the customer end of the network-areas where less complex short lead time material such as cable, ducts and telephone instruments were used.

This will affect Telecom's ability to service new customers where significant cable reticulation is required to connect them-areas such as new housing estates, fringe urban areas and new and fast growing recreational and tourist areas.

When customers apply for a telephone service, Telecom will tell them if significant delays will occur. It is likely that the number of applicants experiencing serious delays will rise very significantly,'' Mr Brack said.

The rural and remote areas program which aimed to provide modern automatic telecommunications services to rural and remote area customers by 1990 will be seriously curtailed and will not be completed by its target date.

Network relief activity meant to improve congestion levels in country areas will have to be scaled down, and work to modernise switching equipment in central business districts to provide enhanced services will be put at risk.
Mr Brack said that the material orders placed with Australian manufacturers will have to decrease by about 50 million dollars.
He also said that there would be substantial staff reduction in Telecom over the above those already planned. This could be of the order of 3 per cent.

``Such impacts on Telecom's customers, suppliers and staff are greatly regretted by funding reductions of the magnitude announced by the Treasurer cannot be expected to be undertaken without significant effect of Telecom's ability to provide the range and quality of service that is expected of it,'' Mr Brack said.
14th May, 1987
Released by Keith Hainsworth, National Manager, Media (03) 606 5017.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The scale of proposed increases was several times larger than what it needed to recruit the extra customs and sales tax revenue the Government wants. How this can be used as an excuse to cut Telecom's orders to Australian industry is beyond me. The changes, although they affect Telecom's ability to invest in new technologies, should encourage a greater reliance on products developed in Australia. Telecom has also signalled that it will apply pressure to the Government by creating longer delays in the provision of services to new housing areas and fast-growing recreational and tourist areas. This is a direct challenge to the Government. The Minister should demand an explanation of just what additional delays Telecom wants to engineer and make it public. I understand Telecom's disgust at this large addition to the Government's demand on its revenue. However, threats to cut back Telecom's public services are most unworthy of a publicly owned enterprise. Telecom has also threatened to cut back its provisions of new services in rural and remote areas and to reduce staff by up to 3 per cent overall. Both these threats are entirely non-productive for Australia and will exacerbate the stupidity of the Government's actions in imposing this extra charge.

During the second reading debate on this Bill I referred in some detail to the content of these amendments. In fact, they follow a line similar to that of the Government's amendments, only covering a great many more areas. They relate to matters of concern regarding the increased powers to be given to the Department of Social Security in this legislation, ranging from the alteration in rules for people living under one roof all the way through to secrecy provisions and the various requirements for the payment of sickness benefits, the waiting period for unemployment benefit, the recovery of overpayments, and the power to seek information from third parties, as well as discretionary powers in a number of areas, including discretionary powers in relation to payments to social security beneficiaries currently living overseas.

As I have said, I canvassed fairly widely the provisions of these amendments during the second reading debate. However, I say at this point that there is a great deal of concern in the community about the provisions in this legislation-concern which principally goes to the fact that the various measures that are addressed in my amendments appear to put far too much power into the hands of the Department of Social Security. These powers surpass those which are available to other Government departments, even those departments which are charged with the responsibility of ferreting out tax fraud, and those charged with the responsibility of prosecution of criminals. These amendments relate largely to this matter, but they also address some of the problems which the mini-Budget has presented to various groups in the community, from the young unemployed to women who find their circumstances dramatically changed by the removal of the supporting parent benefit and the widow's pension when their children reach the age of 16. I might point out that that is an enormous change from the age of 24, which is the current position. The Democrats do not believe that the transition provisions in the legislation are adequate, and one of the amendments addresses that issue.

There is great concern, as I said, about various provisions in this legislation. Most of the amendments address the effects of this Bill on people very much at the individual level. I regret the fact-and this was indicated by several other senators during the second reading debate-that we do not have a great deal of time in the Committee stage to address these six Bills, namely, the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1987, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs Tariff (Commonwealth Authorities) Amendment Bill 1987, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 and the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987. I know that various senators have prepared a great many amendments for the six Bills. Unlike some of my colleagues here, I do not believe that the time limit of 55 minutes which we have been given for this Committee stage should be taken in large measure by one individual senator. That is why I chose to devote most of my speech in the second reading debate to addressing these amendments. I commend the amendments to honourable senators.

Finally, I make the point that in normal circumstances such significant Budget legislation could have taken two, or even up to three, months to find its way through both Houses of Parliament, during which time it would have been subject to careful scrutiny. The various parties in the Parliament would have been in a position to negotiate the various aspects of the legislation. As has occurred quite often with legislation in the past-and this is certainly the goal of the Australian Democrats-these amendments and possibly others, would have been carefully worked through, perhaps with the Government, with advice from relevant departments, and perhaps with the Opposition, to address some of the very genuine concerns that exist in the community. I refer, of course, to my amendments to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. My area of responsibility also encompasses a later Bill in respect of which I would have made the same comments, had there been any time available. I commend these amendments to the Senate, and although I have had an opportunity to put these amendments, I regret that, because it has been only three weeks since this mini-Budget statement and because we will all be galloping off to an early election in a day or two's time, there has not been time to address the amendments in quite the responsible way which the Australian Democrats would have preferred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is very concerned about the phasing out of the class B widow's pension. I believe it is a disgrace. The Australian Democrats have moved some sort of amendment that prolongs the phasing out period but does nothing at all to assist the class B widows. Class B widows are those women in our society who no longer have dependent children but who, in the majority of cases, have been out of the work force for some 20 to 25 years. These women have spent that period of time bringing up their families. They have no work force skills left. They have been dependent spouses for a period of 20 or 25 years. They have not had the luxury that all the men in this place and in Australia have had of upgrading their work skills as time went on while they were in the work force. They have chosen, in support of their husbands and in bringing up their families, to stay at home and do the job that would cost the Government a considerable amount of money to have someone else do. Many of them have cared for elderly relatives, both their own and those of their husbands. They have not forced their relatives into institutional care. They have looked after them in their homes. Indeed, some have taken them into their own homes to look after them. They have cared for the children and they have not been able, over the 20 to 25 years, to upgrade their work skills. When their husband dies, they are left without any work skills to be able to go out, as the Minister has suggested, and get a job.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has told us that the class B widow's pension stops the incentive for this group of women to get out into the work force. What utter rubbish. That sort of thing could come only from a male dominated group of decision-makers. It could come only from the sort of government in which the women senators have shown such a lack of interest in that group of women that the Minister for Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) did not even know that pensions for that group of women were eventually to be phased out. It could come only from a government so lacking in compassion for that group of women that it cannot see past saving a few dollars. The Government says to them: `Okay, once you are 50-or 45 if you have had dependent children up till that age-and your husband dies, go out and get yourself a job. Go down to the Commonwealth Employment Service weekly and see if you can get yourself a job'. The Government does not understand that there is no way that that group of women can possibly get themselves a job. They have not been in the work force since they were 20-odd. They gave up the security of a job to rear the children, to look after the elderly relatives and to assist their husbands, the breadwinners. But this Government has said: `Once your spouse and breadwinner dies, that's it. We will no longer give you the widow's pension. We will throw you on the unemployment heap'. That is the full extent of what this Government has done to that group of widows. It is without any question an absolute disgrace.

The Government is hiding behind the fact that it is taking quite a while to phase out this scheme. It is saying to women in that group: `Don't you worry about it; it's not you lot that we'll get at, it's the lot coming up'. So anyone in that age group at the moment is quite safe. Those people will continue to get the pension; they will not even know it is going on. But the next group coming up-the next lot of women reaching that age group and suddenly becoming widows-will know what the Government has done. But this Government is so lacking in compassion and so sly that it believes that the new lot of women falling into this category will not be aware that there was ever a benefit available to them and will not be aware that this Government has taken it from them.

I can assure this Government that this side of the House will continue to remind those women-that group of people who have been let down by the Government that cares so little for the traditional mother in Australia-that the Government has ripped off from them, for a few lousy dollars, the class B widow's pension. I can assure the Government that this matter will not be forgotten, because the people of Australia do indeed respect the mothers who have stayed home and cared for them. The people of Australia do respect, whether this Government does or not, the women who have given up the security of a job to look after their children, to support their husbands in their work and to look after the elderly in Australia. There will be a backlash. I assure the Government of that. I assure the Government that, now that Mr Hawke has gone for an early election saying `give us the mandate to continue the job', the Australian people will say: `Not on your life'. There will be no mandate to continue to hurt the most disadvantaged and those least able to care for themselves; and there will be no mandate to finish off the people of Australia-elderly women in particular, including war widows and B-class widows which are the two groups that this Government has attacked more than any in the whole of this society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government does not agree to Senator Powell's amendments. The Government estimates that the amendments would cost some $40m in 1987-88 and some $50m in 1988-89. During the course of Senator Powell's speech she said that she would like to have had the opportunity to work through her amendments with the Government rather than just moving them and having them voted on. That opportunity will certainly be accorded her by the Government prior to the Budget session of Parliament if she would like to do that. In view of the costs associated with the amendments as moved, and for other reasons, the Government cannot accept them at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters made a fervent plea on behalf of B class widows, and I understand some of the things she said. She seemed to be objecting to the Government inserting what used to be called a grandfather clause-although I suppose `grandmother' would be more appropriate in this case-as she saw that as being some sort of devilish cunning on the part of the Government. That is not so at all. It is just that people who are currently in receipt of those pensions have probably become used to receiving them, many of them having received such benefits for some years. That pattern has developed in their lives and they are reliant on those pensions, and for that reason the Government has--

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be phased out.
—I understand that.
—Obviously you have never had any understanding of women of that age-none at all.
—Senator Walters made an impassioned speech redolent with hypocrisy, if I may say so, about the position of these women who in future may be required to seek employment.
—You try to train them.

—I have heard the honourable senator talking in this place again and again about 17-year-old girls from whom she would take away any support at all to make them get jobs-and the circumstances of 17-year-old-girls are no different from those of B-class widows.
—They have had their support taken away from them, too.
—That is not true, Senator; it is not true at all.
—Of course it is.

—It is not true. Is the honourable senator now relying on the views of the Australian Democrats on this issue? All I am saying to Senator Walters is that she should get her act together about these things before making these sorts of speeches, aided and abetted by Senator Boswell over there with his fervent interjections.
—I never said a word.

—You did; you said `Ugh' on several occasions, which I interpreted as some sort of war cry in support of Senator Walters. There is no difference, in terms of the principles that Senator Walters attempts to enunciate in what she had to say, in the position of B class widows and the position of young girls forced into the labour market.
—If you do not know the difference, it is very obvious that you have never had any experience in that area.
—I do not claim for a moment to have had Senator Walters's experiences, and, if that is the result, I am extremely grateful.
—You've had a pretty soft life.
—Senator Walters should declare her interest before making a remark like that. She comes in here talking about Medicare and the medical profession every day.
—That is below the belt.

—Not at all, Senator. I make those observations because I think that if one wants to talk on a plane of high principle about these issues, one should get the principles sorted out first. The Democrats' amendments will not be accepted by the Government for the reasons which I indicated in my earlier remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept what the Minister has said and welcome any possible opportunities in future to address some of the complex issues which are raised by the Democrats' amendments. However, I take up the plight of the class B widows. Because the amendments will not be passed, those widows will face a transition period which will be tougher than we would want and they will not receive the relaxed income test which we have suggested. In my speech at the second reading stage I made it quite clear that a relaxed income test would have been of great benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Government to take into account an issue which is not raised directly in the amendments but is certainly related to the legislation. The Government has put money into training programs specifically, it says, for this group of women. I hope that the Department of Social Security will not wash its hands of the problems those women will have even in the transition period. I hope that it will take some interest in the way in which the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, which will receive a large sum of money in order to set up the training programs, and the Department of Community Services, which also has a role to play, go about their task and do what it can to ensure that such programs are set up, are effective and are available to all those women.

It is all very well to put millions of dollars into retraining programs and, I might say, into babysitting, which will hardly be much use to this group of women, but for women in isolated areas in particular it might not be a great deal of benefit if the training programs are set up somewhere in a metropolitan or regional centre. I do not know what the Government has in mind for those women in terms of transitional arrangements, but they will be at risk. I ask the Government to ensure that the Department of Social Security, having washed its hands of these women in regard to benefits, continues to take some interest in their welfare and perhaps jog along those other Government departments whose responsibility these women now are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has been said by the Government and the Australian Democrats is a lot of rubbish. Both the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party have engaged in a public relations exercise. When they say, `We will try new things to retrain these 50-year-old-women', I suggest that they are talking through their hats.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise another aspect-the income testing of the family allowance. The clause mentions an income threshold of $50,000. We have been told that full family allowance will be payable to a family with one dependent child, up to a taxable income of $50,000, gradually reducing to nil when the income exceeds $51,094. For a family with two children the figures are $52,500 and, I believe, $55,156. For a family with three children the figure is $55,000. I presume that the allowance will cut out when an income reaches about $59,528. I attempted to clarify the above figures for one of my constituents. I have a table before me, the figures of which were calculated by a member of my staff who, in the interests of accuracy, sought to have them verified by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). A member of the staff of the Minister's office, in turn, tried to obtain assistance from the Department. It advised that the final scales have not yet been drawn up and could not confirm the figures that I have been quoted. The Department said that decisions relating to the treatment of portions of dollars in salary and payment of family allowances of less than $1 had not been finalised. The Minister's office suggested that I use only the $50,000 threshold figure, as stated in the May statement, as being the maximum taxable income which could attract full family allowance for one child, and I was advised that, for every dollar of income over the threshold, family allowance would be reduced by 25c and that when a family has more than one child the threshold increases by $2,500 for the second and subsequent children.

When I asked whether I could use the final cut-out that my staff had worked out for me, I was told no, that I might end up with egg over my face. I asked the Department whether it could possibly give me the figures, and it told me no. We have legislation before us, and the Department, and the Minister more importantly, cannot tell the people of Australia what the final cut-out figure is for family allowance being taken away. Can the Minister please enlighten me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell referred to training programs and the need, as she put it, for the Department of Social Security to jog other departments about the administration and availability of those programs. I understand that there have already been discussions among departments about that. Senator Powell having jogged me, I have jogged the officers of the Department here, who did not need any jogging, but the process will be taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: Insofar as Senator Walters's question is concerned, I understand that there is a readily available answer. The calculation involves a simple mathematical formula which is clearly understood, and I cannot add to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister whether these figures are accurate, seeing it is so simple and seeing his Department informed me that a set was not available and that I had better not use these figures. For accuracy sake, the Minister has officers of the Department beside him. Is it a fact that for one child the threshold for family allowance starts at $50,000 and finally cuts out at $51,094; for the second child $52,500 and finally cuts out at $55,156; for the three children $55,000 and finally cuts out at $59,528; for the fourth child $57,500 and finally cuts out at $63,900; and for the fifth child $60,000 and finally cuts out at $68,587?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is a simple arithmetic formula. No scale of the kind that the honourable senator has suggested in her question is yet prepared, but it just involves the application of a formula to income. If the honourable senator has a particular set of figures that she wants to put to officers of the Department they will quickly tell her exactly what the cut-out point is. The honourable senator could throw up examples all night, but I think she would probably be wasting the time of other honourable senators who want to speak on these Bills. Certainly the Department will provide her with answers if she wishes.

—That answer is not sufficient. My officer has spoken to the Department which told him that it could not give him the accurate figures for which we asked. I was trying to respond to one of my constituents, and I was assured by the Department that it could not give me the answers. As it is a simple arithmetical calculation why can the Minister not tell me whether I am right? Are my figures correct, seeing that it is so simple? Why is the Minister hedging the question? Why can the Minister's departmental officers, who are sitting beside him, not tell me whether at least the first two or three figures are correct? During telephone conversations, departmental officers continually refused to give me the information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to quibble about this, but it is not my Department. I guessed from the honourable senator's earlier question that she might have consulted the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce about this matter and had not been able to get an answer.
—Don't be silly. I am talking about the Department of Social Security.
—I am not being silly. I am advised that the first figure cited by the honourable senator is correct.
—What about the next figure.
—I am not going to go through all these figures with the honourable senator.
—But the Department will not give them to me.

—The honourable senator should try again. I am not going to spend the whole night going through a set of calculations with the honourable senator. The Department has indicated that it will check the figures she has put to them. I am told that the first one is correct. I am not going to go through them all. That offer has been made to the honourable senator and I hope that she avails herself of it. In the Senate I cannot rely on conversations which allegedly took place between a member of the honourable senator's staff and an unnamed officer of the Department of Social Security. I am telling her as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security here that if she goes back to the Department and asks for verification of the figures she has compiled and whatever else she wants to know about them, the answers will be given to her. That is the best I can do.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10b) Page 11, clause 21, after proposed subsection 120a (2a), insert the following new subsection:

`` `(2b) The Secretary may, in his discretion, treat a person as having been unemployed throughout a particular period for the purposes of subsection (1) notwithstanding that the person undertook paid work during the whole or a part of that period if the Secretary is of opinion that, taking into account the nature and duration of the work and any other matters relating to the work that the Secretary considers relevant, the work should be disregarded.'.''.

This amendment relates to the 13-week waiting period which amendment 10a sought to remove. That amendment having been negatived, amendment 10b would permit the Secretary to disregard any brief periods of employment during the 13-week waiting period, therefore not necessitating the beneficiary going back to the beginning of the 13-week waiting period an that case. It is obviously an area of great injustice. The 13-week period seems to us to be inordinately long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON

SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1987
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have received a large number of submissions from duty free shops, from photography equipment manufacturers, from Customs officers, and from jewellery producers within Australia protesting at the removal of the discretionary duty free allowance for travellers entering Australia. This is, in fact, in contradiction to the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission in December 1985 which led to the establishment of duty free shopping within Australia for Australians leaving the country. The Australian Democrats strongly supported these moves because of the increased trade within Australia and the increased ease of surveillance by Customs people of the regulations. This allowance has encouraged a considerable expansion of Australia's enterprises which have been manufacturing jewellery and photographic equipment, and it has led to the increase in the number of duty free shops throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs officers pointed out to us the difficulty of policing people entering Australia with personal effects from overseas and that attempts to police people will divert efforts away from the effective policing of quarantine and drug laws, which are of greater importance. The Australian Democrats will move an amendment to the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1987 to leave unchanged passengers' concessions on sales tax exemptions for personal items. At the same time, we will move a set of amendments to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1987, which by some strange organisational arrangement is in another package of Bills which the Government is guillotining, which will make the whole proposition revenue neutral. When we consider this legislation, I will move a motion to disallow the current free allowance of alcohol and cigarettes for incoming passengers. This measure represents quite a large amount of money and, as we understand it from the figures we have, it would be to the advantage of the Government. We have received a number of submissions from various shops. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from A. E. Sharkey and Co. Pty Ltd, Banksmeadow, to Senator Haines, which I think puts the point very clearly.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
1 June 1987
The Right Honourable Senator Janine Haines,
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
My Dear Senator,

As discussed with your secretary, set out below is a submission in relation to proposed changes to sales tax provisions relating to duty free goods imported by passengers (Item 114 (2) of the Sales Tax Assessment Act).
These notes are dictated for the sake of saving time, so may not be as fluent as I should have liked them to be.

This change is linked to the restriction of passenger's allowances resulting from the by-law amendment which will withdraw recognition of personal effects, etc. and confining the passengers' allowance to goods to the value of $400.

1. Restriction of passengers' allowances as proposed will materially and adversely affect the Australian duty free store industry. This industry makes export sales valued at $750 million per annum and generates some 3,000 jobs in Australia. It provides a major attraction to overseas tourists but requires the business diverted to Australia, by way of sales to outgoing Australians, for the maintenance of its low cost structure.

2. The changes proposed will create a very substantial administrative work load for little or no net return. Whereas currently very few outgoing Australians provide lists of goods in their possession, in future most will need to do so. Wristwatches, cameras, personal jewellery, binoculars, fur apparel and so on must be listed on departure or run the risk of attracting duty on return. Obviously, new, if any , additional staff will be provided to customs to meet this work load and resources will need to be diverted from the vitally important quarantine and anti-narcotic functions of Customs at airports. The flow of incoming passengers is likely to be congested by the necessity to value items currently admissable without these processes being required. Our attractiveness as a tourist destination is likely to be diminished by congestion at airports.

3. Although the sales tax aspect of passengers' allowance has come before Parliament, the critically import allowance provisions have been materially amended by administrative decision. This change in this instance has not even required the signature of the Minister. A copy (attached) of the first page of the gazette notice (S82) of 14 May 1987 shows this. Parliament ought to express its opposition to this process by rejecting such parts of the package as come before it.

4. The passengers' allowance in nominal dollars has remained unchanged for some seven years. Clearly, the value of a duty free $200 today is considerably less than it was when it was introduced. A concession relating to goods to the value of $400, but including personal effects formerly non-dutiable is a major contraction of the already eroded passengers' allowance.

5. The new requirement to account for the incoming personal effects of overseas visitors on arrival and departure, aside from the diversion effect mentioned above, will inevitably lead to harassment and upsetting of visitors in relation to whom the Government has spent millions of dollars to attract to Australia.
Yours Faithfully,
A. E. Sharkey
on behalf of
Australian Duty Free
Operators Association

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, subclause 2 (2), lines 9 and 10, leave out the subclause.
(2) Page 5, clause 28, lines 25 to 33, leave out the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I say formally-I have conveyed this to the Australian Democrats-that the Opposition will not be supporting these amendments. We fully understand the reasons why the Democrats are seeking to make these changes which, as far as the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill is concerned, returns sales tax exemptions to the status quo that existed before the Government's May mini-Budget statement. As I said earlier in the second reading debate, the Opposition thinks this is a very ill-considered measure of the Government. We believe that it does not take full account of all the circumstances that should have been taken account of, including the Industries Assistance Commission report which earlier recommended various changes to the arrangements relating to duty free entry by visitors or other incoming passengers. The Government has chosen to ignore the advice of the IAC and the Australian Customs Service in the decisions it took in the May statement context.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today I requested the Government to withdraw this proposal, to have another look at it and, if it must find another $21m to squeeze out of taxpayers in some shape or form, to do it in another way if it is unable to cut its coat to suit its cloth by reducing expenditure by an equivalent amount. I hope that the Government will have another look at this proposal. We take great account of the views that have been expressed by various groups which are concerned about the financial and other impacts of the proposal. Considerable concern is being expressed by the Australian duty free industry about its impact on duty free operators. There is concern about the employment factor. There is a particular concern in the tourism industry about the impact of the automatic congestion that this change will involve at major airport terminals. We sympathise with and understand all those reasons. We think that the Government's measure is stupid, but as a responsible party we had to take a decision at the outset-

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the new line, that you are a responsible party?
—We took that view on all the Budget Bills, as Senator Button well knows, both in the 1986 Budget and in the package of Bills that make up this putative, so-called mini-Budget of May 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: For that reason, we will not support the amendment of the Australian Democrats. However, I repeat to the Minister-especially as he has responsibilities for commerce and the development of Australian industry, including tertiary industries-that we want him to look again at the proposal because we are convinced that the decision that he has taken-which goes against the advice of his own Department-is contrary to what the proposal constitutes. I urge him to have another look at the legislation and, if he must raise revenue, to come up with a more efficient way of raising it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short said, we find ourselves unable to support these amendments, despite the fact that we believe that they should not have been introduced by the Government because of the constraints imposed on us by the Government's decision to treat this as a revenue raising measure. After the forthcoming Federal election we hope to be in a position to review the matter and to deal with it appropriately at the first available opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to Senator Vigor's remarks, I draw attention to the attitude of the Australian Democrats towards the question of duty free shopping. The greatest threat that has been posed to the viability of the duty free shopping industry was the introduction of inward duty free shopping. A monopoly is granted at Australian airports, to the great disadvantage of all the small business operators off airport. That legislation was passed only because the Australian Democrats voted for it-all except their leader, Senator Haines, who voted against it.

The debate on 5 December 1985, was led by Senator Sanders on the basis that the measures were `not considered by us to be tax or Customs measures'. He said that the measures were aviation measures, and that the Democrats would allow the duty free shopping legislation to pass. What is more, in the Committee stage on the same day, he said that he envisaged no problems that the people in the Australian Customs Service could not solve, despite the fact that that was untrue at the time, is untrue now, and has been claimed to be untrue by the Democrats during this debate. They voted for the introduction of inward duty free shopping despite the fact that it was confined to only three items-tobacco, alcohol, and perfume. So for all of the waffle about the terrible effects of tobacco and alcohol, the Australian Democrats voted to introduce inward duty free shopping on the basis that only those three items-tobacco, alcohol and perfume-would be sold.
In that debate, Senator Sanders read into the record, on page 3058 of Hansard, a letter written to Senator Chipp by Senator Button, which stated:

As previously discussed, I write to confirm that the Government will not under any circumstances move to extend these provisions to include further categories of goods other than those already announced to be covered, namely, tobacco products, alcohol and perfume.

The Australian Democrats think that they can pick up the duty free operators' votes-the 3,000 people in the industry. They come here and bleat, all of a sudden, that they want us to support the duty free industry when it was their vote that produced the most significant attack on the industry-prior to this Government's-by bringing in inward duty free shopping. Despite the fact that Senator Haines voted against it, every other Democrat voted for it on that occasion. It was not a tax measure or a customs measure. It was an aviation measure, because Senator Sanders was in charge of the legislation at the time. What is more, the only things that were to be introduced to increase sales and revenue were tobacco, alcohol and perfume. Now the Australian Democrats are saying that they want to rip tobacco and alcohol products out of the duty free classification because they are now wicked and evil; they have become wicked and evil since 5 December 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —The perfume is all right.

—The perfume remains all right. It is a clear indication of the way in which the Australian Democrats approach any issue, group or lobby, that they think they can pick up along the way, despite their own track record. I want to put clearly on record that if the duty free industry has anything to complain about, apart from the Government's taxation measures, it is the Democrats' support of in- ward duty free shopping in December 1985. If the Democrats want to tell us how evil tobacco and alcohol are, they have a great deal of explaining to do as to why they introduced a new monopoly for the sale of those two products, plus perfume, at inward duty free stores only 18 months ago. It exposes the whole sham of the way in which, suddenly, the Democrats have become supporters of the duty free industry when they have done so much to damage it in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would make the point that in the Bills concerned the Australian Democrats were not given the option of getting rid of tobacco and alcohol. The option that was given to us was that they should be in Australian shops under the control of Australian Customs officers rather than having a situation that was quite out of control. I believe that the matter can be better solved by the measures we are putting forward. There is no inconsistency in our operation. Senator Puplick, with his eloquence, has managed to present an unreasonable picture. The two operations are quite independent one from the other. We shall continue to fight against the evils of people who want to import drugs into Australia, even if they are ordinary people.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

Clauses 1 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 7, proposed subsection 163 (1c), line 12, leave out ``the regulations referred to in''.
(2) Page 3, clause 7, proposed subsection 163 (1d), lines 16 and 17, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
`` `(1d) A fee is not payable under subsection (1c):

126. Where-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it under a two-hour guillotine a package of seven Bills dealing with various changes in customs and excise matters. The seven Bills as listed are the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill, the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, the Customs Tariff Validation Bill, the Excise Tariff Validation Bill and the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill. Because there is a two-hour guillotine operating on this whole package of Bills and there are seven speakers listed to speak on this package, it appears unlikely that we will be able to get into the Committee debate on these pieces of legislation. I therefore propose to indicate in my remarks the areas in each of the Bills in which the Opposition would have moved amendments if in fact we had had the opportunity to move into Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: These seven Bills can in fact be broken into four groups of Bills, and I want to say something about what is contained in each of the four groups. In the first group we have the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill. The main provisions of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill are to bring about changes associated with the Government's policy for the manufacture of motor vehicles and changes to rate of customs duty applicable to certain refined petroleum products, to implement the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission report on the chemicals and plastics industry, to bring about various changes associated with the Government's decision on the post-1988 assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries and amendments made in the context of the current TCF sectoral policy, to implement the Government's decision on the IAC report on the power electronics industry and to implement the Government's decision on the IAC recommendations on citrus fruits.

In the second category of legislation we have the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, which provides a series of amendments to specific bounty measures. Amendments are proposed, first, to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act arising from the Government's decision in November 1986 concerning the textile, clothing and footwear industry, and secondly, to the Fertilisers Subsidy Act to give effect to the Government's intention that locally produced fertiliser should be subject to the new assistance arrangements set out in the Act from 20 August 1986. Amendments are proposed, thirdly, to the Subsidy (Cultivation Machines and Equipment) Act to correct the Act's provisions for eligibility for a subsidy, and, fourthly, to the Bounty (Books) Act, among other things to acquit undertakings given to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that certain determinations by the Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

In the third group of Bills we have the Customs Tariff Validation Bill and the Excise Tariff Validation Bill, which give effect to the Government's recent announcements on tariffs and bounties. The three principal areas of the Customs Tariff Validation Bill arise, first, from the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on vegetables and vegetable products; secondly, from the Government's decision on the IAC report on luggage, handbags and similar containers; and, thirdly, from consideration by the Australian and New Zealand Governments of the duty free status of gas barbecues, including a recommendation that gas barbecues be allowed into this country duty free. We know that in this package a very considerable issue arises over the recommendation for changes in the tariff level on vegetable products. I will be saying something shortly about an amendment which we would have moved, had we had the opportunity to do so within the framework of the guillotine, drawing attention to the continued anti-rural stance taken by this Government in relation to the vegetable industry, which is the second or third largest crop enterprise and the fifth or sixth largest sector of the agricultural industry.

The seventh Bill in this package is the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill, which increases the duty imposed on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers Region from 11c per kilogram to 80c per kilogram. This is a very considerable package of Bills and, therefore, I want simply to indicate the areas of primary concern to the Opposition on these pieces of legislation.

In relation to the Customs Valuation Amendment Bill, we are concerned primarily with clause 9, which we would have sought to delete. Clause 9 provides that the time framework specified within section 161d (1) of the Customs Act 1901 should be altered. At the moment section 161d (1) of the Customs Act provides:
At any time within 12 months after the making of a determination or other decision by an officer under this Division, the Comptroller may review the determination or other decision and may-

It then lists a series of specified things. The amendment before us leaves that an open-ended commitment by removing the time limit specified-namely, within 12 months. We would have moved an amendment to seek to delete that in order, we believe, to facilitate greater certainty and operation for the assessment of payments which need to be made properly under the Customs Valuation Act.
As to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading:
At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the uniform general tariff rate of duty on power electronic goods under reference should be further reduced in the medium to long term''.

The Opposition has clearly established a belief that all reasonable steps should be taken to wind back levels of tariff and protection on goods which are currently subject to various rates in a controlled and sustained fashion. Over the last couple of years the Opposition has taken the view that a consistent attack upon tariff levels needs to be mounted. That would be a practical indication of our concern about this matter.

We would have moved to eliminate Part V of the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill which amends the Fertilisers Subsidy Act, and about which I do not propose to go into great detail. It was, however, made abundantly clear in Mr Moore's speech during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives that the Opposition is very concerned about the clauses of the legislation which relate to the Fertilisers Subsidy Act, giving effect to the Government's decision last year to remove the subsidy payable on imported fertilisers, which is a subsidy on consumption, and reallocate those savings by increasing subsidy payments on locally produced phosphatic fertilisers. This has been a matter for debate on a number of occasions in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. We have expressed our view on the matter and, in particular, on the subsidy which we believe in large part is being directed in entirely the wrong direction. We believe that the amendments proposed to the legislation should be opposed.

I also draw attention to the amendments which are made in this legislation to the Bounty Books Act. There are a couple of things to be said here. The first is that the legislation continues the chopping and changing which has occurred in regard to the arrangements under the Bounty Books Act, which has been the subject of fairly consistent amendment over quite a number of years. Once again, it is an attack upon the way in which the Act operates. However, on this occasion the legislation is responding to concerns which were expressed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in relation to the powers of the Comptroller-General to make certain determinations which were not subject to proper review and scrutiny by the Parliament. As you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has been particularly active in ensuring that delegated legislation is subject to proper parliamentary scrutiny. When the legislation was before us on the last occasion, making changes to the long term protection arrangements for the book printing industry, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee indicated its concern. Correspondence went backwards and forwards between the Committee and Minister, and the Minister gave certain undertakings that the legislation would be amended to enforce the principle of parliamentary scrutiny which had been of concern to the Committee. This legislation now gives effect to the undertaking given by the Minister at the time. We are very pleased to see that that undertaking has been honoured and that the work of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has once again proved valuable to this chamber. I might also mention that the amendments to the Bounty Books Act continue to increase the range and type of books which are to be excluded from the bounty by amending section 5 of the Act to insert a new paragraph 11 (5a):

a book whose printing and publishing by a person, or whose sending by a person through the post, constitutes or would constitute an offence by a person against the law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory.

It may be recalled that some years ago-I think it was when I was first in this chamber in 1978 or 1979-amendments were moved by me and others to provide that the bounty for book production should not be paid on pornographic books which, if they had been sought to be imported, would have fallen foul of what was then Regulation 4a of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. We were concerned that a very considerable amount of bounty had been paid on pornographic books which, because they met the description under the Act, namely that they were more than 49 pages long, were casebound, et cetera, attracted bounty under the Act. A considerable amount of the bounty was paid. I well remember getting into very considerable difficulty with a firm called Griffin Press in Adelaide which, despite having all sorts of knights of the realm on the board and doing worthy things like publishing the Adelaide Advertiser, also had some subsidiary companies which were making a very considerable sum of money out of the government by publishing pornographic books and getting the bounty for them.

The old section 8 of the Book Bounty Act was amended to provide for a test involving the department and the Attorney-General's Department deciding whether a book would have been a prohibited import under regulation 4a, in order to exclude it from the operation of the Act. When the Act was substantially rewritten a few years ago that provision became paragraph (1) (s) of the legislation, and the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 now tidies up a further loophole that has been clearly identified.

Ordinarily the Opposition would not have proposed any amendments to the Excise Tariff Validation Bill 1987 or to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1987. We would have specifically sought to address ourselves to some matters arising under the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendments Bill 1987 in relation to amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats. I will refer further to that matter in a moment. In relation to the Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1987, I formally move an amendment circulated in the name of the Opposition. I move:

At end of motion add '', but the Senate is of the opinion that the long term tariff rate in respect of processed vegetable products should initially be phased down to 15 per cent rather than 10 per cent as proposed by the Government''.

As I said earlier in my remarks, the vegetable industry is a very important industry in Australia. It was the subject of an Industries Assistance Commission report of 29 April 1986 concerning vegetable products. Although it must be conceded that the recommendation of the IAC was that the import of certain classes of processed vegetables be dutiable at a general rate of 10 per cent we acknowledge that that is a long-term objective to be achieved, and that in fact at this stage the dutiable rate should be 15 per cent rather than 10 per cent, with further consideration of what should occur being delayed until the effect of the introduction of a 15 per cent rate is assessed. We believe that the Minister was initially disposed to the 15 per cent interim rate but that he was unable to persuade his Cabinet colleagues to adopt that point of view.

The vegetable and vegetable processing industry is well spread out throughout Australia. For instance, Victoria produces some 27 per cent of all vegetables grown in Australia, Queensland about 25 per cent and New South Wales 18 per cent; the other States account for 30 per cent in total. This industry is particularly significant for Tasmania. The Tasmanians, for instance, have a very particular problem with the protection of their potato industry. It is a very important industry as far as that State is concerned. I must say that my good friend in the other place, Mr Miles, was roundly abused the other day by the Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones, who referred to his comments on this matter as rendering him subject to the description of being `potatocentric'. Of course, potatoes are very important to Tasmania; they are very important to Mr Miles's electorate, and he is very assiduous in protecting that industry. Indeed, in the past there have been total prohibitions on the importation of potatoes. We are concerned that the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission in this matter are moving events a little too speedily, and I indicate that if the decision had been in our hands we would have phased down the tariff to 15 per cent rather than 10 per cent. That is why I have moved an amendment to that effect to the second reading motion.

The other matter-a matter of some significance-relates to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill. Of course, this Bill would have given the opportunity for a fairly wide-ranging debate on the nature of the Australian uranium industry. We have made it quite clear that we support the development of the Australian uranium industry. I note that my colleague Senator Kilgariff is in the chamber at the moment. As honourable senators know, Senator Kilgariff will be leaving us at the end of this session-voluntarily. I think it would be churlish not to record the fact that Senator Kilgariff has been one of the outstanding proponents and defenders of the rational development of the uranium industry in Australia. He, together with members of the Opposition, has sought to bring about the balanced development of a mining and extractive industry, which has become one of the principal foreign exchange earners for this country. He has been very assiduous in ensuring that the interests of the balanced development of the uranium industry in the Northern Territory are properly and adequately protected. When we have had the opportunity to debate matters regarding the uranium industry itself-such as land rights questions or environment and conservation questions-he has ensured that the Senate's attention has been properly focused upon the development of that industry and the unreal restrictions which have been imposed upon it by the Australian Labor Party in government. His outstanding contribution as a senator for the Northern Territory stands in marked contrast to the records of other senators who have ignored the interests of the Territory. I have no doubt that Senator Kilgariff's successor, Mr Tambling, when he comes into this chamber will be able to pick up on the very fine work that Senator Kilgariff has done over a large number of years.

Nevertheless, the whole question of the development of the uranium industry is of very considerable importance. This particular piece of legislation proposes a change in the payment regime to increase the duty imposed upon exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers region from 11c per kilogram to 80c per kilogram. We would have clearly made the point that the fostering and developing of the industry, particularly in the Northern Territory, is a matter of considerable national significance. We would have had the opportunity had the operation of the guillotine not prevented it, to discuss that matter in some considerable detail.

As I said, we will not be able to go into the Committee stages of these Bills because of the operation of the guillotine. I have therefore indicated our concerns on the principal items within this package of seven pieces of legislation, and the amendments that we would have moved had we been going into the Committee stages. I have moved two amendments to the second reading motion, one of which relates to the tariff rate of duty on power electronic goods, while the other relates to the phasing down of the assistance provided to the vegetable industry.

Nevertheless, the Opposition does not intend to oppose any of the Bills or to vote against them. However, we believe that the Government's overall approach to the way in which it manages customs and tariff bounty and subsidy arrangements is increasingly ad hoc and increasingly related to its political prejudices particularly in relation to industries like the uranium industry.

When we come to government after the forthcoming Federal election we are very keen to ensure that a greater degree of certainty, a greater degree of rationality, a greater degree of predictability and a greater degree of sense as to what is truly in the national interest is brought into debates on excise, tariff, bounty and subsidy matters. I hope that my remarks in relation to this package of Bills clearly indicated the general thrust of policy that the Opposition will adopt when we occupy the treasury bench after the forthcoming election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to intrude into this debate for any length of time. I am very grateful that Senator Puplick is not opposing the legislation, as I understand it. I remind him that since this Government has been in office the Opposition has not opposed, I think with one exception, any tariff changes made by this Government. Since this Government has been in office, the whole Opposition policy on tariffs and industry policy has been a classic example of me-tooism of the first kind-and that cannot be screamed loud enough. In relation to the Bills being debated tonight I will draw attention to some of the things said by Senator Puplick. He kept talking about principle. It is always a matter of great concern when that word is bandied about by a politician. The principle here tonight is that the tariff on power electronics should be lower and the tariff on frozen potatoes-and I take it that the honourable senator was referring to frozen and not processed potatoes-should be higher. That is not a principle; it was dictated, or suggested, to him by his colleague from Tasmania for reasons of political expediency. I find it very strange that in considering the principles involved Senator Puplick did not consider the whole package brought forward by the Government in relation to the vegetable industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact of the matter in regard to that package is that some tariffs have been raised to a 10 per cent rate, some tariffs are at a zero rate, and a third group of tariffs will be phased down. The purpose of all that is to encourage growth in those sectors of the industry previously inhibited by tariff considerations. The whole thing is put up as a package which I assure honourable senators is rational and sensible. Senator Puplick went off on a flight of fancy to talk about what a Howard led government-and I remind the honourable senator that it would be a Howard led government, which is something he has had a few things to say about on television-would do in respect of these matters. It would introduce rules of certainty and rationality, which is the expression Senator Puplick used, into the consideration of industry protective regimes, or barrier protection.

I point out that there is no rationality or certainty about what Senator Puplick said tonight. The honourable senator would know that the largest importer of frozen potatoes in this country is the company that has been kicking up the most fuss about the lowering of the tariff. He would know that imports are coming into this country because demand cannot be satisfied. I hope the honourable senator knows these things; he should know them, because he happens to belong to a more sensible faction of the Liberal Party which has now been relegated to the back bench. The shadow Minister is not here tonight because he is in some room on the other side of the building helping to work out the Opposition's tax policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just getting organised.

—Getting organised, you call it, Senator. I wish him every bit of luck. It is a cruel fate to befall a senator of Senator Puplick's ability to be relegated to exile to the back bench with the rest of the talent in the Liberal Party. It is a cruel fate that tonight Senator Puplick has to be in here debating something that he does not quite understand. He was told to talk about principle and so on-but there were no principles in his speech-while his own shadow Minister, the person who should be here-I will not remind anybody of his name because nobody else knows it-is downstairs working out a tax policy scrabbled together for the Opposition for the forthcoming election.
—He is choosing his office for when he is in government.

—I would not be surprised if that is what he is doing. I see people reeling out of the tax policy decision-making room, white, shaken and mopping their brows. He is probably going round looking at furniture and so on, because that is about all he is fit for.

SPEECH.PARA: I rose only to say that I am disappointed in Senator Puplick. The package in relation to the vegetable industry is a very forward looking and sensible one. It is not part of this Government's attack on rural industries. I draw the honourable senator's attention to the fact that rural industry protection has been rising--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Can you give me some assistance? I cannot work out why the Minister is speaking when he is not on the speakers list. Is he closing the debate? It seems very irregular that a Minister should get up during speeches at the second reading stage. It is normal for Ministers to close debates. Can I have a ruling on that?
—There is no point of order. The Minister is quite entitled to enter into the debate.

—I think that the honourable senator was dozing when I got up to speak. I just wanted to respond briefly to what might euphemistically or charitably be described as the points made by Senator Puplick and to point out that they were rendolent with inconsistency and uncertainty.
—Redolent.
—Redolent-I am scared to say `red'; that is the problem, Senator.
—You have used that word twice today and you got it wrong twice.

—Every time I stand up in this place I get terrorised by Senator Boswell. I cannot even speak the language properly. I apologise to honourable senators. I want to tell Senator Puplick something: Potato was deep in the dark underground, tomato above in the light; the little tomato was ruddy and round, the little potato was white. The honourable senator knows the rest. They finally end up in an Irish stew-and that is what his speech was about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I wish to speak to only one Bill in this package of legislation, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, and to refer to some amendments about which I will not be able to speak at great length at the Committee stage. However, if we run out of time in this debate, which has been guillotined, I will seek to use the contingency notices of motion that we have on the books to move a batch of amendments dealing basically with new clause 25a. That series of amendments would put on the statute book an operation which I believe is vitally necessary in terms of Australia's trade, particularly with the United States of America. While a 2 : 1 imbalance has existed since 1952, the United States Congress is moving in a whole range of areas further to cut off current access to the United States market and ultimately to restrict or exclude a number of our exports to the United States in total.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, the current political situation in the United States is that the Administration is relatively powerless. It is totally pre-occupied with the Contragate hearings, and the focus of decision-making within the United States has now moved to Congress. The omnibus trade Bill which has been passed by the House of Representatives in the United States had in its debating procedures an amendment referred to by the name of the person who moved it, the Gephardt amendment. Essentially this amendment means that, where the United States has a trade deficit, if a number of other procedures which I will go into in a moment are there, that will trigger a mechanism whereby the United States will impose higher and higher tariffs until the other country tries to do something about its surplus.

In terms of Australia's deficit of trade with the United States I think there is general agreement of all parties in Australia that we can wear that deficit, but what we cannot wear is a continuing weakening of our access to the United States markets. I can give as an example sugar. In 1980 Australia exported to the United States 800,000 tonnes of raw sugar. In 1985 terms that amounted to about $US100m. This year our quota is 74,000 tonnes. So 800,000 tonnes has been restricted to 74,000 tonnes-that is, a loss of nearly $US60m in revenue to Australia. The current operation in the United States will mean that the quota that we are selling to it will disappear in two years, according to Secretary Ling, so that we will lose an additional $US38m in the next two years. At the end of that two-year period we will be exporting no sugar to the United States.

When one considers that the United States is the largest sugar market in the world we will have suffered a combined loss in terms of our sugar market alone of $100m. When one considers that sugar is one of the major products of Queensland and that indeed it is the sole support for a large number of our regional economies that is an absolutely devastating blow-certainly one of the most serious blows, if not the most serious blow, to an agricultural product that has been suffered by Australia in the last 10 years. Of course, we have had enormous problems with regard to wheat, but we have been able to sell all of our wheat.

The difficulty with sugar is in creating new markets. The only growing markets for sugar happen to be in underdeveloped countries, and almost every one of those countries has its indigenous and expanding sugar industry. The Australian sugar industry has suffered an enormous blow as a result of the European Community's subsidised exports of sugar. We now face losing our total market to the United States. The duty drawback operation, while it technically comes under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, will be in violation of the spirit and I believe the letter of GATT. Essentially, the duty drawback operations will mean that the duty payable on all raw sugar imported into the United States to be processed by the United States refineries and re-exported will not be for the last two years as is normal under the GATT agreement but for the last 10 years.
