We will give to the United States industry a $US200m export subsidy. So we can look forward in two years time to the United States sugar industry exporting heavily subsidised sugar on to the world market and again driving the world sugar price through the floor. We are still expected to look kindly on the United States and its arrangements with us.

Two weeks ago I was part of the all-party delegation to the United States Congress. We spent a number of days in Washington talking with congressmen and senators on the half hour. We got a single unified message from them that they were going to respond to the political imperatives within the United States political system. A number of those congressmen and senators said to us that it really does not matter because we will not do anything. We ought to have on the books the ability for the Minister to do something if we are backed into a corner not only on sugar but also on casein, on lamb, on wheat, on barley, on rice, and on so many other agricultural product markets that have been devastated. Let us look at barley, for example. Our $4.3 billion barley exports to Saudi Arabia, the largest barley market in the world, were slashed in half in one year because the United States sold into a market in which it had rarely sold before, in direct competition with our producers. The United States knew that it was only our producers who were selling barley in quantity on the Saudi Arabian market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that subsidised?

—That was subsidised. Anything produced in the United States ends up being subsidised. Our farmers are not competing against United States farmers. In fact, our agricultural production in almost every commodity is at least twice as efficient as United States agricultural production. For example, we produce wheat for exactly half the cost in United States dollars per bushel that the United States farmers produce it for. So we have no worries about competing against United States farmers on a fair market internationally because we will beat them every time. But we cannot afford to compete against the United States Treasury. In the current circumstances we are being asked to continue to import from the United States twice as much as we are able to export to that country, and then to sit by while it cuts off the meagre exports we have to its market-to sit by while it cuts off our exports to the United States of sugar, casein, which the United States does not even produce, and for some absurd reason, lamb.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, our lamb producers have offered to assist the United States industry. When one considers the fact that the average American consumes less than one pound of lamb a year, and an Australian consumes about 40 pounds, one realises that there is an absolutely enormous market to be developed in the United States. Our Meat and Livestock Corporation people have been to the United States and have offered to go into joint partnership with the United States lamb industry to promote lamb and to promote the industry within that country. We can benefit from this development. The United States lamb producers can benefit also, but they will not even talk to our people. The Americans are intent upon destroying our markets there but still expect to export to us.

While we were in the United States the Government announced its submarine purchase. We know that $1.3 billion worth of that submarine purchase for our defence systems comes from the United States-another $1.3 billion worth of goods we are buying from it. We are the world's second largest cash buyer-we are not buying on loans that the United States provides- of United States defence equipment. This situation cannot go on indefinitely. How can we possibly afford to continue to buy from the United States when it plunders our markets within its own operation? I believe we should support the amendments which I will move-they are written in identical terms to the Gephardt amendment which is attached to the United States legislation-and have a go at those markets that stand in surplus to the United States, in other words the Japanese market. We should be following the terms of the Gephardt amendment. In those bilateral trading arrangements which are $3 billion out of kilter, our trade with the United States is $3 billion out of kilter; where that market is worth at least $7 billion, our bilateral trade with the United States is worth $7.2 billion; where the value of foreign goods is at least 75 per cent greater than that of domestic goods, which happens to be the circumstances between Australia and the United States, and where the United States is engaging in massively unfair trading practices, which are directed, so it says, at the European Economic Community, our markets are affected. Unfortunately, this affects almost solely our markets because the European Economic Community has the money to continue to subsidise its products, but we do not. It is shooting at the United States and we are getting the bullets.

This amendment would not place a mandatory power on the Minister; the power would be discretionary and it would have exactly the same effect as the Gephardt amendment. In other words, it would give the Minister power, on a yearly basis, to put a 10 per cent surcharge on all American goods coming into this country until America sees that it cannot engage in those types of tactics with a country which has moved very rapidly not to a totally free trade operation, but to one of the most fair trade positions of any of the trading nations in the world.

It seems extraordinary that we should be able to continue operating with the United States and yet sit by while it continues to restrict our access to its markets and continues to demand expanding entry to our markets. On a per capita basis, a United States citizen buys $11 worth of Australian goods while Australian citizens buy $350 worth of United States goods. That imbalance cannot continue indefinitely. We cannot afford that type of imbalance in our trading relations. We ought to be able to give the Government the discretionary power to retaliate against the United States if it continues the types of policies which are so destructive to Australia's rural industries.

As I have said before-I emphasise it now-Australian producers have absolutely no difficulty whatsoever in engaging in a fair trading operation with the United States producer. In almost every one of our primary production areas we would always be able to sell ahead of the United States producer. However, the extent of support given to the United States farmer is staggering from our viewpoint. On average the United States farmer receives 50 per cent of his income direct from the taxpayer. How can we possibly fight against that type of operation? The notion of complete equity in bilateral trade is absurd. Essentially, Australia could wear the imbalance with the United States of America, provided that it could operate in a trading surplus with other countries-as, of course, it does. The ultimate judgment on international trade should be made on a multilateral, not a bilateral basis. However, there are maximum and minimum points for that, and the minimum requirement with the United States of America must surely be that it does not further restrict our access to that market. We are already suffering all sorts of tariffs and subsidy arrangements in going into that market, yet 75 per cent of the goods that come into Australia from the United States of America come in at less than a 5 per cent tariff-almost free entry. That situation is weighted most favourably towards the United States of America. We cannot afford an operation whereby it is allowed to restrict our markets without retaliation.

I have foreshadowed the amendment because, in the meetings that I had with congressmen and senators as part of the delegation, the message that came through clearly was that unless Australia shows some sort of retaliation, that will hit the United States of America in some way, our friends in the United States of America congress will not have an argument to kill the amendment that is attached to the Senate trade bill and which, when it goes to the conference floor, is likely to end up in the finally agreed version. Whether President Reagan will have sufficient power to veto it when it reaches him some time towards the end of September is anybody's guess. I do not believe that we can afford to wait on that factor.

We must give a signal to the United States of America Congress, and this amendment would give such a signal. It is vital for the Government to have that sort of power. I have made it not mandatory, but discretionary. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) can say that the Government would never use the power, but having it in our legislative armoury would give some support to him. I must say that he has probably done as good a job as, if not a better job than, most of our trade Ministers during the past 30 years, for example, in getting together the Cairns group and working very hard for the establishment of free trade operations throughout the world. However, I do not believe that the Minister can be successful unless we show some determination to retaliate when we are pushed against the wall.

This amendment is a shot across the bows and we should pass it. If we at least do that, we will show the United States of America Congress that, ultimately, when we reach a certain point we will retaliate and take our trade elsewhere. Practically every item that we import from the United States of America could be imported from some other country. We are not helpless in that regard. We do not want to do that; we want to continue and expand our trading relationships with the United States of America as a country with which we have always had the most friendly and cordial relationship. I think that that is the generally agreed position of all parties in Australia. However, as someone said recently, and as Ralph Hunt is wont to tell a number of congressmen, with friends like the United States of America, who really needs enemies?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, are you referring to Committee stage amendments rather than second reading amendments?
—I am sorry. They are Committee stage requests. If we do not have time I shall seek to move a contingency motion, through the suspension of Standing Orders.
—An amendment has been circulated by the Australian Democrats relating to uranium exports. Will that be moved by someone else?
—As I said at the beginning of my speech, the amendments relate to the customs tariff legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am addressing the remainder of the Bills in this package on behalf of the Australian Democrats. I point out that a number of the Bills, although they have been termed urgent, are in fact not urgent. Indeed, some of them have been hanging around for quite some time and have not come up on the Notice Paper. In regard to the Customs (Valuation) Amendment Bill 1987, an Opposition amendment to clause 9 will be moved to disallow the change to the Act which gives unlimited time for the Comptroller-General of Customs to review decisions or determinations of officers concerning the amount of duty that is to be levied or refunded to people going through Customs. This will require people and agents to keep an inordinate amount of paperwork over a long time and will add costs and red tape to customs operations. It will also be difficult for agents to recover moneys or reimburse clients over a quite long period, and the Australian Democrats will be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a proposed amendment to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1987 which will retain the existing level of exemption from customs duties for incoming international travellers. The Opposition did not support our amendment to the Sales Laws Amendment Bill on the wimpish ground that it is a Budget measure. I trust that the Opposition will have no reservations in this case where we are continuing this measure which will return the normal travel arrangements to what they were.

Another proposed amendment seeks to remove the right to import duty free alcohol and tobacco. Senator Puplick has already made an unwarranted attack on the Democrats concerning our previous support of the inward bound duty free shops. Indeed, the Government brought in legislation in this context and sold it to the Democrats on the basis of safety on aircraft. It was argued that it was preferable to have those types of goods, which are not unique, actually stored in Australia and not carried on aircraft thus producing extra weight. Senator Puplick was way off course, as he sometimes is. Even though he has great eloquence, the content is sometimes very fanciful.

Senator Macklin has dealt with our amendment to this Bill to reciprocate against the unfair trading practices by the United States of America and by other countries which might export large volumes of goods to Australia, or to countries where such goods compete with goods produced in Australia. This is an important amendment if we are to mature in trading relations with the rest of the world and be prepared to move not only in the use of terms and conditions of trade to influence our trading position in the world but also perhaps to indulge in a little bit of resource diplomacy from time to time to make certain that the larger countries do not walk over us completely.

The next Bill is this package is the Bounty Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. One part of the Bill makes clear that locally produced fertilisers will receive new assistance from 20 August 1986; it will not cut out subsidy at the old rate on imported fertilisers which were already contracted for at that date. We see no problem with this part of the Bill. However, the Opposition proposes to move an amendment to disallow this part of the Bill. We feel that this is a cynical political move which we will not be supporting in any way. We would, however, like to see a subsidy to all farmers in compensation for the heavy tariff costs which they meet on equipment and chemicals, while they are forced to compete for sales on the open world market where other countries heavily subsidise their agriculture and rural exports. Such a subsidy could be paid from duty received on imports of this type. We could phase out tariffs on those products simultaneously. I believe a system of bounties rather than tariffs would be much better. The fertiliser subsidy could then be treated honestly according to the needs of the local fertiliser industry. We would then not have to be dishonest about the way in which we use the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which produces bad reactions amongst our trading partners and does not help the people we are trying to help.

The Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1987 is intended to validate the Customs Tariff Proposals in three main areas-vegetables and vegetable products; luggage, handbags and similar products; and giving gas barbecues made in New Zealand duty free entry. The vegetable proposals are quite unacceptable in that they have a detrimental effect on industry which is struggling to restructure. I have heard Senator Button speak on the subject. The industry seems to have real problems currently which have be exacerbated by the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand, but it will have to live with this. The vegetable industry has developed a central plan which will bring a remarkable degree of co-operation between unions, growers and processors. I hope this plan will bring some measure of stability to the industry, which has suffered desperately for many years from low prices, high costs and, at best, only marginal viability. The industry went to the Government asking for co-operation; in particular, it asked for a stable domestic environment with a sufficient tariff to ensure this. It is estimated the necessary level to be 15 per cent. The Government will phase the level down to 10 per cent in 1992. This is much below the level which should be accepted.

Tomato growers in the Riverland in South Australia, potato and onion growers in cooler regions of the State, and particularly growers in Tasmania, are fearful about the future. Tomato paste imports, for example, will have the tariff lowered from the current level of 48 per cent to 10 per cent. Potato products have also had their protection drastically cut.

We are not happy with the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill and will propose some amendments to it. We do not believe that the duty is sufficiently high. The Bill seeks to raise the export duty on uranium produced in the Alligator Rivers region in Kakadu National Park from 11c to 80c a kilogram to cover half the costs of the environmental monitoring and research in that area. The Bill comes into effect as from the date of announcement; that is, 19 August 1986, except for any loadings or consignments which were under way at that date. Also exempted is a contract for 800 tonnes between Queensland Mines Ltd and Electricite de France whose delivery was delayed under the 1983 embargo on uranium exports to France. Queensland Mines later bought back this uranium after the embargo was lifted but it is to be exempt from the increased levy. This is scandalous.

The levy is expected to raise an extra $2.6m per annum, which will cover around half of the annual cost of the relevant duties of the Office of the Supervising Scientists. We believe that it should cover the total cost of the Supervising Scientist. The Australian Democrats are opposed to the mining and export of uranium and particularly to mining of uranium in the Kakadu National Park. Furthermore, uranium is a national resource and it seems it is being mined and sold with no payment to the people of Australia for the loss of the resource which they own. It seems reasonable that any such mines should at least carry full responsibility, not only for all on-going costs of environmental supervision but also for full and unlimited liability for any damage caused to the environment or people and for the final clearing up and restoration of the area. We will move an amendment to put some money into a trust fund.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Entry to Australia of Controversial Visitors-Telecom Australia: Management-Australian War Memorial

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 December last year I asked the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs a series of questions on the Hawke Government's policy regarding the entry to Australia of what are known as `controversial visitors'. I asked the Minister what the Government's policy was on the entry of such visitors and whether any changes had been made to that definition and policy. Today I received a response from the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) for which I am grateful, which I believe indicates an alarming shift in the Government's policy towards controversial visitors. This is a shift which, in many ways, could be seen as giving the green light to the entry of terrorists to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has revised its policy on controversial visitors. The response that I received from the Minister today said that the Government's policy on such visitors sought to balance its support for human rights, including the freedom of speech and movement, with its desire to keep Australia free from international terrorism and violence. The Minister said:
The primary criteria applied in deciding whether to accept or reject a visa application are:
Whether the person has planned or participated in, and/or has been active in promoting, acts of politically-motivated violence or criminal violence, including acts of terrorism in particular;
Whether the person is likely to propagate or encourage such actions during a visit to Australia and/or pose some threat or harm to the Australian community; and
Whether the person seeks to enter Australia as the representative of a government not recognised by Australia.

I also asked for the categories of controversial visitors-both individuals and representatives of organisations-under existing policy. The Minister's response was that the controversial visitor policy was applied on a case by case basis and that there were no categories of controversial visitors except, as noted in the earlier response, persons claiming to represent governments not recognised by Australia. My third question last December was:
Has the Government taken any steps to liberalise or change the policy regarding the entry of `controversial visitors' into Australia in recent months; if so, what are the changes that have been made.
The response to that today was:
The Government considered its policy on controversial visitors last December.
That is, December 1986. It continued:
The Government adopted the policy formulated above.
That is, the policy that I have just read. The response continued:

Now mere membership of, or an association with, an organisation which has at any time in the past advocated violence as a means of achieving political goals, will no longer constitute sufficient reason to refuse a visa. Cases are now decided on their individual merits.

That is the response that I received from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. This admission must be of concern to all Australians. Foreigners who have advocated violence will not, for that reason alone, any longer be refused entry into Australia. Foreigners who are members of well-known terrorist organisations or officials of countries which have sponsored terrorism, will not, as a matter of normal practice, be refused entry into Australia. The Minister said that cases are now decided on their individual merits.

Further, the Minister in his response to my question indicated what this amounted to. In the case of the visit of the Palestine Liberation Organisation advocate and member Ms Mysoon Shaath late last year, the Minister confirmed that his Department, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, was unaware of her membership of the Palestine Liberation Organisation. She did not indicate on her visa application her membership of the General Union of Palestinian Women or that she was a representative of Palestinian women on the Palestinian National Council. Because she had not done that, this was enough for the Immigration Department to conclude that there was no problem with her application, and so it passed and she came in.

At the time of her visit I brought that matter up in the Senate. Reliable sources who contacted the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs after she had arrived-this is why I did bring it up on the Senate-were told that the Department had indicated that it was unaware of Ms Shaath's visit. But communication with the Department of Foreign Affairs revealed that that Department did know of Ms Shaath's visit, and six months later this disturbing revelation has now been confirmed by the responsible Minister, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —No co-ordination.

—There was no co-ordination at all. I ask: Just what is the Immigration Department doing? Why did it fail to check the credentials of Ms Shaath? After all, she is a well known member of the PLO and it would not have taken too much effort for the Department to ascertain this.
—And a friend of the Socialist Left in Victoria.

—Very much so. Her visit was connected with that. But this is not the first time that advocates of violence as a legitimate form of political activity have slipped into Australia unbeknown to the responsible government authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: In November last year, Abdul Akhbar Mohammad, a radical white racist preacher, slipped into Australia. Again, the Immigration Department did not know that he was in the country. Indeed, the then responsible Minister, Mr Hurford, explicitly informed this Parliament that Mr Akhbar would be refused entry into Australia. But do honourable senators know what happened? The following day he appeared on the Ray Martin Show advocating violence as a legitimate political weapon.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt also invited by the Socialist Left.

—No doubt. The toing and froing that went on in the corridors of the Department of Immigration and the the Department of Foreign Affairs over the transit of eight South Pacific islanders on their way to Libya last year is yet another instance of this Government's slack security arrangements. Despite the production of the necessary docu- ments to show their travel arrangements, the group was initially refused transit visas. Yet, two days later, transit rights were allowed. An article entitled `Pacific Delegation to Libya Obstructed', appearing in the socialist newspaper Direct Action, reported:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian authorities were forced to allow the eight islanders through on 15 November.

Why did the Government change its mind? According to an Australian Broadcasting Corporation report of 12 November, the eight islanders were on their way to Libya to be trained as bodyguards for top Vanuatu Government officials. Given the links that Libya has forged with that Government, it would appear that the islanders were really on their way to Libya for terrorist training.

These events and the change in the Government's policy on controversial visitors have alarming and disturbing implications for the security of Australians. Surely now is not the time, when the once placid and stable South Pacific region-Australia's own backyard, of which Australia is a very important part and in which it wishes to play an important part in co-operation with its neighbours-has undergone a rapid transformation with events in Fiji and increasing involvement of troublemakers of the likes of Libya's Colonel Gaddafi, for the Australian Government to relax its controversial visitors policy.

It is imperative that the Australian Government take every step to reassure Australians that it is taking measures to ensure that they will be protected from the ravages from unwanted and troublesome visitors. The Minister's response to my question demonstrates the hollowness of the assurances of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Australian people-that he would not go soft on terrorists and that he would act swiftly and decisively on the threats of terrorism in our region.

The visits of Mysoon Shaath and Abdul Akhbar Mohammad were organised by an Australian group called the Australian People's Congress which is closely linked to Colonel Gaddafi. Mr Robert Pash, the Director of this Congress-he was until recently, but I am not sure whether he is now-in addition to now being the Director of the Libyan Arab Cultural Centre in Victoria, has had a lot of publicity lately. It was his organisation which organised the recent Australian delegation to the Matabah Conference in Libya.

Mr Mansell, who is an Aboriginal activist and director of the Commonwealth funded Tasmanian Legal Aid Centre, was a member of that delegation. He stirred up much controversy-as we are well aware-because of his outrageous comments at that Conference. They included his willingness to accept financial support from Libya to pursue his aim of creating a separate Aboriginal nation, with violence if necessary. This incident quite rightly severely embarrassed the Government. It prompted the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) to reprimand Mr Mansell and initiate an inquiry into the affairs of the Tasmanian Legal Aid Centre.

A fundamental responsibility of any government is to maximise the security of its people. It appears that both through a deliberate policy shift and inefficient intelligence and administration, the Government is not adequately fulfilling its vital responsibility. It has been a bipartisan policy for many years that members of known terrorist organisations, including the Palestine Liberation Organisation and its affiliates, should not be allowed entry into Australia.
The Hawke Government's decision to reverse this policy can only serve to put at risk the security of Australians and world leaders and notable figures who frequently visit Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a few matters which come out of Estimates committees and which were curtailed and could not be examined at that stage because of the guillotine.
—You should be sticking up envelopes for the election.

—I care about the country. I wish to raise a point which the honourable senator might find of interest. It relates to Senator Button's portfolio. The Inglis report of the Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements observed that Telecom Australia is responsible for 31 per cent of Commonwealth purchases in the area of high technology. Time after time Telecom has taken the view that it must protect monopolies in the market place. Indeed, woe betide the small Australian company which wants to do business with Telecom but will not agree to assigning to Telecom complete rights to a product.

SPEECH.PARA: Tender specifications indicate that this willingness to give Telecom exclusivity is a major factor in tender decisions. Undoubtedly, that suits Telecom and its multi-national suppliers. Telecom continues to con people into believing that it supplies all the equipment. The multi-nationals have an extra outlet and are able to prevent an indigenous research-based industry from taking any hold. These multi-national companies are also able to decide where they take their profits, whether here or abroad, by using transfer pricing arrangements which they can set up by using the value ascribed to assembly work in Australia as a means of changing the price of their product. They are able to offer high Australian content because Australia-based competitors have to use the cost of purchase in Australia for foreign-made components rather than freight-on-board prices overseas which other suppliers can use. The Telecom tender system is wholly against Australian-controlled technology and export earnings.

It is not surprising to find that Telecom refused to tell Estimates Committee C what it had been doing to improve the lot of Australian-based industries in the last year. Of all the government departments and instrumentalities, Telecom alone replied to our Buy Australian question:

This question relates to matters raised by the report of the Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements, (Inglis Committee), which Telecom management has under examination prior to providing advice and recommendations to the Commission and the Minister. Consequently, it would not be appropriate for Telecom to respond to these questions prior to informing the Minister of its position.

This arrogant non-answer was indeed trotted out in relation to what Telecom was doing to minimise any tendency to favour overseas products, the question about what contacts there had been with industrial supplies officers, also to the question about when whole of life costings are in fact made on products which are being purchased or used by Telecom, and even to the questions about how often Telecom has failed to pay an account within 60 days and what Telecom is doing to improve its payments to small business, I do not find it difficult to believe people when they say that they have been treated in an offhand manner by Telecom. The evasions supplied to Estimates committee C reinforced that belief and indeed the impression that Telecom believes that it is a law unto itself.

The same uncompromising arrogance was in evidence over Telecom's response to problems with its Viatel system. The Australian Federal Police have indicated that they were not called in to investigate unauthorised use of code names in the Viatel system. The fact that it was possible for hackers to succeed in the first place is an indictment of the managerial methods of Telecom. The specifications for the computer phone and other Telecom approved products were in fact supposed to prevent the 10-digit password to the Viatel system from appearing on the screen, and yet these things have happened because of software faults. In addition Telecom was alerted about a deficiency in its Page 924 facility, which makes it possible for someone with the four-digit code of a user to obtain the 10-digit password and hence unauthorised access to the system.

Unfortunately telecom itself became a victim of this practice. It appears that someone styling himself Robin Hood was able to write down the four-digit codes for the Prahran and Camberwell business offices in Melbourne and then to get access through the passwords, which the Page 924 facility provided during the months of February and March 1986. Just as Telecom has strict rules for unauthorised phone usage and who is held responsible for the bill, it issues this warning to Viatel users:
If you let anyone else use your customer identity number, you will be charged for their use of Viatel.

However, judging by what happened to a constituent of mine, Brett Stokes, in the Robin Hood case, this stricture applies to everybody but Telecom. The Robin Hood character used the passwords for two Melbourne Telecom business offices to access a variety of services including those provided by the Henley Computer which was operated by Mr Stokes. However, Telecom is apparently saying that the password was used fraudulently, and so Telecom should not bear any responsibility for these matters. Although Telecom management threatened to call in the Federal Police, investigations remained internal to Telecom through its own Security and Investigation Branch. The heat was taken off media inquiries by a statement that matters regarding Mr Stokes had been referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions. On 18 December the Victorian Director's office wrote as follows:
As you are aware this office received material from the Australian Telecommunications Commission concerning the possible defrauding of the Commission.
I have decided not to institute any prosecution action based on that material.

Yet in February 1987 Telecom public relations staff were apparently saying the matter was still before the Director of Public Prosecutions. I would like to get an explanation from Telecom about this whole episode. Would the same have occurred if another service user had been in the place of the two Telecom business offices and the password had been used without authority? If so, what standards of proof would have been required about the unauthorised use? Has Mr Stokes been cleared of all possible wrong-doing, or is Telecom continuing its own investigations? What efforts have been made to establish the identity of this `Robin Hood' who sent Mr Stokes a letter from an unknown Melbourne address in terms which question the diligence and technical competence of Telecom? I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter postmarked 1.30 a.m., 9 April, Melbourne, 3000.
Leave granted.
The letter reads as follows-
I am writing in response to the article `Telecom's Men far from merry over `Robin Hood'' that appeared in the Australian on Tuesday the 8th of April 1986, page 23.
As I am the Hacker in question I would like to shed some light on my `Donation' of $500 from a Telecom Viatel Account to the `Henley Computer' a Service Provider on Viatel.

Through using Viatel I had become aware of a bug in Viatel's security. This enabled me to find out a person's 10 digit ID number by watching them key in their 4 digit password. All I had to do then was use their terminal alone for less than a minute to obtain the 10 digit number. This technique only works on a few types of terminals, among them the Telecom Computer Phone.

After using Viatel free of charge for a while, which was nice considering how expensive it is to use, I soon became bored with it as there is little of interest on it so I decided to liven things up a bit by donating some money to the `Henley Computer' which is one of the very few interesting things on Viatel.
By this time I had also decided to inform Telecom of this bug in their security because I did not like the idea of people ripping off small businesses or private individuals.
Much to my surprise, when I did inform Telecom they were already aware of both the bug in Viatel's security and the fault in the Computer Phone, but were not going to do anything about either.

Now that Telecom have become aware that such bugs in security can increase their own Viatel bills and not just other peoples, which would be to Telecom's financial advantage, they seem to be in a hurry to plug the gap in their security.
Unfortunately, Telecom has not reacted well to my use of their funds and have victimised the potential recipient of the $500, Mr Brett Stokes of the Henley Computer.
Telecom will not accept that there is no connection between myself and Mr Stokes, despite talking on the telephone with both of us on separate occasions'.

Further, they have threatened Mr Stokes with action by the Federal Police for a crime he did not commit or even benefit from, as he has not received any of the money I donated and is not likely to, as Telecom have broken their contract to pay him 95% of all frame revenue he receives from Viatel.
If Telecom remove `The Henley Computer' from Viatel they will be judging Mr Brett Stokes as guilty without a scrap of evidence and setting an unhappy precedent for all other Viatel Service Providers.

Also, they will be removing one of the few Service Providers that provide information of interest to the residential users of Viatel, and as residential users make up about 60% of all Viatel users, Telecom should be trying to increase the number of Service Providers who cater for them, not decrease them.

The way Telecom have plugged the gap in this security is very crude and has resulted in thousands of Viatel users no longer being able to program their terminals with their ID number by using page 924.

If Telecom had given it any thought, they would have come up with a very simple and obvious solution to the problem without disadvantaging thousands of users. I know of people who have suggested such solutions to them.
Telecom are also incapable of following their own guidelines for the design of Viatel terminals.
In their publication `Viatel Terminal Specifications', issued 1st July 1984 section 6.2, they stated ``The Terminal shall not display the customer identity number''.
The Telecom Computer Phone is designed to be used as a Viatel Terminal but does not come up to the required specifications, and will display the customer ID number when used with page 924.

People who have bought Viatel Terminals have the right to program in their own ID numbers if they wish, and owners of Computer Phones should not be disadvantaged by sub-standard equipment potentially costing them hundreds of dollars.
Instead of victimising Mr Stokes, Telecom should accept responsibility for their own lack of security.
Robin Hood, Melbourne Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I would like to know whether, during February or March 1986, Viatel messages to and from the Henley computer were being monitored automatically. If that happened, and certainly Telecom has been able to produce print-outs of various messages involving the Henley computer, I would like to know in what circumstances the privacy of Viatel users may be violated, and upon what authority this can happen. Who decides whether any security measures are to be applied, and what criteria have to be met before such action can be contemplated? Similarly, if Telecom receives complaints that messages are offensive, under what circumstances will it take action to have the perceived offensive messages removed? I note that some Telecom spokesmen have said that Telecom does not interfere at all in these areas, yet some service providers in the past have been told that material was unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Who is responsible for making sure that State legislation in relating to gambling or lotteries has not been infringed? Mr Stokes has drawn my attention to months of apparent inaction by Telecom while large corporate interests remained in breach of the South Australian legislation. If any revenues were collected as a result of breaches of the law, what efforts did Telecom make to ensure that those who may have acted illegally did not profit from these activities? Did Telecom itself refund its proceeds from the access people made to Viatel lotteries which contravened the South Australian Lottery and Gaming Act? In other words, have the same standards of conduct been applied to everyone? I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) who is at the table, will refer these matters to his colleague in the other place so that Telecom management will provide a detailed response to the various points which I have raised tonight. I look forward to receiving some answers, or to these answers being made available which will be more in keeping with a proud Australian outfit which values the skills and talents of its staff. I commend this matter to the Minister and ask him to provide this information to his colleague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not weary the Senate with any great response to matters which were raised in the Parliament by Senator Lewis in this chamber and by Mr Tim Fischer in the House of Representatives regarding the Australian War Memorial and the ceremony to mark the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, Mr Tim Fischer having made his contribution last week and Senator Lewis having made his contribution last evening. An attempt was made in both contributions to suggest that the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlement Act at the Australian War Memorial a year ago was somehow significant in the subsequent decisions of the Federal Government, of Cabinet, to recommend to the Governor-General the termination of services of the Director of the Australian War Memorial.

SPEECH.PARA: The Veterans' Entitlements Act is the most important legislative initiative in my portfolio since the Repatriation Act 1920. It ensures that those who serve Australia in wartime receive the care and support they were promised when they went off to war. An information campaign to advise veterans of their entitlements under the new act was planned by the Department of Veterans' Affairs during the parliamentary debate prior to the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. I remind the Senate that that took several months from the time that the House of Representatives dealt with the original Bill. However, once the Act was passed the public relations section of Veterans' Affairs found that it had insufficient resources to implement the campaign to advise veterans of their entitlements.

I stress that a departmental officer suggested that the War Memorial was a suitable venue for the launch of the Act, on the grounds that there was no more suitable way to commemorate veterans' sacrifices than to ensure that their dependants and survivors received the assistance they needed by means of the new Act. However, my Department's public relations director requested that the Minister's office write to the Secretary endorsing a campaign so that the Secretary would make extra resources available to the public relations section to conduct the campaign. These resources included recalling my Department's public relations section's executive officer, Mr Bright, from his secondment to the ACT Fire Brigade inquiry. I am told that in planning the launch there was an initial verbal indication by Mr Bright to my media secretary of qualified reservation from the then Memorial Director, not the detailed memorandum which appears to have been entered in the departmental file which were made available as a result of the freedom of information legislation. My media secretary asked Mr Bright to assure the Director that the purpose of the launch was to ensure that all veterans would learn of the new legislation and their entitlement to benefits, and was not in any sense a political event. To that extent members of the parties were invited to the function. Sir William Keys was an important participant in the launching of the Act.

When no further objections were raised by the Director, my departmental officers and media secretary assumed with good reason that the Director had accepted the genuine intent of the launch-that is, to inform veterans of their entitlements. Some publicity arose out of that proclamation. My staff handle their responsibilities every day without referring routine matters to me. This is the only way that I am able to concentrate on my responsibilities and take the major decisions in my portfolio. No effective Minister could function any differently. I have selected my staff with care and have confidence in their ability to operate on my behalf. I think I can say with absolute assurance that members of my staff enjoy the confidence of the members of my Party as well as the confidence of many, if not most, members of the Opposition for the way in which they deal with matters referred to them.

As no further objections were raised by the director, my office was entitled to believe that it was proper to go ahead with the ceremony. Had the Director raised any further objections, they would certainly not have been overridden, and the matter would have been referred to me. This whole issue is trivial and of no consequence. My staff have acted properly in accordance with their responsibilities. I repeat: At no time did I take any part in the decision to hold the function at the Memorial, nor did any member of my staff instruct or cajole the Director, or anyone else, to hold the function at the Memorial.

Finally, on 27 May I presented in Parliament the report of a management survey conducted by John White Associates in association with a representative of the Public Service Board. John White Associates is a very reputable and capable organisation which was able to make a proper evaluation of the administrative functions of the Australian War Memorial. Mr John White is the brother of the shadow Minister for Defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). He indicated that information to me when he accepted the brief to conduct the management survey. The survey showed without any doubt that the administration of the Australian War Memorial is my concern. I suggest, therefore, that members of the Opposition, particularly vocal members in their capacity as shadow Ministers for Veterans' Affairs, read the report before they make any further comment on the Australian War Memorial.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.59 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Government's policy regarding the entry to Australia of `controversial visitors'.
(2) What are the categories, in terms of individuals and organisations, of `controversial visitors' under existing policy.

(3) Has the Government taken any steps to liberalise or change the policy regarding the entry of `controversial visitors' into Australia in recent months; if so, what are the changes that have been made.
(4) Would any foreigners who have been permitted entry over recent months, not have been allowed entry under the previous definition of `controversial visitors'.
(5) Does the Government have any plans for further changes to the definition of `controversial visitors'.

(6) Which persons, who are either members of the PLO or any of its affiliated organisations, have been permitted entry into Australia since the ALP National Conference in Hobart in July 1986 and who have been refused entry over the same period.

(7) Which persons who are members of other organisations whose members were either, before July 1986 classified as `controversial visitors', or are no longer so classified, have been permitted entry into Australia since July 1986, and how many have been refused entry over the same period.
(8) What are the names of the organisations to which these people belong.
(9) Has Mr Faris Glubb, member of both the Palestine Liberation Front and the General Union of Palestinian Writers reapplied for a visa entry to Australia since July 1986.
(10) Would Mr Glubb be denied visa entry into Australia under existing policy.
(11) Has the Government any plans of permitting Mr Glubb to visit Australia in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's policy on controversial visitors seeks to balance its support for human rights-including freedom of speech and movement-with its desire to keep Australia free from international terrorism and violence.
The primary criteria applied in deciding whether to accept or reject a visa application are:
Whether the person has planned or participated in, and/or has been active in promoting, acts of politically-motivated violence or criminal violence, including acts of terrorism in particular;
Whether the person is likely to propagate or encourage such actions during a visit to Australia and/or pose some threat or harm to the Australian community; and
Whether the person seeks to enter Australia as the representative of a Government not recognised by Australia.

(2) Controversial visitor policy is applied on a case-by-case basis. There are no categories of controversial visitors except, as noted above, persons claiming to represent governments not recognised by Australia.

(3) The Government considered its policy on controversial visitors last December. The Government adopted the policy formulated above. Now mere membership of, or an association with, an organisation which has at any time in the past advocated violence as a means of achieving political goals, will no longer constitute sufficient reason to refuse a visa. Cases are now decided on their individual merits.
(6) No person who is a representative of the PLO has been refused or granted entry since July 1986.

Mr Abu Lughod, a U.S. citizen, Head of the Political Science Department at North Western University in Illinois and a member of the Palestine National Council, was permitted entry in August 1986 to deliver the keynote address at the Australian-Middle East Studies Association Meeting in Canberra. Mrs Mysoon Shaath who was reported by the Australian media as a member of the General Union of Palestinian Women and a representative of Palestinian Women in the Palestinian National Council did not give any indication in her visitor visa application that she was other than an Egyptian citizen, resident of Egypt, and employed as an office manager, planning a private visit to Australia.
(7) Nil.
(8) Not applicable.
(10) and (11) Any application would be considered on its merits against prevailing policy at the time of lodgement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 20 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: I refer to an article in the National Times on Sunday, 5 October 1986 entitled ``Secretive group infiltrates leftist unions'',
(1) Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that officials of the Federated Clerks Unions travelling overseas receive expense payments of up to $230 per day.
(2) Is it appropriate that officials of organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act should grant themselves such expense payments.
(3) Will the Government impose restraints on such expense payments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of the level of overseas travelling expenses paid to officials of the Federated Clerks Union.

(2) It is appropriate and usual for officials of all organisations to be reimbursed for expenses incurred in relation to the performance of their job. The level of such reimbursement is a matter for determination by the organisation concerned.

(3) The imposition of such restraints would be an unwarranted interference in the democratic administration of organisations of employers and employees. The Conciliation and Arbitration Act has, as one of its objectives, to ensure the democratic control of registered organisations. The Act contains detailed provisions for the financial and non-financial administration of such organisations. Provided that such an organisation is complying with those provisions and with its rules, and is not otherwise acting unlawfully, there are no grounds for the Government to interfere in its internal management.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Convention on Tribal and Indigenous Populations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 17 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Has Australia ratified International Labour Organization Convention No. 107 on Tribal and Indigenous Populations; if not, why, and will the Australian Government consider doing so in 1987, the 30th Anniversary of this Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has not ratified ILO Convention No. 107 on Indigenous and Tribal Populations. It has not done so because the Convention, adopted by the International Labour Conference in 1957, is based on the concept of integration as the principal objective of dealing with indigenous and tribal populations which is now outmoded and the subject of criticism in various world fora.

The ILO has itself regarded the Convention as requiring urgent revision. In September 1986, it convened a Meeting of Experts to examine its provisions. Australia was represented at the Meeting. The Meeting recommended that the Convention be revised to replace its present focus on integration by one of respect for the identity of indigenous populations, and that its revision be placed on the Agenda of the International Labour Conference in 1988.

In November 1986 the ILO Governing Body accepted the recommendation of the Meeting of Experts and decided to place the revision of Convention No. 107 on the agenda of the 1988 International Labour Conference for the first of two discussions leading to its revision.
Australia's representative on the Governing Body supported the recommendation of the Meeting of Experts.
Once a revised Convention has been adopted by the International Labour Conference, Australia will give urgent consideration to its ratification.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 18 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of reports that an improved accident reporting scheme introduced by the NSW Joint Coal Board has improved safety and appears likely to reduce accidents and Workers Compensation costs.
(2) Does the Minister believe that the success of this scheme demonstrates that the best way of reducing Workers Compensation costs is to improve safety monitoring and thereby reduce accidents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. The NSW Joint Coal Board introduced a new accident reporting scheme on 1 July 1986. Advice has been received that the main features of the scheme are:

The collection of information on all injuries rather than only injuries involving a compensation claim. This has increased the annual number of incidents reported from approximately 9 000 to about 29 000; and,
The emphasis is on collecting data that is oriented towards prevention rather than towards compensation and insurance related data (as was the case under the old scheme).

The aim of the scheme is to provide better information to assist in the development of strategies directed at reducing the number of accidents, the severity of injuries and workers compensation costs.

Accident reporting schemes are essential for the identification of major problem areas, for the development of preventive strategies and for monitoring the success of strategies put in place. The more detail that can be provided on each accident the greater will be the chances of developing strategies which are successful in the reduction of accidents, the severity of injuries, and costs. The efforts made by the Joint Coal Board in improving their information base should therefore be supported.

At this time it could be said that the scheme, which is prevention oriented, appears to have the potential to reduce accidents and workers compensation costs. However, this will depend to a large extent on how the collected information is utilised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State the following question, upon notice, on 23 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What would be the cost to the Commonwealth of supplying the proposed scale of issue of Divisional maps and Electoral rolls, contained in Recommendation 16 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, Report No. 2.
(2) What would be the cost of implementing the Recommendation in each State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On the basis of average printing costs of approximately $14 for Electoral Rolls and $2 for Divisional Maps the cost to the Commonwealth of the scale of issue proposed in recommendation 16 of the Joint Select Committee Report No. 2 would be $133,196.
(2) The estimated costs of implementing the recommendation in each State are as follows:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1986 (Hansard, page 2009), Senator Peter Baume asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice.

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that public hospitals will be subject to the fringe benefits tax on the difference between the amount allowed for accommodation in nursing awards and the assessed value of that accommodation? Why has the Government decided to reduce further the ability of public hospitals, for example in my State of New South Wales, to cope with the health care crisis in the community by imposing on those hospitals a substantial extra tax burden? Does the Minister suggest that the hospitals should now cash out the benefit by increasing nursing salaries?
Senator Baume also asked the following supplementary question:
Is the Minister telling me that the accommodation provided for nurses in public hospitals is in the nature of a fringe benefit and therefore will attract the tax?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:
Public hospitals are not subject to fringe benefits tax. They qualify as public benevolent institutions and benefits they provide to an employee are exempt from fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 December 1986 (Hansard, page 3254), Senator Parer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that as from 1 July any tax liability arising from receipt of travel allowance payments will be assessed under the Fringe Benefits Tax Act? Does this mean that any excess of travel allowance remaining after responsible expenses have been deducted will be taxed in the hands of the employer, not the employee? In a case such as that of the Treasurer, is it true that any tax liability will be incurred not by the individual receiving the travel allowance but by the Commonwealth Government?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

A travelling allowance is not a fringe benefit within the terms of the fringe benefits tax law. A travelling allowance forms part of an employee's assessable income against which appropriate deductions may be claimed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1987 (Hansard, page 2388), Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Given the importance of the opium poppy industry in Tasmania, is the Minister aware that major producers, India and Turkey, have disregarded international convention provisions against stock build-up in excess of that required to meet current trading needs? Acknowledging the existence of this excess stock will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will not relax its policy of banning codeine imports so that excess stock will not find its way into Australia? Can he also explain why Australia did not call for the vote during the February 1987 United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs in Vienna on implementing previously approved resolutions, and assure the Tasmanian opiate producers that Australia's position was not, as was alleged in some quarters, used as a trade off or negotiation for the entry of Australian products into Turkey?
The Acting Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The 1986 Report of the International Narcotics Control Board (INCB) estimates that currently world supply and demand of opiate raw material for licit purposes are approximately in balance. I am however aware that India and Turkey accumulated excess raw material stocks in the late 70's and that these stocks have been carried forward. I understand that from informal discussions, Turkey has indicated that it is determined to deal with its excess stocks and we understand further that India is significantly reducing its excess stock to a reasonable working level. I am confident that full adherence by all parties to the provisions of the UN Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs will prevent the recurrence of the problem in the future.

The connection in the Senator's question between excess stocks and codeine imports seems to imply a concern that India and/or Turkey might dump their stocks on the international market in order to clear them. In turn, overseas codeine manufacturers might obtain an unfair price advantage, which would enable them to displace domestic production if they were allowed into the domestic market. I have received no information to support concerns about such a connection despite the presence of these stocks since the beginning of the 1980's. At present, Australian production of codeine phosphate satisfies both local demand and substantial export orders. Policy towards the import of codeine will continue to be determined by reference to normal policy considerations such as general trading policy, health and safety factors, international treaty obligations and our overall narcotic control objectives.

The Australian government at the February 1987 UN Commission on Narcotic Drugs sought to safeguard the interests of the Australian licit opiates industry in a way consistent with Australia's national interests both commercially and in the field of narcotic drugs. In the Government's judgement the most effective way to achieve this was to seek consensus on the issue through the negotiation of a resolution which does not threaten Australia's interests in licit opiates and to further define the principles underlying our position in a statement to the session. The Government considers the outcome to be the most acceptable achieved for some time. The Government also notes the moderate and co-operative approach taken by India and Turkey in seeking agreement on the draft text of the resolution.

The approach adopted at the February CND session is not new: Australia has only called for a vote on 4 occasions and has joined in consensus resolutions in the 1970's and each year in the period from 1982 to 1984. Despite adverse resolutions on those occasions on which Australia was forced to call for a vote, the Australian licit opiates industry has continued to grow.

With reference to the Senator's concern about allegations of a possible trade-off for other products, he may be assured that there was no such consideration in Australia's position at the Commission on Narcotic Drugs.
